response_text: The learning environment raises concerns regarding student consent and comfort. Currently, students are required to be filmed as part of the course, with no option to opt out. response_text: This course is very cool. You actually learn how to write a screenplay. You start slow and small, with 5- to 10-page short films, and Prof. Bell walks you through the process, so it's not scary. You also read your screenplay in class, and everybody gives feedback. It's vulnerable, but so constructive. You learn so much from your peers in this course. By the end of it, writing an 80-page script is time-consuming, but not super challenging.

Watching and later analyzing the movies was also a lot of fun, and I learned a lot from reading scripts while watching them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Throughout my entire experience in my Writing 101 class, I was constantly reminded about the importance of citing sources and how to do it correctly. Using these skills helps credit authors for their work while providing different insights into their writing. Another thing I learned was how to find credible and reliable sources. In the Duke library website, sorting articles and novels by "peer reviewed" helps show that the source is backed and approved by other authors, greatly increasing the chances of the writing to be credible. The final major thing I learned was how to format scholarly writing and the language that is acceptable to use throughout my paper. This knowledge is extremely helpful considering almost every class I take in the future will require me to write scholarly papers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned about how African Americans have fought for access to literacy and how their own literacy practices have changed over time. We also developed a way of viewing literacy more broadly than strictly reading/writing. We also learned how to use the Duke Library and how to cite correctly.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: We used cyphers, or short, open discussions that put scholarly works into conversation, as well as our own personal experiences. These helped us see the scholarly works more deeply and in a new light. The learning environment was laid back and very accepting. The professor was very supportive and understood our different work paces. She is VERY good at constructive criticism. I have been in many learning environments where teachers slash writing papers with red ink. This class was very refreshing in that the professor facilitated us being more open-minded about improving our writing and study habits.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Botex did an amazing job at creating a productive and encouraging learning environment for us. She made sure that we all felt supported and respected. In addition, she was very straightforward with her expectations of us and never failed to provide any and all resources we need. I loved the conversation-based structure of the class because it helped me see new perspectives and learn about my classmates. In addition, the freedom we had with when we turned in assignments was very valuable because it taught me how to structure my time well but in a way that I was not stressed. Dr. Botex did an amazing job at providing feedback and making sure we knew that her door was always open.

I also improved my knowledge of different types of papers I will be asked to write in college. I did a personal narrative, literature review, research proposal, and research paper, which I will likely encounter in the future.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This attendance policy is misleading and damaging to the overall course. Students are not allowed to miss more than 2 classes (even with STIMF). If they do, their grade is automatically dropped to an A-. Additionally, students cannot obtain an A without completing 3 “labors,” essentially teaching a whole class period. These expectations aren’t in line with other Writing 101 course expectations.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Grading and assignments were confusing, difficult, and unclear. Workload and expectations are unnecessarily harder and more tedious than other writing 101s.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned a heck of a lot with Professor Taylor. I approach thinking about reproductive issues very differently, knowing the incredible depth of issues they cover. We talked about important topics in the scope of politics, history, and everyday ideas we all encounter. I also gleaned a lot about how to think when reading academia and how to break down dense reading into the crux of the matter. The last important thing I appreciate about this class is that it taught me to think in nonconventional ways, challenging ideas I've had for years, even having me correcting my own language use in my day-to-day life.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Very, very interesting course! I learned how to draft thorough peer responses to my peers' work, learned how to utilize sources, and integrate them into my writing with lots of useful techniques, and how to better utilize the university library to look for relevant sources

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

- How to cite sources in APA format

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned how to write a research paper, how to read critical texts on dialect writing, and how to peer review

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Some of the most useful topics I learned through this course were which citation techniques to use depending on the context, the writing continuum (elements of formal and informal writing, when each can be used), and the course readings provided interesting discussion on the use of dialect in writing and why it should be more accepted throughout society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Looking at writing not as a set of prohibitive rules but a set of conventions set by groups of people
Using the revision process to change high level ideas and structure rather than sentence level changes
To incorporate different sources efficiently and to cite them correctly

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about integrating interviews as data in research writing, reading (and writing) research papers in terms of structure, and approaching citations and external sources in papers (i.e. using the Duke Library to find sources).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I began to delve into the field of linguistics studies, which I had no idea about what it could even encompass in terms of research, arguments, and schools of thought. 
2. I learned that writing is more about creatively utilizing different techniques adapting to certain contexts and audiences rather than stringent rules (sorry prescriptivists)
3. I learned how to craft an academic research paper. I still have a long way to go in terms of perfecting the skill, but at least I know the basics of structure and norms.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One skill I developed is how to get started writing a paper by getting my ideas onto the page and then later going back and revising. I also learned how to structure and complete a forma research paper.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Through this course, I developed valuable skills in formatting research papers, understanding writing on a continuum, and the tradeoff between language prescriptivism and nuances.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Uniquely, interviewing others for first-hand field research, which pushed me outside my comfort zone. The two research paper projects assigned in this course also prompted me to devise a writing workflow and set up a citation database software. (However, these things were not taught in class! I wish they were, and it would be VERY helpful.) Finally, the discussions in the class regarding writing in dialects was highly debatable and approaching the controversial topic challenged me to rethink about previously held ideals.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The instructor was engaged in the class and created a welcoming atmosphere for students. 
The course had the right amount of assignments and appropriate time was given to complete them.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class is absolutely, if not over, well laid out. Everything is very nicely paced with a soft deadline for each section of major assignments. The professor is also super super candid and open to our ideas on class grading, syllabus, and assignment planning. I think this is again another class impossible to fall behind on, given how nicely laid out and paced the reading and writing tasks are. I like these little soft deadlines! And how open the professor is about office hour. When they say reach out, they actually mean it.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Our professor set up a well-organized structure to complete our papers. It usually followed a format of introducing the project with some background readings, in-class discussions on these readings with some writing analyzing the topics, and then starting a research paper using these readings, along with other papers we find on our own, for our sources. This helped me stay focused on the papers and office hours were always available for any feedback.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated the level of interaction between students and with the professor. Professor Asmuth made great efforts to quickly remember and use everyone's name, while implementing group activities so that students get to know each other. Especially during freshmen year, this was a nice addition to building community and I believe group interaction should be kept for future years. Additionally, there was lots of scaffolding and periodic deadlines that prevented the assignments from feeling too overwhelming.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The feature I liked the most was how the research paper projects were "scaffolded", where different stages of the paper were set as several assignments so that the projects were much more manageable, and it also alleviated procrastination. I'd love this to be kept for future years!! 
The readings assigned also served as some scaffolding for subsequent content, which provided a basis for higher-level discussion (instead of just out of nowhere and completely amateurly). For example, they could be used as motivations or sources for the final project. Finally, how additional sources for final projects were provided was really helpful for writing my paper and backing it with sources responsibly.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: One aspect of this course that challenged me to adopt different points of view was the readings on whether dialectal writing should be accepted like the standard dialect of a language. Honestly, I had a lot of internal debate on this issue, and it set me to reach out for opinions of others as I was very troubled by it. I ended up centering my final project on it and it was quite interesting (and relieving) to do so. However, other parts of this class weren't very intellectually stimulating as many of our class discussions were quite shallow. I like the linguistics-related topic of this section but there were few moments where I could say "wow, that was actually interesting!", unlike my other classes in the arts and sciences. I wish more linguistics could be introduced in this class, and more seminal readings by reputed academics could be assigned.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

The amount of reading was fair, and there were 1 or 2 assignments a week. The professor is a nice person and fair grader, but the classroom was not made very engaging and honestly I think class time could be better spent. Also do note that the course has two research project papers with field work components: the first project on slang analysis was quite fun, and the second was based on a debatable topic. This course is still being improved from semester to semester and I hope your experience with it could be better!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course provided an entire new set of language and concepts that are applicable to everyday life. Three specific things that I learned include: that if you are a master of attention, you are half-good at anything, value comes from creating new knowledge and then finding evidence to support your innovative thoughts, and that we can use different forms of attention to shape our reality. First, by being an attentional expert, you can understand how to adapt your attentions in order to have a greater understanding of any given situation. Second, it's important to be creative and generate new knowledge and fresh thoughts. Third, understanding different methods of attending to situations can give you the opportunity to build the world around you and the way that you want to view situations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: As for knowledge this course imparted on to me wholly new knowledge about attentions and attention literacy. Related to this, I learned methods of switching my perception of myself/surroundings in such a way that it might be tailored to a particular task. I also had insights about writing--where previously I would write essays by giving my thoughts on a source, this class taught me how to truly come up with wholly original ideas.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to view the world in different ways. I learned how to achieve any attentional goal. I learned how to be a better writer in all aspects.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Attentional literacy itself is one of the most unique things I've ever learned about in an academic environment and learning to think in this way was hugely impactful.
2. Writing in an academic context, with specific predictable "moves" leading to each point, was really helpful to develop my writing style.
3. Collaborating with the other students on such a unique concept was a lot of fun and really helped develop my sense of just how useful peer review is.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me about attention and attention literacy. I learned how to create different attentions for different attentional situations and goals. I also learned how to more effectively write by learning about the writing process and how to incorporate research into my writing. I also think many attentional concepts through the readings that were assigned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: While the writing style used for the essays is pretty niche, the lessons learned apply much more broadly. The course and his feedback emphasize writing with "maximal meaning and minimal words" through poetic expression, which has helped me write more concisely and meaningfully. In previous high school writing classes, I never really had to think critically, as they mostly required easy-to-BS summarization. This class will force you to actually write something substantive, an essential skill for academic writing. This is my first time having to write a long paper and a great introduction; he teaches you how to synthesize a well-written paper from the bottom up and taught me a lot about the iterative writing process, helping me overcome the intimidation of a big blank document.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1.	The importance of intentional attention: I learned how paying attention often aligns with what authority wants us to focus on and how I can take control of my own attention. This method has helped me become more mindful of my biases and more forgiving of myself when I get distracted, fostering a healthier and more intentional way of engaging with the world.
	2.	The practice of serious noticing: This concept has been particularly impactful for my writing. By differentiating between surface-level observations and truly noticing the nuances of scenery, memories, and people, I’ve improved my ability to create vivid and unique prose. It’s helped me analyze what makes great writing stand out compared to clichés.
	3.	A deeper understanding of perception and thoughtfulness: The course has encouraged me to rethink how I perceive the world, helping me be more reflective and thoughtful in my day-to-day life. The course's insights on perception have not only enhanced my understanding of the course material but also continue to influence how I view and interact with the world around me.

how to apply course concepts to daily lives

response_text:
The knowledge I learned in this class included:
• attentional lenses and their usage in situations
• the influence of attention in the masses as early as the 20th century and how we can use our attention positively instead of for the benefit of others, such as big social media companies 
• learning to trust my gut and the work I am doing.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professor of the course was very attentive and lenient towards what we wanted, always asking what order or what things we wanted to do in order to help us in the most efficient way. The methods of writing academically and drafting essays is definitely something I would continue using for the future.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Landes had a structure in which we spent the first portion of the course learning and reading about attention and attention literacy. The second portion of the course focused on our writing and our ability to construct creative new forms of attention. Professor Landes emphasized the importance of having the students select their own paper topics so that they could be more invested in the paper and have more expertise on the topic being discussed. I would recommend keeping this feature in the future.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: There are certain components of the course that facilitated my learning. The most notable of these was probably the APT assignments. These assignments asked on us to reflect on what we learned and accomplished over the week, and through this reflection did I truly learn and grow from the content.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Landes is an extremely empathetic professor, in that he loves to understand where students are coming from, why they do the things they do, and how they can best be asked to approach the class. Overall, Landes fully committed himself to our education and made sure we were all at the places we needed to be.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

He would structure the class around our needs so if we had a question or just needed time to work, he would change class time to accommodate for that. He also provided many resources and readings so that we had the literature to understand attention and attention literacy.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor is very willing to help the students. While it's easy to get frustrated as your first draft might not meet the requirements, the way he talks to his students enforces a growth mindset rather than harsh criticism. I ended up going to a lot of his office hours, which are plentiful (some days they would be 7+ hours long, a huge time commitment for professors), and ended up learning a lot hearing his feedback on mine and other students' writing. He also teaches us to be self-editors, with the philosophy that helping us learn a general intuition of what the problem is before immediately telling us is helpful in the long run.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the predudices that currently exist within writing spaces against people that learned English as a second language, and about how writing studies can be adapted to better support these multilingual speakers. I became more appreciative of code-meshing in rhetoric.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I genuinely feel like I grew a lot taking this class this semester, specifically as a writer, but also as a person. Rhetorics was never something I had studied before, or at least anything being labeled: rhetorics. I wan't familiar with pathos, logos, ethos. At first the course was very confusing but I quickly felt relieved when the teacher made us do a reading on threshold concepts. I think that's what made me realize that I was on the right track and the reason I was so confused was because I was learning threshold concepts. Apart from not only understanding the western definition of rhetoric, I then understood that rhetoric is an expansive concept and it is culturally deeply rooted. Apart from that, at first, writing reading journals was extremely hard for me. I didn't know where to start and so I would do the reading and copy and paste every single quote that resonated with me, unless it was usually one third of the text. I was always so overwhelmed by an information overflow that I did on myself. Reading Journals often took me a lot of hours, however, then, with Professor Li's recommendations I was able to get so much better at the journals in the sense that I was able to write them much quicker without sacrificing the quality of the journals.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
A better understanding of how and why rhetoric is used in writing
Ways of categorizing rhetorical choices (beyond high school ethos pathos logos)
An understanding of writing through the lens of contact between cultures
How to approach my own writing, regardless of topic.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think I was able to develop a very sentimental relationship with writing. I was able to learn from personal perspectives and adjust my writing ways with the help of my professor, guest speakers, and peers. Dr. Li ensured that everyone in the class participated and learned from each other. We were encouraged to think outside the classroom doors and seek the message in art, movies, and, of course, writing. I enjoyed being able to write freely and with a message. I also enjoyed how the first day of class was focused on getting to know each other, which allowed the class to become more open and discussions more involving. I think that near the beginning of the class, I was a little shy, but near the end, I was able to join in on the discussion and was able to speak through my writing.

Structure of research papers and writing with models like CARS

response_text: Professor Li is genuinely amazing. Every class dynamic, reading journal and prompt that goes with it, every workshop, every little thing was well thought by her. The reading journal prompts I find very impressive because she makes sure the students are weaving and merging and recalling past readings. Personally, the reason why this course was so intellectually stimulating is because she made sure that the concepts we learned in all the past readings were being implemented after, instead of forgotten. I would keep the reading journals for future years because I truly think that the reason I learned so much in this course is because the prompts were challenging and obligated me to delve deep in the topics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of ways to improve my analytical skills with research papers and a lot of ways to improve my writing. I learned how to assess the credibility of a research paper based on authors, publishing dates, and journal credibility. Finally, I learned important ways to become a better writer through improving structure, sentence formation, and conciseness.

Some of the W101 aspects are pretty boring, especially if you learned them in high school, but they're pretty much required across the board so they can't be avoided. Other than that, the Disney content and Professor Andres were great and I would definitely recommend.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's a relatively high demanding course but you will walk away with many new and important skills and feel connected to students you might not have met otherwise.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would tell the student to be prepared to work in a group and for the consistency of the coursework. There is homework in every class, but Professor Andres does an amazing job of communicating when the due dates are.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be aware that this course requires a lot of time and effort. There is a lot of work that sometimes seems like busy-work. The actual Disney content is interesting because Professor Andres enjoys talking about Disney and the other students in the class also engage in conversation well. However, this writing course seems more difficult and time-consuming than other courses many of our peers took.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I am earnest,  Dr. Scharnhorst (pardon me if I do not write her name correctly) has inspired me to better understand my own reflection process (despite my experienced/somewhat experienced background regarding writing). Above her curiosity to understand and provide her advice, she emphasized earnest, methodical, and honest writing when approaching any writing project (which I guess are principles I learned throughout the course).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned a lot about the process of revision and how it's much more in-depth than just fixing a few words here and there. 
2. I also learned a super helpful method for taking notes on sources, which made it a lot easier to cite and incorporate those sources later on. 
3. This class was also a nice exposure to the world of humanities research, and I learned several interesting things about the style that humanities papers are typically written in.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I like the emphasis on collaboration that is involved in this course. Our final project was a three-person effort where we wrote around 8000 words of archival research material. This group project promoted my ability to individually contribute while simultaneously incorporating the perspectives of others in my work. I also really liked the annotation assignments with Hypothesis. This is something the instructor should keep using in future years. Ultimately, I think the instructor provided a safe space to learn about writing and appreciate it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have explored the different methods of education, especially the "banking" model and "problem-posing" model. I have also reflected upon my own education journey through reciting my own anecdote. I have also learned how deliver a lesson from a teacher's perspective.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Through different readings and writings, I developed my knowledge of different educational approaches (e.g., Freire's banking method and problem-posing method), my understanding of the negative impacts of some education curricula on marginalized groups of people (e.g., Gloria Anzaldúa's "How to Tame a Wild Tongue"), and my ability to integrate my own personal experiences with concepts that I learned (i.e., the Personal Ways of Knowing essay).

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Hojem gave us weekly free writes with the goal of making us more comfortable with letting our thoughts transfer onto the page in a short amount of time, and I found these assignments to be very helpful and successful. It helped me get started with my ideas and gave me a space to express myself where other courses did not; I would like to keep this component for future years. We also were given plenty of time to complete all of our assignments, which I greatly appreciated. We had plenty of time to revise, go through peer edits, and attend office hours if we so choose.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the useful skill of addressing an audience within my discipline. A lot of times, you hear the word interdisciplinary a lot, but you never get the chance to learn how to effectively communicate within your discipline itself. I also learned the importance of citing my work inside the body of text I'm presenting. Finally, I learned the way of thinking that acknowledges where I am as a scholar and how to best communicate that in my writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to write a literature review. This includes how to find sources using Duke's and other resources, how to catalog them and cite them, and how to structure an annotative review, bringing in information from the texts but also synthesizing them to make an argument about the literature.I also learned about concepts like cutlural rhetoric--how culture isn't just the words people speak, but also their traditions, behaviors, actions, and much more. I learned to consider rhetoric as not just literal words or persuasion, as the Western definition says, but many other things.I also learned to write a research paper, including a survey of existing works, writing interview questions, analyzing them, writing a discussion of results and a conclusion, etc.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared for a harder-than-normal Writing 101. This course was extremely challenging, and the professor will make you work for an A if you don't immediately fall into what she deems good writing. As all English classes go, the professor will have an inherent bias when grading, as each professor has certain qualities they like better in essays. Once you find out what this professor, in particular, likes, you should be good. The readings outside of essays are pretty easy. If you want to think more philosophically and are ready to put in some extra work, then this course is for you.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about working in a team especially during the final project. I had never had to rely on a team in this capacity, so I learned how to manage my team and step up into a leadership role when my team was off task. Another thing I learned was how to critically summarize papers. I am often not confined to a word count, so I struggled to shorten some of my papers to just the most important things.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Three specific things I learned were forming an informative summary of readings, developing a synthesis and argument from research papers, and learning how to access and use literature research to synthesize a paper on epidemiology.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class I learned how to write academic papers from beginning to end including a summary, analysis, and finally a collaborative review and synthesis. In this class, especially when it came to our final paper, collaborative work was a skill that became the expectation. Whether it would be doing various forms of peer-review or being able to expect internal deadlines to be met, collaboration and group work was a part of our every day, in and out of class time. I also learned how to respond to that feedback in the most effective way to perfect the writing as a whole.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Finally, I have learned to analyze, review, and synthesize academic works in order to provide constructive feedback and contribute to a larger body of scientific knowledge.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
One specific thing I learned was how to collaboratively write. This was different than how research projects are usually formatted, and it enabled us to learn a new way to approach writing and collaborate. 
Another thing we learned was how to synthesize sources and allow them to be in conversation with each other. 
Beyond that, another skill we learned was how to quickly read research papers and summarize them, developing our skills in academic literature research along with evaluating the efficacy of sources to evaluate and use for writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained experience with peer review. I feel as though I really improved as a writer through peer review, especially with this genre of writing as opposed to a typical high school English class. I learned how to effectively analyze, summarize, and synthesize scientific pieces of writing. There was a lot of practice throughout the semester, and each assignment built on the last. Lastly, I learned how to collaborate within a group setting on a writing assignment. Prior to this class, I have never written a paper with a team. This was a new and very valuable experience.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The ability of academic writing

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Clearer insight into how to structure clear and effective academic papers — we delved into sections such as introductions, thesis statements, body paragraphs, and so on, which really refreshed and refined my prior understanding of effective essays. I found the information on thesis statements and literature reviews, in particular, most helpful — for example, we learned how to effectively synthesize literature using a synthesis matrix, which is a technique that groups common ideas between sources together — it's definitely a technique that I'll be using for my other research papers going forward.
2. Incredible insight into Disney's evolution in terms of its content (especially in recent years with the Disney-Pixar merge and the introduction of much more mature topics) and the company as a whole! Reflecting on the role of Disney in producing "edutainment" (among other super fun discussion topics), for example, was super eye-opening.
3. Learning to think about the importance of the PROCESS when writing (rather than just the outcome) — while writing, it's important to critically assess each draft and to make improvements, and we can use techniques such as a reverse outline to ensure that we're clear in our writing, etc.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
1. The structure and sequence of our Low-Stakes Assignments really helped us practice specific writing skills and also sequentially fed into our final paper. This was definitely effective at teaching us writing skills.
2. Seminar discussion questions, where we as students got to prepare questions on readings to lead class discussions — it fostered such a fun and open discussion environment, and also allowed me to maintain consistent engagement towards the class
3. Recognition that life can get in the way, and the importance of maintaining good mental health — the course offers one Mental Health Day (one day off class with no class attendance penalty) and one Pixie Pass (a 72-hour extension on an assignment), and Prof. Andres is also super nice!
4. Super clear & organized website, with a super clear syllabus, super clear homework instructions posted at the start of every class, etc. — this really helped me stay on track with class progress
5. Handouts with clear instructions for all our assignments (plus handouts with notes for the different sections of academic writing that we looked at)
6. Our super warm and supportive and friendly class environment — much of that due to Prof. Andres' energy
7. I also really liked our semester overview document (which outlined what content we would cover & the homework due every single lesson), which was posted at the start of the year & helped me plan for deadlines for the semester — for future semesters, it would be even better if updated versions are posted on Sakai/Canvas after changes are made

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
The parts involving discussion with others were most stimulating for me:
1. Public annotations of readings — it really helped me make outside connections (connections with other topics discussed in class, things I learned from other classes, other classmates' comments, etc.)
2. Seminar discussions every lesson (led by a different group of students each time, with questions written by them!) — the questions were super broad in scope & invited a lot of reflection (both about ourselves and society), and our class discussions would also yield new things to consider!Also, I really enjoyed watching (and crying) over our assigned films, and realizing how applicable the messaging of these films was to our lives (and how differently I interpreted them now versus when I'd first watched these movies years ago). The course offered so much food for thought and so many new approaches to thinking about themes and the messaging behind films — we looked at a lot of existing literature about different films (which also served as examples for how we should write our own final papers) in addition to watching the films themselves. (One approach that was particularly new and thought-provoking to me was the idea of parental neglect and resulting trauma in "Frozen".)

response_text: If you're interested in exploring the effects and implications of Disney movies (a huge enforcer of culture), are interested in thoroughly developing your writing skills, and aren't afraid to engage in a little more work compared to other WR101s, definitely choose Decoding Disney — while it was a lot of work, every single lesson was fun (with super eye-opening discussion), and I'm really glad I was able to reflect on the impact of Disney and realize its sheer cultural relevance while honing my writing skills.

response_text: The course allows you to learn a lot about the topic of nature and biophilic cities. I think more people should be encouraged to take such a course. It also taught you lots of different writing methods. However, I definitely think it is one of the harder writing 101s.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Make sure to attend office hours and use the Writing Studio for all essay projects and make sure to use the time between the first draft and final due date to make lots of changes.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say take this course if you are interested in architecture, sustainability, urban planning, or environmental science because the content is what really drove my interest in this course.  Otherwise, I would say don't take this course if you are just looking for a fun writing course as--from what I've gathered from others--this course is much more intensive than other writing courses. I personally did not find this course difficult (although some of my classmates may disagree) but rather just really labor intensive. The time investment for a writing 101 course is what I found hard about this class. Lindsey Smith is a bit particular with formatting and that kind of stuff so just make sure to thoroughly read the assignment prompts. Also, I don't totally understand why this course requires the ethics co-req.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I strengthened my knowledge on how to develop strong analysis and research papers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained insights into how to use library resources for research, how to synthesize articles, and how to work effectively on research teams.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Well, we learned a lot about Ebola, at the beginning of the year which was very interesting and relevant to today. I think the other main thing was different styles of analytical writing which is important going into 7 more semesters of college and beyond regardless of major.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Research Skills - Looking through databases to find sources relevant to my cultural approach and global pandemic. 
Synthesizing Sources - From gathering research articles with multiple tones and arguments to relay the arguments within my thesis 
Constructive Feedback - How to give feedback to other writers and incorporating the feedback we receive

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Writing to be concise, working with a team, revision over a long period of time

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read and understand scientific articles. I learned how to write and convey an analysis of a scientific article (or any piece of writing) with my own voice. I learned how to effectively offer constructive feedback when peer reviewing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned various types of academic writing (summary, analysis, and synthesis) from a variety of disciplines (epidemiologic, ecologic, cultural, and political) and model works, as well as some new methods of peer review and collaboration.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to summarize scientific literature more effectively and concisely. I also learned how to differentiate a summary versus and analysis and practice with a few of my own. I enjoyed exploring topics typically considered within the hard sciences via a humanities approach.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to write a collaborative scientific paper with intro, results, and conclusion. I also learned how to navigate the duke research resources through the library which was very helpful. I also learned how to write a review and synthesis based on various research articles.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I really liked the fact that this course focuses on the "process" of writing. At times, the importance of the "process" of something gets underestimated (especially when there's too much focus only on the final product). However, this course shows how important the process is for an even better final product. I learned that it's important to precisely and accurately summarize an academic paper. I also learned that it's crucial to be able to incorporate my own thoughts and perspectives to analyze the writer's argument.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Exploring academic databases efficiently and identifying sources that aid my research
2. Working collaboratively on a project and ensuring that team dynamics are as welcoming, effective, and well structured as possible
3. Developing methods for summarizing, analyzing, and synthesizing academic sources; exploring problems from an interdisciplinary viewpoint, whether it be in terms of epidemics or beyond

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course really helped me develop my professional writing skills that were definitely a little rough coming into college. I had taken AP English courses in high school, but this kind of writing, which focused a lot more on science and ecology than I had worked with previously, definitely helped me learn how to write through different lenses in efficient and effective ways. Additionally, the peer-review aspect in this class was such a valuable tool that I developed for the sake of others' writing and my own. Finally, the collaboration that occurred in the second half of this course helped me learn to trust my team members and be a valuable team member myself to make sure we always keep up with the work needed.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor had very clear and thought out plans for each class, specifically in terms of peer-review and outlining drafts - I specifically liked the reverse-outline style of revising a paper and found it useful.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor gave great feedback on papers and in class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Prof Welsh was very hands-on. the sequence of assignments was very helpful - learning to summarise was easy which then stepped up to analysis - learning this skill was very useful for the final project. the review and synthesis was very useful too

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Welsh was super nice from day 1, and always made the classroom feel warm. It was a very low stress environment, and there was plenty of time to complete assignments.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Diagraming and discussing example models in order to dissect and use it to apply in our pandemic for our interdisciplinary approach. Especially the student example was an especially helpful assignment that was a proper scheme that we could follow through or look at when I had any remaining questions or didn't know how to approach a section. In effect, it facilitated my learning because it made me understand how a draft should look like and how I should approach it to make sure I was following the guideline.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The step by step nature of the research paper was very nice as we knew what we had to have done the entire time. It was not left to just a final night “quick write the the whole intro.” Also, the “smaller word limits” provided a unique challenge that other classes have not really given. Writing a lot in a little is a skill that is under appreciated since it’s easier to simply “write more” to get to a point.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Welsh made it very clear we can always come to her or the writing studio for help on our essays. She taught material in a very effective, structured manner. She is also super friendly and facilitates a warm, collaborative learning environment.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the mix between talking/lecturing about each area we learned about with discussion and time to work on practicing and improving our writing skills. That balance really helped me feel like I was getting more out of the class, which should probably be kept for future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Welsh is very accessible to students and I always found that meeting with her and or getting feedback during class was helpful. She was also very considerate of everyone's schedules and additional workloads which I greatly appreciated.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Welsh was very helpful throughout this entire course. Whenever I had questions regarding assignments or not being able to find a proper source for something, she was always very welcoming towards those questions and helped me in whatever way she could. I really like how the class was set up with first learning how to write summaries of articles and then an analysis so that we could put what we learn from those together in the review and synthesis.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I'd keep everything and discard nothing from this course. Every class period was extremely productive, and activities were designed so that everyone has a chance to participate and contribute. Three meetings with the course librarian were especially helpful because it served as a stepping stone towards conducting research for my final project.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Welsh facilitated my learning by using an incredible course structure that layered each new topic we learned onto the next topic; I loved how the interdisciplinary study of Ebola virus began with a summary, had us use our skills we learned in the summary module for the new analysis module, and then brought everything we learned together in the final review and synthesis paper. It truly felt like the writing toolset we had been building up throughout the semester all came into play for the final assignment, and seeing everything come together was really incredible. Her detailed working schedule was also very helpful to stay on track with the course and facilitated my time management.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Welsh's provided great examples, guided writing activities, and facile peer-review sessions in a way that was very effective to my learning and made this course a little bit easier. Especially, the summaries and analysis before moving into the group research paper helped ease us into a larger assignment, which could have been overwhelming and stressful, but was made a lot easier with the help of Dr. Welsh's planning and activities.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was interesting to learn something I was familiar with (epidemiology) from a variety of new perspectives that I hadn't considered before. question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

response_text: It can be tempting to speed through all of the edits Dr. Welch suggests or loosely follow many of the tips she gives you, but if you dedicate more time and effort to it, I think your writing will improve more and you'll have a much better foundational understanding of the writing process and academic literature in general.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The workload is not too bad and Dr. Welsh is available to provide feedback on drafts. I would recommend if you have any interest in pandemics but would not expect to come out of this course as a better writer.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Keep up with the readings and assignments. For the first drafts of assignments, it is okay if your writing is not fully developed because that is what the peer reviews help with.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I improved my skills in writing critically and in a scientific manner. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have learned how to write scientific and research based papers which I did not know how to do before coming to Duke. Ive also learned how to analyze epidemics from multiple perspectives which I have found myself doing when talking about other epidemics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned how to analyze and read academic papers across different disciplines in a critical and analytical manner. We first delved into academic course writing in the context of pandemics by writing academic summaries of papers. We then took a more analytical approach to academic writing by critiquing academic works across disciplines and applying critical thinking in writing. Finally, we practice synthesis by writing an academic paper on our own by reviewing and synthesizing other works. We took a collaborative approach to all of our works by having peer evaluation and reviews as a critical aspect of our writing process. Overall, learned a lot.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed ideas on how to construct thoughtful, concise, and clear writing, especially in terms of scientific writing. Specifically, I learned how to read and digest complex scientific papers, how to create flow and meaningfulness with limited words, and how to research the Internet for a specific idea.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to summarize scholarly sources, analyze their merit in a broader context, and link together sources in cohesive arguments.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In my writing, I developed the skills of writing a good quality summary, synthesizing sources and collaborating with peers on an essay.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- reading research papers across disciplines, specifically in terms of epidemics. 
- literature research: learning how to research specific topics and the resources used.
- collaboration in essay writing and research: working together in a group to revise, collaborate, and review papers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to cite my sources in a paper, how to summarize scientific articles(can be a very arduous process reading the information and deriving an analysis from it), and write in a formal way to create a professional writing paper.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was very helpful at improving my writing and revision skills. I learned lots of new techniques to help me with this. For example, I learned about reverse outlining, a process where you work backwards to make an outline of an essay you already have written. This makes it much easier to see if you need to restructure parts of the essay. I also practiced reading dense biological articles, a skill I struggled with as I often got lost in the details like specific words and did not see the big picture of each paragraph. Something else I improved on was my peer review skills. Having a template given by Dr. Welsh made me think more deeply and give better feedback. The questions from the template will be very helpful to me in the future when doing peer reviews in other classes.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed knowledge on how to construct and analyze different types of writing, such as summary, analysis, and synthesis writing. I also developed the skills to pull useful information from scientific papers, as well as the skills to interpret and compare viewpoints from different types of disciplines. Through the synthesis assignment, I learned key methods to collaborate well with my peers, as well as how to combine different styles of writing and different topics into a cohesive introduction and conclusion. Finally, I also improved on providing constructive feedback and going through the processes of peer review.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was really philosophical and got me thinking about topics I don’t usually focus on in my day-to-day life, like death, the grieving process, and how to live well. From books like A Grief Observed and When Breath Becomes Air, I learned that grief isn’t a linear process and that it’s okay to feel happiness while grieving—it doesn’t mean you’re doing it wrong. We also explored how different authors, like Emily Dickinson and Edgar Allan Poe, viewed death and how their beliefs shaped their perspectives on life, which made me realize how much religion and personal experiences can influence the way people see death and what comes after. Toward the end of the course, we focused on what it means to live a good life, what really matters, and the idea of carpe diem. Those conversations made me reflect on my priorities—whether it’s relationships, career goals, or just being content—and how to focus on what’s most important to me. Overall, it was a class that really pushed me to think about life and my values in ways I usually don’t.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course challenged me to confront what it means to live a meaningful and worthwhile life through the analysis of various texts throughout history, songs, works of art, and films as they related to the overarching concept of Death and the Afterlife. In this course I feel more adequately prepared to challenge my own mortality and analyze the values that I want to be remembered for and what mean the most to me.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

-I developed the way of thinking about food and its authenticity. How our origins with food are based on where we come from and what we were first taught about food throughout our lives. 
-I developed the skill of revision through drawing and presenting out your main idea. We used a technique of crearting an artwork with random materials that represented what our project was about. We then got anonymous comments of our peers who got the paper by just looking to the artwork and a short description. This method let me recognize what was being percieved of my paper and analyze whether or not what my intentions of the paper where reflected enough on my paper or not.
-I developed a deeper understanding of the importance and different ways of revising my papers.

She is very clear with keeping us aware of all the work we have to do for the following class. One method of instruction I would keep for future years is the revising your own work. They way it worked was every Tuesday we had about two to three readings that we had to write a 500 response/reflection about. response_text: The biggest thing I've learned from this class is to be vulnerable around others and to respect their vulnerability by participating.
