And the most important part of that was respecting their willingness to do so by participating when they asked for input on their writing. The third thing I learned was to research and dive deeper into my own feelings so that I can learn to become a happier individual (understanding why I feel certain things).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about self-introspection. I made some good friends and feel more mature about entering dialogue about my or other peoples' emotions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the skills of being vulnerable in my life and the skill of listening to other be vulnerable and give feedback to papers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to write professionally in a first person perspective.
I learned how to do qualitative research.
I learned how to write formal and informal peer responses.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learning to analyze my life in the current moment rather than take myself to be an amalgamation of all my past issues. Also, I learned to identify the emotions I feel in any specific instance.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to be a better writer by testing new formats. I also learned how to give and receive feedback in a respectful yet constructive manner. I became more comfortable speaking in front of peers too.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to apply psychological research to unpack my own experiences, write richer memoir stories, and effectively engage with my classmates' writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to meaningfully connect with people, how to analyze a source and use it correctly in an analysis section, and how to find sources that relate well to me.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to be reflective and introspective, as well as write different parts of a case study.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Creating a class dynamic where everyone is vulnerable and shares with each other facilitated my learning by creating a safe space to explore topics relating to my coming of age and happiness. Things like the speed dating helped create one on one bonds in the class, and Sheryl truly caring about everyone makes it so much better. Also Friday snacks are the best.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: First of all, there is no teacher as welcoming as Sheryl (at least in my experience thus far). Her willingness to communicate with us, her insistence of being called her first name, and her enthusiasm for us are unparalleled, and I'm very grateful for it. She also has all of her material prepared for the entire year in Sakai which makes it easy to know what to expect and check ahead of time.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Sheryl is so open and welcoming. I genuinely feel like I could say anything to her and should be ok without. The class is pretty flexible too.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: By focusing on ourselves, the class was always engaging if we were willing to be vulnerable with the class. I see we because this is a group investment. Getting to listen to other's profiles and do their workshop was really great. I just wish we would have engaged 1 on 1 more often or in smaller groups to look over work or just talk about life.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor made me feel very comfortable. She was uplifting and authentic in her relationships with her students. Unlike other professors, I was not intimidated and felt like she had my best interests at heart.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Sheryl was truly the most phenomenal teacher I have ever had. She nourished my passion for creative writing by giving us a foundational structure for a very vulnerable, thought-provoking, and extensive assignment but also allowing us to be innovative. Her unique case study assignment was a fantastic, life-changing experience, and every student at Duke should have the chance to take her class. I liked that we gradually pushed ourselves, starting with more manageable and less intimate assignments and ultimately finishing with our case study. I also adored the emotion check-in at the start of every class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Sheryl did an amazing job being very engaging and helpful during our learning, such as giving us examples, and letting us learn and grow on our own while providing assistance. I would keep everything for future years!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it!! Sheryl is amazing and truly cares about all her students. This class on the other hand is a break from the rest of Duke in the sense that Sheryl just gives you the space to explore topics that are important to you, and focuses more on your vulnerability and response to feedback rather than your writing itself.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class will change your life if you put in the effort. Slot out enough time and work carefully on your case study. When doing the analysis, push yourself at every sentence to ask, "So what?" Use Sheryl as a resource and schedule meetings with her if you have clarifying questions/are experiencing writer's block. Don't be afraid to be authentic and vulnerable with your peers. Somehow, everyone is a million times kinder in the setting of this class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed knowledge of food culture in America and how it has changed over time. I also learned how to read large quantities of text and respond to it with my own thinking and developed opinions. I understood how to write a research paper and synthesize sources.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The primary skill I developed in this class was writing. Dr. S taught me several techniques to employ while writing, especially reverse outlines and just writing a first draft. We also examined the sociology of food and I really learned about nutrition in the final project. Learned a lot in the class overall!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: New skills on revising the structure of work, new way of thinking about writing first drafts, and better understood how much work goes into writing something good.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I developed many ways of thinking. Broadly, we looked at food as a way of informing culture, identity, habits, and much, much more. However, I felt that this course was far deeper than the theme. One key takeaway from the course is the importance of revision. Professor S. did an amazing job of providing opportunities to revise and showing why revision is so imperative to writing. I also think this course helped my writing process a lot as a whole. I was shown that writing is a process and we can't expect it to be perfect. But by appreciating the process and trusting our abilities, the writing we produce can surpass our expectations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how first tackle writing, not to get scared or be confident about my content to write. Second thing that I learned is how to effectively revise my paper by pruning. This helped me construct sentences that are concise and to the point, which helps to my final paper. Last thing that I learned is that how to effectively outline my paper with reverse outline.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Writing analysis was used in every class

Learning about the different ways to conceptualize food was really interesting because I was able to see food from a different, writing-oriented perspective

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I'd recommend it if you have a particular interest in Latin America, or if you want to practice talking to others and talking in front of people. I feel like the workload for this is a bit much considering you'd have to watch films, read texts, prepare for presentations/discussion, and write (a lot). The main projects (research project + annotated bibliography x 10, film review, film analysis) seems like an okay load, but you also need to host a context report and a film discussion, write peer reviews for your classmate's work, and rewrite drafts of your work, in addition to watching films and reading materials. If you're not familiar with writing film review/analysis, it would likely take you a long time to get the first draft out, and you'd need to drastically change or completely rewrite sections in your following drafts. There is a 48 hr soft deadline for most larger projects though, which might be helpful.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Taking Coming of Age and Happiness has been a uniquely transformative experience in my growth as a writer. Although I’ve taken two other college-level writing courses, this class stands out for how it challenges me to write on a deeper emotional level. Most writing courses focus on structure, genre, and analysis; this course, however, has encouraged me to turn inward—to examine my own life experiences, emotions, and internal conflicts as valid material for meaningful writing. I can perfectly encapsulate this into the following: 
- I’ve developed the ability to engage with my writing emotionally.
-I’ve come to see writing as a method of self-discovery.
-This course has helped me think in a more interdisciplinary way, especially through storytelling.

response_text: Sheryl is amazing! She's so sweet and understanding and easy to talk to. The assignments are structured fairly, giving us time to really read through the SPNs, listen to the podcasts and chapter readings, etc. I enjoyed the structure of the first few weeks being in-class discussion. I loved talking about the topics as a class and especially on topics that we could all relate to, like Excellent Sheep.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Sheryl is simultaneously "one of us," in that she doesn't keep the professional distance that most professors do, while also maintaining a fairly rigid regimen for class. These are both ingredients of an effective class, I think. You had to do the work assigned, and she would notice when you didn't. But within the structure of fulfilling your class responsibilities, she is conversational and open and fun.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: As someone who tends to be introverted, I initially found aspects of this course’s structure—especially the emphasis on open discussion and peer feedback—challenging. Dr. Sheryl M.’s approach consistently pushed me outside of my comfort zone, asking me to reflect more openly on my thoughts, emotions, and personal experiences. Whether it was sharing my perspective on a reading or commenting on a peer’s draft, there were moments when I genuinely dreaded having to speak up. Yet, over time, I began to understand the purpose behind this discomfort. By engaging in these moments of vulnerability, I not only became a more confident writer but also a more thoughtful communicator. I believe this process helped me grow both intellectually and socially.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The knowledge, methods, skills and insights I learned were rooting in different ways of analyzing and delving into film regarding Latin culture and sexuality. Three specific things I learned was director cinematographic choices (lighting, camera angles, diegetic and non diegetic sound), issues that are extremely significant in Latin America or Latin diasporas (machismo, maternalism,etc), and how to write analysis pieces such as film reviews and analysis (something I was previously completely unaware of).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Additionally, I learned how to cite sources in MLA and APA format as I had previously never done so.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say that this class is good but it's not a good class if you don't feel comfortable being forcefully vulnerable. I feel like people tend to ask really intrusive questions about others and some people don't mind but some people do. I don't think that anyone should feel forced to share lots about their life if they don't want to and I didn't really like how we had to submit our personal statements at the beginning of the semester. it seemed like a breach of privacy. Overall I enjoyed the course but I think that if you don't feel comfortable sharing about your feelings this isn't the class for you.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to do archival research, what the process was like for writing an academic paper, and the history of Duke as an institution.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about archival research as well as how to approach my writing. This includes ways to go about finding reliable sources and then how to analyze sources, as well as how to get started with my writing and then refine this writing. I think and hope I made noticeable improvements in both of these fields.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to battle some perfectionist habits. I learned how to study archives. I learned how to revise my writing more effectively.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to use the archives at rubenstein and navigate the catalog, and collaborate better with a group to make a cooperative composition

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned techniques to overcome the initial "writer's block" people sometimes feel when starting a project. I learned how to conduct effective and efficient archival research. I also learned some specific techniques for revision.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Most importantly archival research skills. I think it also helps me to learn more about teamwork and absolutely academic writing skills.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I became better at working in collaborative enviornments, how to research effectively and properly, and most importantly how to rethink in comparison to traditional ways I do things life, whether that be writing like the class or anything else.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Although I developed a lot as a writer in this class, I believe the most valuable thing I gained is more confidence as a writer. Improving your skills in writing is extremely important and beneficial, but I learned that no matter where you are in the writing process, it's important to trust yourself and write whatever comes to mind, even if it is not that great. That first draft does not have to be shown to anyone, but it allows you to put words down on a page for you to modify later. Before this class, a blank page was an extremely intimidating thing to see, but now I realize how exciting it is and it no longer intimidates me. My new found confidence has greatly helped me as a writer not only in this class, but also in my life.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned about how to conduct archival research for various topics and projects, both in writing studies and in other subjects. I plan on using these skills in future courses.
2. I learned how to edit my writing effectively, and I learned how to articulate my writing in a clearer and more concise manner.
3. I learned about Duke's history and the people and events that shaped it; I also learned that not all perspectives are easy to find in archival research and the steps to take to ensure that we as writers are representing diverse groups of people.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think I learned a bit about editing, revising, and drafting through this course. But to be honest most of what we did was general/basic knowledge that I felt I didn't need help with. Many lessons felt redundant and like a poor use of my time.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to critically analyze a niche topic and craft thought-provoking, creative pieces of writing. This course made me a better writer overall. I became much more analytical, cautious, and aware of my mistakes.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to conduct archival research (specifically how to use the Rubenstein), how to read, interpret, and incorporate primary sources, how to plan, write, and revise a long-form paper

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: 1. Dr. Scharnhorst structured the course to focus on improvement as a writer instead of just writing to get a good grade. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: From this course, I can proudly say that I have learned how to use scientific writing, specific to the field of neuroscience, to contribute to the academic conversation. Being able to collaborate with others prompted critical discourse that added to the complexity of my argument and strengthened the overall framework of my writing. Additionally, having to read the work of others also often encouraged me to go back and refine my own writing.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really liked that the first essay wasn't introduced until after we had several discussions about various topics in neuroscience and how to write academically. These discussions were engaging and made sure we were all on the same page. Dr. Parks also facilitated learning by introducing us to several super useful resources, such as Zotero. Her feedback and advice was also extremely helpful, but she still made sure we were independent writers and that we thought of our ideas ourselves. Additionally, I felt that both essays were useful and provided unique insight to the writing process.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Parks was very organized in putting all of the materials in a centralized place. I liked having the resources all laid out in a single place.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the structure of this class. At the beginning, we completed specific, targeted assignments that worked on our skills in reading and analyzing papers. As someone with little to no background in this area, I really needed the basic, directed assignments to give me footing for our projects. As the semester progressed, we gradually gained more autonomy over what we wanted to write about. For example, for the first paper, we were given an assigned topic but could craft any argument we liked around it, but by the last assignment, we could do whatever topic or argument that we wanted as long as it fell under the umbrella of neuroscience. Overall, this environment gave me the necessary structure that I needed while also allowing me to explore my interests in the field.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: - I enjoyed the teamwork aspect in different in-class activities. Being able to unpack the articles with others was really helpful and added to my comprehension.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Upon coming into class, Dr. Parks would either hold eye-opening discussion regarding neuroscientific case studies and questions or would ask us to complete activities that improved our writing strategies. I would say that each and every class was incredibly value — teaching me more about the overall field of neuroscience and how I can translate this understanding into communicative writing.For future years, I plan to continue engaging in peer feedback. Whether that be going to Duke's Writing Studio or asking a trusted friend/professor to read over my paper. Additionally, Dr. Parks introduced us to Zotero — a software that has made citing and annotating [difficult to understand] scientific papers incredibly easy. She also taught us strategies meant to enhance the ways in which we go about our research process (e.g. sifting through databases, narrowing our searches). I have already applied these skills when writing for other classes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Parks was incredibly helpful because she was there for us every step of the way, always accommodating our requests for meeting with her and encouraging us to do better. She made 8:30 am classes so much fun because of her enthusiasm and her compassion for us as students. She ensured that we had the support we needed to complete assignments and laid out the course expectations ahead in time so that we would be aware of them and could prepare in advance in case we had a busy week ahead, which I found very helpful.

Being able to discuss these real-world questions, and critically think about both sides of the debate has encouraged me to think about this issue in a complex manner. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The essays in this class take a lot of time to write and revise, but the end result is definitely worth it. My writing is a lot stronger because of this class and Dr. Parks' teaching. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Finish your drafts and everything early. Pick topics that really interest you. Make a chain of the signals sent out from your arms.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: While it is definitely work-heavy, if you have interest in neuroscience or academic writing in general, it is very effective in giving you the skills and confidence that you need for the rest of writing 101. I think I have pride in knowing I took a "real" writing class, as opposed to one of the "easier" writing 101s that may graded based on completion or not really graded at all, especially because this rigor pushed me beyond my boundaries and made me a better writer.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is good, but you do need to know a lot about of neuroscience when starting out, so expect a learning curve. Dr. Parks is very enthusiastic but her course is challenging and lacks some clarity at times on assignment specifics, what she is grading you on, etc.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: TAKE THIS CLASS!!! Having taken many writing classes, I can confidently say that this is a course I have learned the most from. Being able to successfully contribute to the "academic conversation" is essential as college students and as future employers. Dr. Parks has taught me writing strategies that have made the process much easier and that I am sure to continue using. In addition to the benefits of taking this course, this was also my favorite class of the semester! The discussions we had in class, and their associated homework assignments, were always so engaging.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

I loved the class overall and would recommend it to anyone and everyone!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to become a better writer, understanding my skills as a writer, and how to engage with peer review.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned a lot about the writing process: getting peer reviewed, working as a team to write a paper, and how to engage with scholarly articles.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was an amazing introduction to navigating through the writing process, since it taught me the value of carefully analyzing various different sources in the context of a particular topic, effectively providing peer review to other individuals, and revising rough drafts. I believe that the instructor did an amazing job of teaching these things to the highest standard.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to apply neuroscience to other fields, like the law. We also extensively discussed the writing process through a literature review on a neuro topic of our choice and an argumentative paper. There was also an emphasis on collaboration and I regularly engaged in discussions with my peers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the revision process, how to write collaborative papers, how to critically read scientific papers, and how to better structure my ideas for a first draft (through strategies like storyboarding).  I learned about the process of reverse outlining which helped me to reevaluate my writing and argument.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the writing process and how to draft, revise and organize information in community. We learned how to put text in conversation with each other and build an essay that is organized conceptually instead of categorically. I've been given many tools that I can implement in another setting and become very familiar with course topics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learn to read the paper in terms of the issue it solves and suggestions it gives for future study. This allow me to better reframe its voice in terms of my main argument and inspired how I structured my paper as well. The MEAL Plan also helped us a lot when we try to reduce the “abstract stacking” issue in our group paper later.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a new way of thinking in terms of revisions in the writing process. Learning how to better accept peer feedback and apply it to my piece of writing. Another skill I developed was the ability to better plan out my piece of writing and revise my writing style. In the past I have written scientifically, but without such an emphasis on analysis and developing a cohesive flow of ideas. I would often write in a timed setting and focused on getting as much information on the paper. After this class I have learned how to properly plan before I begin writing and organize my ideas to build my argument and assist the reader. I also gained a new interest in the field of neuroscience and mental challenges such as depression and dementia. This class influenced me to take a class in psychology next semester and continue exploring this field.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to write a scientific literature review. I gained the skill of adding my voice better and integrating analysis with evidence more cohesively. I also learned how to better give and respond to feedback and I became more willing to rip my draft apart and reconstruct it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to contextualize scientific data in society, how to write a coherent paper, and how to write with a group.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to write an effective literature review. Skills on writing structures translate to all kinds of writings.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

response_text: The instructor was always super engaged with the course material that they taught, and I believe that one of the best things that they did included being flexible with office hours to help us revise papers. I also think that they did an amazing job with how they structured the writing process, which included gathering/analyzing sources, writing the first rough draft, receiving peer review, and then revising.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
I really enjoyed the learning environment. We did a variety of activities, sometimes getting outside or working in teams within the classroom. That kept me engaged, especially in a class that is at 8:30AM. In terms of components of the course, I appreciated that we had two big projects throughout the semester, which allowed us to thoroughly work on each stage of the writing process and create great final products.
Dr. Parks was always enthusiastic, available for support outside of class hours, and pushed us to reflect on ourselves as writers, which I appreciated.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is not a joke. You will be pushed to write and think analytically about complicated topics. However, you are supported the whole way. If you want to improve as a writer, this class will be a great opportunity to do that. Additionally, if you expect to do scientific writing in the future, this class is a great resource for practicing those skills.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor had us try different methods and walked us through many different techniques to change the way we write and think about writing. In the future, I think I will continue to try and change my perspective on writing from a chore to more of a fun activity.  I found meditated writing was really helpful for describing all the problems in my life.  I feel as a writer overall I did not change, but my perspective on the subject did.  We practiced looking for differences in conclusions and introductions, so I changed my outlook on how the two were different and figured out theyre very similar.  I have certain skills which I can use, but it was very different from learning new methods such as a scientific paper or other research paper.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to critically analyze topics from a rhetorical perspective. I learned to write research papers using various sources for information. I also learned how to make my writing have better transitions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about research and writing research essays. I also learned how to cite and analyze primary sources. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Over this course, I developed further knowledge in different areas of reproductive justice. We covered a large variety of different topics, including period poverty, abortion rights, and the rhetoric and language surrounding motherhood and femininity. I also developed more advanced writing skills and learned to break away from the traditional 5-paragraph structure that was taught to us in high school to develop more complex writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned new facts about different reproductive justice topics, like menstruation/period poverty. Also learned more about policy/law revolving reproductive justice. 
2. The feedback on my assignments helped me recognize common patterns in my writing that take away from clarity. I now can see these issues and address them before submitting a paper. 
3. I am now able to have a more open mind when it comes to thinking about reproductive justice and the different opinions and perspectives.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned rhetorical discussion and writing methods. I learned research skills such as accessing, analyzing and interacting with archival material. This was something I had never done before. I also applied and practiced writing as a process.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- ability to comprehend lengthy and complex written materials
- I can confidently say that my knowledge about reproductive justice has expanded drastically
- Ability to look at the issue from different lenses: race, gender, socioeconomic status

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have become a significantly better writer over the course of the semester. I have learned how to better assess my sources for credibility, how to write about statistical analysis, and how to structure a paper around an argument.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze original scientific research for biases and potential contextual flaws, learned to see different sentences as consensus, claim etc., and learned to use topic sentences and paragraph conclusions to edit and analyze my own writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have learnt how to evaluate, and I have also learnt how to analyse different studies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to make my writing more dynamic in many ways, including how to effectively put sources in conversation with each other. Also, I was taught helpful tricks to make my writing more compelling and easy to follow, such as understanding the importance of topic and conclusion sentences. Finally, I learned the importance of catering my writing towards my audience, ensuring my sources are credible, and not just writing the easiest argument, but the one supported-- or not supported-- by the research to create a complex analysis.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to write more deeply and extensively than in high school. We also learned how to organize and structure our papers effectively. We also learned how to cite sources in new ways, introduce counterarguments and concessions, and put studies in conversation with each other.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I learned how to analyze research papers and academic journals. I learned how to properly look for sources, cite sources in-text, and use AMA format.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Although I have not taken any of the other writing classes, I would recommend future students choose this writing course. It has been the most helpful writing class I have ever taken. I learned things that are actually useful in academic and professional writing, not just vague grammatical "rules" which don't always apply to every discipline. The topic of physical fitness is interesting, so the writing assignments and class practice exercises are engaging. I feel I learned tools which gave me a new perspective on writing, and I believe my approach to crafting big papers is much better. I enjoyed this class a lot. Dr. Moskovitz is so kind and very understanding, and obviously wants the best for his students.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's a great course! It has greatly improved my writing skills, and I loved the flexibility in choosing topics that interested me and writing papers on those. For group projects, be deliberate and mindful of who is in your group if you want to get a good grade.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed better reading, writing, and analysis skills from this course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much about the writing process. I learned new strategies like the concept map, reverse outlines, the key to a central claim, how to peer review and so much more. This will be so helpful to my writing in the future.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I grew a lot in this class as a writer. It greatly expanded me as a writer, because I stopped thinking about the 5 paragraph structure and started to think about what truly makes an effective essay. It made me think more about evidence and analysis, and transition sentences.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to develop an effective argument with a strong central claim. Also, I learned how tedious the writing process is and that a final draft should be very different from a first draft.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I reframed the way I think of writing as a more dynamic process than before – really more like rewriting. I learned how to draft more complex central claims, write engaging introductions that avoid falling into common mistakes or cliches, and analyze complex research papers to respond to what other writers have written before while still contributing my own ideas.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to write critically, work in a team, write concisely and think critically.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much in this course. The biggest takeaway was the massive emphasis on the writing process. I learned how to work with people, and I genuinely felt like a scientific writer. I also was able to see the effects of neurosceince on the world. I learned that revision can mean massive overhauling and its ok to have a bad first draft.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I specifically learned how to be successful in academic writing by developing three key skills. First is the ability to be critical of my own work. A key to successful writing is revision, and this class taught me that I need to be comfortable continuously revising my work. Second, I learned to critically analyze the work of others. In this class, we were required to synthesize articles in order to create our own argument, which I gained valuable experience doing in this class. Finally, I learned that I enjoy writing. This class allowed me to combine my passion for neuroscience with writing, and find that I really enjoy writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned many valuable tools for academic writing and the writing process overall. I learned how to deliver constructive and meaningful peer feedback as well as receive feedback and implement it into my work. I learned how to collaborate on an academic paper and work closely with my peers to create a product that seemed to be written by one person. I developed skills to effectively analyze academic papers about complex topics like neuroscience and the legal system, as well as effectively synthesize these sources into my own academic argument.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to read, write, and think critically. I became a more confident writer and learned strategies to make my writing more effective through structural and stylistic components. I also learned about and participated in the collaborative and conversational aspects of academic writing, and that helped me grow as a writer and scholar. Working with a group and giving regular peer feedback was very helpful.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to do a reverse outline. I have always been an "edit as you go" type of person, but learning how to do a reverse outline helped me to think about the overall structure of my papers in new ways. I learned how to write without a specific prompt. In this class, we often needed to respond to readings without a general prompt, so we had to come up with a direction for our writing on our own which was very different than anything I had done in the past. I learned how to write in MLA format according to the actual guidelines as well.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to alter my perception of every day activities, how to turn to peers for feedback, and how to ask for help from my professor. I had a wonderful time in this class and felt fully supported in all of my endeavors. I found the concept of attention literacy fascinating.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: My favorite lesson that comes from this course is the concept of imperfect first drafts. Before this course, I was so focused on making my first draft perfect – there was no way that after writing the draft that anything in my paper would change. I locked in my thesis, arguments, and evidence right away and gave myself no flexibility. This process often resulted in my paper not being the best it could possibly be, despite what I thought. Learning about imperfect first drafts in this course has completely changed my thoughts towards drafting, and has led to me producing much better papers than in the past. I will carry this lesson with me in future courses.Another lesson I learned in this course is to be open to abstract ideas. I feel like my past courses have always been focused on very concrete, foundational topics. I was not used to having to attempt to grasp an abstract concept such as the one we discussed in this course. I think I was pretty not open to the concept of the course at first, but as time has gone on, I really have bought into it and have enjoyed learning about such a unique topic. This process has taught me a lot about my personal learning and has opened me up to try to find new, other unique courses to take in the future.The last big lesson I have learned from this course is that writing can be creative and quirky. All my writing in the past has been super scientific, formal, and sophisticated. I really enjoyed combining typical academic conventions with creative, fun writing. This course taught me how to express myself more through my writing and use my own personal style, rather than a robotic scientific tone. I will definitely try to write more creative pieces for fun in the future.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be patient --  It seems really weird and abstract at first, and as if there is no point in trying to understand it. The course is so much better though when you really engage with the material. At the start of the semester, I was not really willing to try to understand the material, and I learned very fast that that was not going to be what would set me up for success in the course. Now, I really do use attention literacy in my everyday life and am excited to continue learning how to adopt new interpretive frameworks in my day-to-day interactions. Make use of all class discussions and workshop periods. Discussions are really what get you far in understanding the course concepts and setting yourself up for success in your essays. Professor Landes is very willing to help you out, but you need to also put in your end of the work and work to develop ideas outside of class. The class does not demand much work out of you, except for really working to understand the concept. Once you do, it is super interesting and I really am happy I took the course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! This class is extremely underrated and will change the way you approach writing and the world in general. It does involve a little more reading, writing, and purposeful thought than other writing classes, as far as I have heard, but it is very focused on ensuring you succeed and grow as a human being. Be prepared to be wrong or rework your entire paper, but it will be all worth it in the end, especially if you choose topics you are passionate about.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me many skills that I can use both in and out of the classroom. I learned how to think critically and analyze text. This allows me to provide my own twist or opinion to support the claim of my essay. I also learned the skills of writers in my team, which allowed me to incorporate these strengths into my own writing. I also learned a ton about the brain which was very interesting.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me how to write, analytically. It was my first time taking a science based writing course instead of creative writing and I loved it! The proposal, mind map, and team based literature were all new to me and I thoroughly enjoyed each and every one of those things. This class emphasized the writing process - writing and rewriting as much as possible - which I think I really benefited from.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The first thing that I learned in this class is the reader's experience, learning that the reader of a paper has a different experience with the writing than the writer was an important piece of knowledge. Second, I learned how to collaborate on a paper to make a better output than I could have made myself. Lastly, I learned how to digest large research papers and take evidence from them to make my own paper coherent.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the benefits of peer review through having other classmates read through my papers and giving me affective criticism. I learned how to roadmap a a literature review to keep the reader engaged with the paper. Lastly, I learned how to better analyze evidence.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
