It is an amazing course if you aren't as confident in your writing abilities or if you're remotely interested in neuroscience. The balance between science and writing skills was perfect and I really do think every student should enroll in this course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: To a student that is taking this course in the future, I would say that they should feel free to engage with all the content and participate in discussions. Adding a point or counterpoint to a discussion in Dr. Parks' class is the way that students truly understand the content.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is a great environment to learn about how to write about neuroscience and the society around us. Dr. Parks does an excellent job of teaching her students about different writing techniques to become a scholar.  The class has a very uplifting and positive atmosphere led by Dr. Parks. Being able to work as a team for the final paper is a very eye-opening experience and one of the most beneficial ways of learning how to become a better writer.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I specifically learned: a much more flexible perspective on what defines good writing, some linguistic concepts such as prescriptivism vs. descriptivism, and how to approach writing a research paper (e.g. collecting and referencing sources). A lot about what defines good writing in general.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Within this course, I learned about reader/writer responsibility in American writing culture, language ideology, and gained a broader sense of what's considered "good" writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: My knowledge of citations improved, analysis and ability to connect different pieces of work to curate one general idea.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I started to think of writing in a more formulaic manner, thinking more about techniques that are used in writing and their impact on readers and writers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class helped me approach writing from a different perspective. I've always been taught that good writing heavily emphasizes grammar, sentence structure, etc. However, this writing course introduced new ideas about writing in a new manner. Moreover, learning how to write different pieces of writing, including a research project, will help me in the future as I hope to explore publication in scientific fields. Overall, this course allowed me to develop new ideas about writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned note-taking strategies and annotation strategies that helped me read long texts quicker and with more depth. I also learned a lot about linguistic differences and how students are taught to write.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, the most significant thing I learned was how to think about different English speakers. I learned about how different regional dialects are not equally respected in writing, and that our system of writing should be changed. I know we learned a lot, but this is what stuck out most to me and the main takeaway I will walk away with. We also learned about tips for English writing and notetaking.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
How to cite sources
What a research paper looks like
How to find sources

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: During this course, I improved my citation skills. I also began to view writing from a more open-minded perspective.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: First, I learned how to comb through rubrics in order to not get points taken off. Second, I learned that I had to raise my hand three times in class even if it is to say nothing meaningful in order to get participation points because even if you participate once with meaningful contributions, this is not enough. Third, I learned the value of community as our Writing 101 class has to help each other get through this semester.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned how to use writing skills in different genres of writing from what I was used to. In particular, I learned how to write an academic response paper and a research study.
2) This class gave me greater insight into issues of language diversity and variation. I was already aware of many of these issues and concepts from a previous linguistics class, so many of these ideas were already familiar to me.
3) I learned a variety of writing techniques to use in my own writing. These techniques were unique in that they encouraged understandability and effective communication instead of following strict writing rules.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class taught me how to properly use APA citation format and provide constructive feedback to other students. In addition, it provided me with a new exposure to academic readings in language outside of what is considered to be "formal" and "correct" English.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- I learned a variety of writing techniques to improve my writing (when to use integral/non-integral quotations, how to signpost, how to implement secondary sources in my writing, etc.).
- I became a more active reader by learning specific reading strategies to break down large texts from a variety of media.
- I learned how to more effectively evaluate my own work as well as the work of my peers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think I developed how I take notes on readings and discovered some great strategies for deciding whether sources are useful or not. I also now have a way understanding of how to access the library's vast resources for research purposes. I also think I improved my writing but also how I feel about it and view other's writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critically analyzing other's writing and understanding the effect language use and choices have on the reader/audience.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the checkpoints for the projects really helped facilitate learning and keep me on track, and I also like the ordering of the course (i.e. starting the semester off with readings, and then moving forward into writing projects). I think that's a pretty smart approach to teaching and describing writing.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course was very much based in discussion and outside reading assignments. For me, the greatest tool in learning came from in-class discussion. I'd continue to implement a strong discussion culture within class-time.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. A did a good job at facilitating conversations and giving a good amount of time to complete assignments. I did appreciate the times when we broke off into small groups because it changed the pace of the class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the tasks in this course are very clearly defined. The assignments are all easy to understand.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I felt like Dr. Asmuth was a very fair grader. As long as you read the instructions and follow everything, you should be fine. However, I do think that the amount of work each week is a little excessive compared to other Writing 101 courses. One thing I do appreciate is how especially in the later half of the semester, the assignments became checkpoints for the big papers, so this helped keep me on track. One thing I would change is decreasing the amount of readings in the first half as some of it did feel repetitive.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked learning how to read texts effectively in the beginning of the course. I also liked that each course was structured as a discussion that was set up first by understanding what made discussions good for students in the past.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor facilitated my learning by making instructions completely clear. There was never room for confusion about assignments because the Canvas page and all assignments were logical, which I liked. Feedback on assignments was also very clear.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: As a non native-english speaker the professor was super helpful at trying to include me in class. They would talk slower in class to make me understand more of what was being said. They would repeat what my other classmates said. They would set up office hours that fitted my schedule to make sure I was able to go see they and get help with my work.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The overall environment of the class was not very conducive to learning. Dr. Asmuth often encouraged questions yet would respond to those questions in a condescending way that disuaded me from asking further questions. Additionally, I often felt that the discussion questions were very surface-level and didn't leave room for students to dive deeper into the topics.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor was very unhelpful in office hours and I noticed very minimal changes or edits in my work in order to get a full score.  If I did not meet for office hours, I noticed that responses similar to what I had submitted when going to office hours was being marked down significantly.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I found that one of the most helpful parts of this class was the small group discussions. It's much easier to discuss ideas and gain feedback from peers in small groups of 3 or 4 than in the entire 15-person class, so I would encourage more of these discussions in future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The recurring peer revision processes were very helpful in receiving feedback on my work outside of professorial insight. However, because feedback was provided on every assignment by Professor Asmuth, I also was in constant communication with them about my progress as a writer.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Asmuth consistently provided valuable feedback for our submitted work. They also broke up the work into more digestible pieces (especially for larger assignments) and allowed us to focus more on each part of the writing process. This pace was helpful in drafting research essays where I otherwise wouldn't know how to approach.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Asmuth often allowed for small group discussions which were generally good and helpful. I also think having to do a lot of peer reviewing in the class was really good and a great skill to learn.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Providing office hours, maybe have more required office hours to review writing and help students improve their writing before turning it in.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think all the discussion surrounding all the different forms of writing, particularly Young and Fish's pieces, really made it stimulating. Also, the nature of choosing your topics made it a lot easier to engage with intellectually stimulating material.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was stimulating through its exploration of language and writing culture within the United States and compared to other countries such as Japan. The discussions were the most stimulating part of the course as it allowed conversational exploration of ideas.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Changing the pace of class and adding different types of assignments like projects, presentations, etc.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class was intellectually stimulating when I was writing my own papers, but the actual discussions could be more complex and engaging.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I just haven't really taken any courses like this, so most of the content was new to me. Nevertheless, some of the content was a hit or miss for me, but it was mainly because of what I was interested in. The topic is just pretty niche in and of itself.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I believe the questions posed during discussions don't leave much room for freedom of thought. And although diverging off topic isn't great, when students feel able to participate in any manner in an open discussion, this could lead to great ideas.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was stimulating, but I felt that it got repetitive towards the end. I think there might not be enough to talk about for an entire semester. I did like the activities we did in class and the group work, though. They found ways to fill a class period that kept it interesting.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think knowing that the professor tried their best to be supportive was what made this class stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The course could be more intellectually stimulating if the course centered the discussions around students and gave them more room to voice their opinions. question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was intellectually stimulating purely based on the class texts alone. I enjoyed being able to research a topic of my interest for the research project, but the first 3/4th of the semester were extremely un-engaging. We discussed how to read and write which often got repetitive and was un-engaging because we all already have our own methods of reading and writing. This section of the course should be limited to the first half or quarter.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I found the readings on issues of language variation to be the most stimulating content in this course. I feel that this course would benefit from leaning into the linguistics aspect of the course description, as that was consistently the most interesting and engaging part of the course.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Many of the observations felt fairly surface-level. I found the Fish vs. Young debate to be the most stimulating part of the class because students began to delve into theories of cultural erasure and the challenges presented by real-world solutions. Other times, discussion was excessively drawn out and thus made the class difficult to enjoyably participate in.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class made me consider many topics about language, writing, and prejudice that I hadn't considered/was aware of. The subject matter was interesting, and my class had many good discussions and conversations. However, the particular readings could be dry, though they were crucial in providing background for following classes.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think doing our own research for the final project was cool and stimulating. I think discussing peers' anonymous writing was also interesting and picking out writing techniques.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: yes it was engaging and the readings were insightful

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: They really want to see you succeed; I would just emphasize timeliness and effort. If you can achieve those two things, you should gain a lot from the course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is great for those pursuing a career that requires strong, argumentative writing. However, it is much more work than many of the other Writing 101 courses. I would not recommend this course for any students within STEM-heavy majors or those with heavy course loads.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The topic isn't hard to understand but its a lot of work for a sort of redundant topic for a class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The course is highly focused on the structure of writing and approaches it like a formula that you plug words into. The class environment is comparable to a small lecture rather than a seminar or discussion. If you learn best through being provided information, this is the class for you. If you learn best through discussing information, this class may not be the best option.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared for a good amount of work every week, and some that feels repetitive in the earlier half of the semester. However, Dr. Asmuth is a fair grader, and as long as you follow the instructions, you will be fine. The topics covered are pretty niche so some you might not find extremely interesting. Nevertheless, for the final paper, you have a little more leeway to do something related to the class but still interesting to you. The most important takeaway from this class is to stay on top of the assignments and ensure you follow instructions.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The content is intriguing, but you must be willing to put in the time and effort to feel fulfilled and become intellectually stimulated. Participation goes a long way.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: A student should be prepared for in-depth thinking about a subject that truly is interesting. These concepts of language ideology are not often thought about, and I enjoyed learning about a topic entirely unique and new. I think first-years should take this course, but I hope the classroom environment could be bettered by more enthusiasm among students, less calling out from Dr. Asmuth, and more complex discussion.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's a class that requires work, with assignments every week. The professor knows they stuff, and it is a potential to learn a lot about writing.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course has a very heavy workload, and class discussions can often feel stifled and dominated by the professor.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would not recommend this course if you are a student who loves to write or interested in developing writing skills. Professor Asmuth creates a toxic environment within their class in which students, like me, who were excited about English and continuing to develop writing skills, are now turned off by writing and do not want to take another writing class again. This professor does not have a rate my professor at Duke yet, but I would recommend checking that website from their previous schools, as former students have also had bad experiences with passive aggressive behavior coming from the professor. I truly love writing, and it saddens me to have had such a bad experience in this class, I would recommend any other Writing 101 if you want to continue to develop your writing skills.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you have an interest in sociolinguistics and issues of language diversity, you may enjoy the general topic of the course. Otherwise, this class has time-consuming weekly writing assignments that tend to eat into your time for other classwork. The coursework is also back-loaded (the two major projects take place towards the end of the course), so keep that in mind.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Because this course is significantly writing-heavier than other WRITING 101s, you may feel discouraged by the tasks presented to you. However, you should try to make the most of each assignment because of the opportunity for individualized feedback. Sooner or later, you will feel that the assignments become more manageable as writing becomes a more manageable task.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The first half of the course is very reading-heavy, but the readings each have a purpose in cementing understanding that you will build off of during the rest of the semester. It also pays to be attentive during class discussions, as you'll be able (and are encouraged) to use quotes from your peers in your assignments and papers.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is difficult and you should be prepared for a lot of work. If you keep up with the readings and weekly assignments everything else will sort itself out, but if you fall behind a little bit, it can be very difficult to catch up again. Also go to office hours and communicate with Professor Asmuth, they're very understanding and want to help you out, so it's good to be in communication with them. The course's content is interesting and you also have a lot of freedom to write about and research what you're interested in for the major projects.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed my writing skills by learning to write more concisely for an academic audience in this course. My writing became more clear and less wordy, and I learned how to communicate my ideas in the most concise way possible.I also learned a new way of thinking regarding attention. I now think about applying my attention as a much more fluid and dynamic thing, rather than strictly "paying attention" or not. I have learned how to describe the different ways I pay attention (attentional lenses). Overall, I have new language to articulate attentions.Learning new language to describe attentions also developed my writing as I was able to practice my application skills by applying the new concepts I learned in this course while writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about attention literacy, improved my writing skills and how I view the writing process as a whole, and developed new approaches to thinking.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned that creating new knowledge through writing is far more challenging than synthesizing and commenting on existing information. I also found that an extended writing process with several phases helps immensely with developing your ideas and arguments, especially because it allows for more opportunities for feedback. Lastly, I developed the understanding that my ideas may evolve significantly over the writing process and may be nearly unrecognizable or outright replaced from the first draft to the final draft, which is a good thing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Dr. Smith is a fantastic instructor who is enthusiastic and understanding of the various problems students face. I would recommend taking it, but proceed with caution so you don't fall behind.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Admittedly this class can be very challenging at times; however, I do not in any way regret taking this class with Professor Smith. Even as a strong writer coming into the class, I still grew substantially as a student and writer through this course. Professor Smith is extremely supportive of her students and it is clear from the beginning of the semester that she deeply cares about helping her students to grow and be successful. As long as students enter the class with the expectation that they will be challenged at times, accept this reality, and embrace the opportunity to grow, made possible by a wonderful professor, they will be successful.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say that they should 100% take this class. You learn a lot and you get a lot better at writing in this class!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 3 specific things that I've learned include the ability to revise my essays and any other piece of analytical work better on my own and with my peers' feedback. I've learned to be more accepting of constructive criticism in my writing, and I'll try to take this mindset into other aspects of my life as well. I also can work better with teammates in team-based settings now through this course's implementation of a major project revolving around 3 people that collaboratively work together throughout the second half of the semester.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How to critically read other scholars' paper - for this writing 101 specifically, our reading materials are mainly scientific paper which are relatively long and difficult to pick up key messages in the beginning. I think throughout the semester, I started to pick up some strategies to find essential information during skim reading
2. The importance of adding our voice to a research question
3. Organize structure and thought processes

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Parks was very clear about her expectations, and her grading rubric is very fair. She genuinely cares about her students and creates a welcoming learning environment. Additionally, there is a lot of teamwork in this class, and I feel that interacting with my peers and working on writing with them was an important point of learning this semester.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really liked the Engages we had at the beginning of the semester as I feel like they helped me gain a window into the course, and were very interesting. I appreciated the small class and the comfortableness I felt around my peers from the start. I think the feedback sessions were helpful with peers, but only when they took the time to really understand your paper and give constructive feedback.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that the open-ended environment of the course facilitated much flexibility with when to start and finish our projects. I like how our teacher guided us through every step of writing -- from making storyboards to our final draft -- with dedicated amounts of time.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I believe the structure of the course facilitate my learning a lot. Dr. Parks break the two major writing projects into smaller, stage-by-stage tasks which are easier to achieve. Personally, peer review feedback is crucial to understand readers' perspectives given the fact that they often don't have any prior knowledge to topics I'm writing about, so they can evaluate whether my paper is clear and cohesive.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Parks is really enthusiastic and accomodating, and clearly cares a lot about the success and well-being of her students. I appreciated the writing toolkits and frequent opportunities for feedback that improved my argument and strengthened my abilities as a writer.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: There was a lot of help from the professor in terms of what was asked of us and if we were on the right track for our projects. The professor was very kind and answered all the questions that I had. I really appreciated how larger assignments or projects were broken up into smaller and more manageable chunks.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated the working schedule Dr. Parks utilized to share what we did in class, deadlines, and submission links. Having all of this content in one place on Google Docs was highly convenient for me, as I often have Google Docs open for my other classes and therefore can check in on the schedule whenever I pleased or needed to. Additionally, Dr. Parks put together many fun activities to demonstrate the neuroscience concepts we would read and write about!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

response_text: The mixture of activities, readings, and topics we could relate to in some ways made this class more stimulating for me! We spent a bit of time talking about how the brain changes during adolescence, directly reflecting what stage of life we are in.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I recommend this course to anyone, although I do think that you should have an interest in neuroscience. There isn't a crazy amount of work, and all of it is used for larger projects so it is not just busy work.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Make sure you really put time into your final product! And make sure to continuously be willing to adapt to new circumstances, both seen and unforeseen, in the writing process.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this course! Very interesting and applicable to students interested in neuroscience and policy making

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: For a student in the future, make sure that you start on the final paper early. Your first draft will NEVER be good. You need to keep working at it for the full 2 months in order to have a proper final draft by the deadline.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Highly recommend to develop your writing skills and interest into neuroscience.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Put in effort into ensuring the communication among peers because this class is very teamwork based

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take student feedback with a grain of salt and always have Dr. Parks check over your work (as much as she is willing to) because student feedback can miss some pretty major stuff

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is definitely one of the best Writing 101s! It is not too much work, besides doing a few readings and some writing (which should be expected in Writing 101). Dr. Parks is a very fair grader, and she genuinely cares about you as a student, being a generally nice and understanding person overall. If you are interested in neuroscience, psychology, STEM, or law, you will enjoy being in this class. There is a lot of teamwork, with the final project being a group essay, but I felt that this aspect was not intimidating.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is fascinating. You will learn so much about not only who you are as a writer but neuroscience in general--in places where you may not even have thought it was applicable.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I think that the best thing for you is to just trust the process.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say definitely be prepared to read and write a lot. Reading is especially important and is foundational to all the writing in the future.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a tough Writing 101 section, but Dr. Parks brings a lot of passion to the course. You can only take this if you are really passionate about neuroscience, given the course's rigor. The course also has a much stronger focus on analytical, scientific writing than most other Writing courses.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a very fun and highly beneficial class. It builds a strong base of neuroscience knowledge and will improve your writing skills.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is one of the Writing 101 classes with a bit more work attached to it, but it is so worth it especially if you are a psych or neuroscience major. Not only does this course teach about interesting topics regardless of your major, I've been able to apply some of the knowledge I've learned in this class to my Psych 101 class and I'm sure I'll find more overlap in my future psych classes!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Attention literacy is like nothing else, so that was a bulk of the new knowledge from this course. I learned about attention literacy, and therefore how there are multiple types of attentions (not just one), and I also learned how to find language to describe unique ways of seeing. I also learned how to be more specific and precise in my writing, describing what something is rather than dictating what it's not.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Landes was very thoughtful with the way he presented class content, ensuring that we understood the key takeaways of each reading and ensured that we reflected thoughtfully on it through his Academic Reading Journaling strategy. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course teaches you to write like a scientist. You will also learn to read a lot of research papers and construct a literature review; you won't be intimidated by research papers anymore. The class also does a good job of giving you practical skills like using the Duke library website, writing studio, and browser extensions for writing & research.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed skills in collaborative writing and working with teammates to draft and edit a paper. I improved my abilities in conducting literature searches, critically thinking about the ideas presented in these papers, and synthesizing these claims into my own novel argument. Finally, this class helped me learn both how to give and receive constructive feedback on my writing and use this to improve my own paper.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I can confidently say that I learned the most in this class out of all my classes this semester. Unlike other classes that might teach me facts and principles about a certain topic, this class has taught me life lessons. It is a writing class and has helped me improve my writing by an unfathomable amount, but the collaborative aspect of the class has taught me to work effectively in a team environment. Writing a paper to me was a very personal process where I express my voice, and having to share my voice on such a big paper was challenging, in a good way. It helped me see others perspective and showed me how my voice can be strengthened by others, and also help strengthen others too.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
As an international student, I was initially pretty insecure about my writing skills. Still, this class and Dr. Parks, most importantly, showed me that I can write and that there are specific strategies for structuring the process.
Considering the class was about neuroscience, I've learned a lot about the brain and CTE, as that was the topic of our group project. 
Regarding the more general things, I've learned a lot about how scientific p[papers are produced, how to approach them, and what are the most important things to consider along the process. 
Skills-wise, it mainly was about group dynamics. I feel like I've never had issues with that in hs, and this course made me realize that in real life, you don't always work with people you want to work with and not everyone approaches work in the same way, and that there are a bunch of challenges associated with that.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I became very familiar with the writing revision and feedback process. I learned how to receive and incorporate peer feedback as well as how to give good feedback and analyze a paper as a whole. I also learned how to be more logical and clear with my writing as a whole by constantly tying back to my main argument. Finally, I learned how to use academic sources in my writing by taking the conclusions of the writer and analyzing it myself in the context of my argument instead of cherry-picking evidence that only supports my argument.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to effectively communicate with my reader-audience by articulating my argument and backing it with evidence and analysis.  I learned a lot of different ways to formulate my argument and think about writing, such as through the Storyboard Matrix or the "MEAL" plan.  I also became better at working alongside others and communicating with teammates to reach a common goal.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How to give peer review feedback in a constructive way
2. How to use writing tools (Zotero, Library, Writing Studio)
3. Creating a reverse outline to strengthen your paper

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The small class size and various small group activities made it easy to get to know other students in the class, which made me feel engaged with the classwork. I also appreciated how Dr. Parks always welcomed each of us at the beginning of class, as it encouraged me to participate in the class discussions.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Even though I'm not planning on studying neuro or medicine, I still found the class interesting.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was very stimulating in that it forced me to develop skills in analyzing current research and combining these ideas to form my own argument, something that is quite difficult but is a very useful skill to have. It also improved my skills in collaborating with others and operating within a team environment, something that is extremely applicable to the real-world. Lastly, I found the topic of this class to be fascinating, and I enjoyed learning about it a lot.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: we covered more than one topic in the class. Dr. Parks would try and incorporate different topics in Neuroscience throughout the semester and I found that to be stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
It was very stimulating as we discussed scientific neuroscientific concepts that I was unfamiliar with before. I was curious about how a teen's brain differs from an adult's and how this difference should be acknowledged during court hearings. 
We also met with a scientist who writes papers for scientific journals, which was fascinating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Dr. Parks' enthusiasm made direct class time very stimulating and the entire revision process was also very intellectually stimulating as I got to read a lot of other student's papers and think deeply about them.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was very intellectually stimulating because it required students to challenge what they know and think.  We were often presented with a neuroscientific research paper and asked to think about the complexities surrounding the evidence in relation to what it does and doesn't tell us about a particular topic.  I liked how the scientific research and information we were learning could be applied to real world problems. In particular, I liked reading about the use of neuroscience in court and as evidence in a crime.  It was stimulating and fascinating to learn about the newly developed state of neuroscience and what that means for society as whole.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: By having deep conversations about neuroscience with other students, I was able to see many different perspectives and learn from them. Much of the neuroscience content also forced me to think in new ways and ultimately develop improved skills in thinking and writing.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

However, if you are interested in the topic, definitely take this course. Dr. Parks is very sweet, supportive, and always available to students, and gives you many strategies to improve your writing.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You will put in some work for this class, but it will be super worth it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would absolutely recommend that any student with a passion for science (specifically neuroscience) take this class. It allows you to delve deep into a topic of your choice in this field, which is very interesting. Also, throughout the class, you are constantly engaging with current research in the field. It also greatly improved my skills in reading and writing scientific literature, which is a skill that I have been looking to develop as I am considering entering a scientific field as a career.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would highly recommend it, especially if you are considering a scientific career. This class helps you learn how to write scientific papers and I found it to be very helpful. Also if you are not a big fan of reading books for class, this class is your best bet because we write scientific papers instead and if you're interested in neuroscience, you'll find it interesting.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say that this is a perfect course to get engaged with scientific writing. On top of just writing papers, we analyzed how actual scientific research papers are created, what they the stratages are and how scientists engage with writing in their everyday life.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You will want to focus on planning your paper out before you write so it all fits together and supports your main argument. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned how to precisely write 3 central forms of writing: summary, analysis, and review/synthesis. I also learned how to effectively research and evaluate sources when finding evidence for research papers. Finally, I learned how to collaborate in a team on writing a single research paper and combining differing perspectives.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed my ability to research articles and journals related to my research topic. Being able to navigate Duke's research libraries and databases. Additionally, my knowledge of research paper formats and citation procedure has improved.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:

- I learned how to collaborate on a paper in a group, not just writing our own sections but writing collaborativley.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I improved my ability to collaborate effectively by integrating different perspectives into a cohesive research paper. I enhanced my research skills by analyzing articles and extracting relevant information, while also developing critical thinking through summarizing, analyzing, and synthesizing complex ideas. Learning to write summaries, analyses, and research papers, as well as revising and refining my work, has prepared me with essential skills for future academic challenges.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned effective ways to improve and revise initial writing drafts. This included learning about reverse outlining. I developed my ability to give feedback to others, in both how to structure my comments so that they can produce effective revisions and stating which parts of a draft are strong and effective so that the person I am critiquing understands what works well. I also gained insight on how to connect different ideas, not only across different topics, but different sources as well. It showed me that a lot of things are interconnected and that a holistic understanding of sources or information can lead to novel, helpful conclusions.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: To save your future-self the hassle, you should do the readings in advance. The class involves a lot of listening since the teacher anticipates students to be unfamiliar to the researching process. If you recently took AP Research, I would advise selecting an unfamiliar W101 to gain new skills; however, if your research wasn’t STEM-related and/or you’re interested in the course description, check it out and see how you’re feeling during drop-add period. Hopefully this won’t deter you but Dr. Welsh doesn’t believe in an A+, meaning students have to prioritize every writing assignment.

response_text: I think the biggest skills I developed in this course were my writing skills. I especially liked how the course encouraged learned and thinking about different perspectives on meritocracy and left it to us to draw our own conclusions based on the variety of perspectives.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to critically analyze the ways writing and communication are portrayed in various media forms, such as films, television, and journalism. This skill allowed me to see beyond the surface and understand the societal implications and biases embedded in these portrayals. I refined my ability to craft clear, persuasive, and well-organized essays. I also learned how to adapt my writing style to different audiences and purposes. I gained insight into how media not only reflects societal attitudes but also actively shapes them, particularly in how professions like journalism and authorship are perceived.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to more present my ideas in a more concise manner. Furthermore, I learned how to examine archival sources. Lastly, I gained exposure to some of the writing resources that Duke has such as the EWC.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze archival materials for research. I learned how to use the resources of Duke, including the Writing Studio and the Librarians. Finally, I learned how to take peer editing feedback and incorporate it into my work.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about rhetorical analyses, the use of primary sources, and how to use the Duke Libraries system in order to help with research.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to write wonderful papers that acknowledge and explain to the novice reader the purpose of my paper. I learned how to write rhetorical analysis, research papers, zines, and how to work in a group to complete a group project. Overall, this class has not only developed some of my world views, but it made me a better writer.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed critical thinking about different topics, how to view things from different perspectives, and a lot of insights into the world of reproductive justice.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I developed a lot of insight and knowledge about the concept/framework of reproductive justice and reproductive issues in the United States. Within this framework, I also learned about different topics that challenge or should be included in reproductive justice like forced sterilizations, pain, and menstrual equity.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned skills to improve my writing overall and better use the library resources. I am now better at targeting my essay analysis to exactly what is asked for in the rubric, cutting down my work to be more concise while maintaining the integrity of my essay argument, and I can now better navigate the library resources. I learned how to request off-site books and materials from the archival library, where to look on the library website to obtain good sources, and how to communicate with the libraries should I need assistance.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the value of carefully drafting out and planning each step of the essay-writing process, what reproductive justice can look like/its nuances, and how a variety of factors can impact reproductive justice policy.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

I would have liked to see some more interpersonal writing/recollections that give us even short moments to connect our purpose in this class to our identity and purpose in our lives in the world.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say this class is very interesting and intellectually stimulating if you engage with the material and put in the work. That being said, the class has a much heavier workload than other first-year Writing 101 classes, so be prepared for that.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would like to say push yourself to think beyond the bounds of even some of the concepts we discuss in class when you begin writing. I think it's very easy for us to narrow our scopes, and write or discuss the easier more straightforward ideals about writing when we're presented with this new information at a new space. However, I urge you to be creative and to go for the thesis that feels most challenging. Many times your most authentic and pertinent work to you will be reflected in your work and - although this shouldn't have to be a huge concern - it will reflect in your grades as well. I think it's helpful to use these classes and the things we learn here at Duke to just broaden your worldview. Allow Writing 101 to be an opportunity for you to take note of how much more you've learned and more specifically to this class, be in reflection of how even the ways we speak and write can be so much more than a simple "motif" or "common theme", it can be symbolic of individuality, heritage, ancestry, and life lived.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is quite intense for a Writing 101 class but if you enjoy this stuff do it! And the good thing about is your teacher will put in double the effort you put in for this class they are very good at making sure every question is answered

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
Do not be alarmed by all the assignments listed on the syllabus. The reading may seem a little more on the intense side during the beginning of the semester, but it all begins to make sense and lessen as the semester moves forward. Dr. Asmuth is very purposeful with each assignment and class discussion they plan, so everything you will be doing will have a purpose and help you become a better writer! The two big projects for this class are broken up and worked on throughout the semester, which is very helpful as well in terms of work load. 
Other than that, Dr. Asmuth does a great job at building an accepting atmosphere where everyone is able to participate and become active in discussion. I would recommend taking this class if you want to become a more skilled writer and have some time on your hands to dedicate to this credit!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would recommend against taking it unless you really like learning about language, linguistics, different dialects, and the way language is taught in schools. Everything we learn is about how writing is taught/viewed by other people, so unless you have a passion for that subject matter, the class can get pretty dry. Class time is also boring. I regret selecting this Writing 101 class and not switching out of it the first two weeks. There isn't too much work but is harder than other Writing 101s, and the project at the end of the year where you have to survey or interview other people is a lot of work.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a difficult course and one that is a large time commitment. Inside of class consists of mainly discussions and analyzing about assignments and outside of class is where a majority of the work is done where the student should make a good amount of time to complete assignments; about 1-2 hours a day.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned about the idea of attention literacy and how to name and modify different attentional modes. 
I learned about the process of writing an academic essay from ideation to the final draft.
I learned about how to assess my own writing and edit it without receiving written feedback from the professor first, to improve my self-editing skills.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to ask for help on writing, what attention literacy is, and how to do different phases of drafting.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how attention is an effortful process and can be altered to give you a new experience, I learned that there are three dimensions to every attention situation, and I learned how to write in a "cook-book" style to teach the audience about something new.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The ideas of this course (attention literacy) were entirely new. This includes the idea of multiple attentions, attentional lenses, and more. I also learned how to write an Annotated Bibliography and a new way to structure my writing process.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The writing process of the first and second essays showed me that I work better when I get more time to draft essays and that I need to spread out my workload to have a good product. Spreaidng out my time puts in buffer periods for when I have unexpected projects or large time commitments pop up like in the beginning of April when I started helping with a student Freewater Productions film set for seven hours at a time multiple times a week. With the drafts being mostly completion, that gives me the freedom to put in as much work as I want to when I have the time. Unfortunately for both essays 1 and 2 I had lots of work around the time the drafts were due so I was only able to put in minimal time for those but I could do that because of the freedom I was afforded.I also learned I can focus for certain periods of time and get a lot of work done but I definitely can’t seem to write rich text for an extensive amount of time so I had some struggles balancing it with other class work especially when it was a long-term engagement like studying. Fortunately, I believe I’ve learned a routine through this course on how I can lock in and enter the flow state that helps with productivity.Additionally, I’ve learned that pre-drafting experiences and feedback experiences are very helpful when I can see feedback about other people’s essays. This included the rapid-fire read-overs that Professor David did during class to check on our proposed attention situations and then also outlines. It’s shown me that the use of examples (other people’s essays) is important for my learning.I think my biggest lessons from the course about attention and attention literacy are the course concepts that I learned during this course. Learning about concepts like ethos/pathos/logos and heuristics and aesthetics directly showed me how I can apply lessons of this class to other subject areas and parts of my life.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Three things I learned in this class are the idea of what attentions in our world and attentional literacy are, how to construct new attentional lenses, and the effects that attention has on all of us. Each of these has helped shape my live and guide the way I look at different situations. Knowing this, I realize when I'm forcing myself into a solo view, and can more easily adjust.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to use language to help you wear an attentional "lens" that helps you construct a mental representation of a phenomenon that helps with processing it in the way you want.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Attention literacy--such an incredibly helpful tool in all facets of life. Not only does this course teach you how to write, but it gives you the tools you need to develop attentional skills which are invaluably useful in navigating day-to-day life.

response_text: I learned about attention literacy, the importance of different attentional modes, and course concepts like theory as a way of seeing and thinking.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The structure of reading materials for the first few weeks, then a mix of reading and writing before transitioning into only writing for the last few weeks was very helpful because it mirrored the natural progression of learning course concepts and then applying them to our essays. It was also very helpful that we were not expected to write an essay every week, so we could instead focus on outlining, writing, and editing our essay over a longer period of time.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about reproductive justice as a subject, which is exactly what I intended to learn when signing up for the class. Additionally, I learned a lot about rhetorical analysis which is something that I had struggled with before in previous writing classes, but since coming to this class I feel a lot more confident with all aspects of rhetorical analysis which I'm really grateful for. Last, I think that I've become a lot more aware of how to frame my voice and different effective methods for sharing my opinion. I think prior to this class I used to think of writing as just something to show off what I knew and didn't focus too much on the person who was reading it, but Dr. Taylor's peer review heavy format really helped me see my writing as a vessel for change which I'm going to take forward in all forms of writing.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Although I love this class more than anything, if you are not comfortable with being vulnerable with your feelings (in front of people that you aren't necessarily close with) I would not recommend this class. It can be overwhelming to re-experience traumatic moments as you write your case study, if I'm being honest. But for me, I took this class for that exact reason--I needed closure from something that had happened to me a long time ago, and I think this class helped me do that.
