question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about rhetoric, and how vital it is important to consider it when writing. Additionally I learned about the different modes of conveying information, even beyond what one would consider conventional writing.I learned about Kairos and how it is important to take into account when writing, especially when the timing of the writing could affect its perception.I learned that one could go beyond writing in a subjective manner when it comes to important topics and that narrativizing or even making something poetry-like through the use of proper diction can help convey information in a manner that sticks more with the reader.I learned a bunch about medical narratives and the history and effects of cancer on peoples lives. Henrietta Lacks story was particularly interesting because it was the at the intersection of so many identities. Through the structure of the book I learned the many things one has to go through to write a story about someone else that happened to cause revolutionary change, and that rhetoric has to be taken into account when doing so.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Throughout this course, I developed my skills as a writer and learned a lot about personal voice even in nonfiction. I was also introduced to research writing and reading which I believe will help me a lot in my future.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Experiencing a large variety of viewpoints makes you a more educated and compassionate person. This course has taught me much about the roots behind distrust around academics and physicians.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Non-fiction CAN be interesting and engaging to read, importance of ethos/lagos/pathos, how to use TWP & writing studio consultants.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Bein more analytical in how I approach media and read, how to write effectively and establish kairos, and analyzing my own perspective and influences.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Three specific things that I learned are what a recursive writing process is, how to utilize kairos, pathos, ethos, and logos, and also how to effectively read and analyze scientific text.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class, I developed skills in understanding and creating ethos, pathos, logos, and kairos. I also developed skills in understanding text that dealt with topics such as cancer, medicine, and all the social and ethical considerations that come with that. I learned how to analyze case studies as well as how to create research proposals from such studies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a lot of skills in regards to creative writing skills. I was challenged in this course to complete multiple assignments that required more creativity than a research paper. This was a challenge, but ultimately it grew my skills in this area and I am coming out of this class much more confidence in my creative abilities in regards to papers, stories, presentations, and writing in general. Another skill I developed was fully analyzing all perspectives of a situation. I learned this through the various readings and analyses of those readings we had in class. This skill can also be transferred outside of class, as now I feel like I am more empathetic and able to understand opposing opinions better. A piece of knowledge I gained throughout this course is how to actually perform research, what makes a source reliable, how to determine the dates of the sources you should look for based on your respective research topic.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Three specific things I learned in this class are the extensive ways in which you can find research and evidence for your writing through data sources, especially credible sources that are not biased. I also learned how to think deeply and critically, especially in analyzing texts and looking beyond surface-level examinations of writing. I also learned how reading non-fiction can be very fascinating, as beforehand, I did not particularly enjoy reading, but Dr. Corey’s selection of readings truly stood out to me and inpired me to read more non-fiction books.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to develop research questions, collaborate on high-level writing assignments/projects, and use rhetorical techniques in my writing.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Encouraged reading and discussion. There were activities that made it easier to discuss topics, since they were in smaller groups and allowed us to view things presented in the text through a different perspective. An example of this is the Hmong story role play, where we act out one of many roles, each with different views on medicine and spirituality. I think keeping the additional labors would be good and the variety of activities that allow us to interpret the text.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: To start, our professor was very supportive which made the class much more receptive to questions and open dialogue. In addition, working on just a few major projects but getting multiple rounds of professor and peer feedback definitely helped me develop my writing.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really liked not having the pressures of grades. I felt I could enjoy the activity of writing more rather than being hyper fixated on writing to satisfy benchmarks. I also liked the Labors since htey felt like a break from the normal flow of classwork.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Corey utilized various forms of assignments, in-class activities, and teaching methods in order to facilitate learning. Dr. Corey, did well matching the relative dynamics of the behavior and tendencies of the students, causing more consistent engagement.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Corey is a very kind and approachable professor, and she would help repeat any instructions if needed for further clarification. She also allowed for flowing conversations between students and would add points and or topics to help gear the subject of class discussions about our assigned readings. Assignments were sometimes hard to understand, but Dr. Corey did a great job in taking notes on how to adjust them for the next class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I feel like Dr. Corey kept us very engaged with discussions by changing the typical, sit in a circle and talk style discussions. She allowed us to discuss in small groups on walks outside class, she allowed us to sit outside and discuss, and she also added to the conversation during large group discussion, which was extremely helpful. This facilitated my learning because sometimes it's harder to want to speak up in a large discussion environment, so the small groups allowed me to gain confidence in my opinions and also spend time with my friends in the class. Also, I really like the grading contract - it keeps the pressure off of grades and allows you to write to the best of your ability without fear that your "best" isn't good enough.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Corey fostered an inclusive and inviting classroom environment through open class discussions and a class Google Doc that allowed us to share our opinions, even if we were unsure/scared of saying them out loud. I would keep the group work component of instruction for future years, as when she randomly assigns us into groups for specific assignments, it helps us learn more by engaging with new perspectives and collaborating these many views.

response_text: I feel like the topics we covered in class were a lot more engaging than I initially thought when I first entered. I thought the class would be difficult and hard to understand, when in reality it was very interesting and helped gain a perspective on medicine and how the different foundations of our society help and hurt certain demographics. I think also being graded on a grading contract made the class setting less stressful.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The small group discussions made this class stimulating, along with the various multimodal assignments, like the narrative mapping project and the additional labors. These assignments allowed us to expand and practice our writing abilities without having to write papers over and over.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: What made this class stimulating was the many different views that the main characters in the readings held and how social elements, such as racism and gender discrimination, contributed to medical failures.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: A lot of new perspectives were discussed that I hadn't considered before. This class also gave me so much freedom around writing that I have never experienced previously.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely worth taking, especially if interested in the history behind cancer and cancer research

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Please take it! Treat it more like an academic experience rather than your normal course. It felt that way for me.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's a great course that has a great balance of work and flexibility. Interesting topics and very accessible teacher, so don't be scared away by grading contract.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Don't be intimidated by the reading amount or the grading contract- both these aren't so bad or actually work in your favor, and it's overall a very enjoyable and interesting class!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a great course to take and probably one of the best Writing 101 classes that will be offered. Do not let the perceived amount of reading cause you to not take the course, because the reading is manageable and quite engaging.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

This experience has truly shown me the value of stepping out of my comfort zone and exploring new literary landscapes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Most of the text we read were written by, or were centered on, the Latin American experience, Latinidad, language and culture. We had a good balance between short "reflective" assignments and larger projects, with a book/movie Review (very fun!), a critical analysis paper and a podcast. We had a good range of media: with 2 books (10 hr reads over a month), a couple of movies, and other short readings / clips. So while I developed my writing, I also learned a lot about the Latin American experience. Even though I am not necessarily part of this community, I learned about the struggles of immigration, language barriers, and human rights issues around migration from South America. It was a really enriching class, and I feel more knowledgeable about the situation in the United States and of the world.

I also learned how to give constructive feedback on my peers' writing via peer review.  Finally, I learned how to write in a group as we worked on a literature review with a 3-person group.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have developed my ability to write, analyze, and synthesize scientific papers. I have also learned how to research effectively and what the APA style is.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to engage in academic/research writing, how to engage and respond to existing academic works, how to write as part of a group, how to give constructive peer feedback, and how to show my own voice/argument in an academic paper.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to engage in scholarly conversation through readings and writings. Every article we read was purposeful and talked about.
I learned how to write with a group of students. The group paper at the end of the semester taught me how to engage in conversations about writing with a group of students. 
I learned how to be analytical and constructive while giving feedback to other students through peer review (higher order, lower order, the 4 C's.)I have nothing but the best to say about this class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned about the intersection of neuroscience and our lives (from learning about the brain to understanding how neuroscience affects law)
2. I learned how to effectively research, summarize, and analyze academic articles that I could later use in my paper as evidence. 
3. I learned how to think more structurally and become a better writer through reverse outlines, peer feedback, revisions, and finding a balance between analysis and evidence.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned how to critically construct my ideas in writing and to prioritize the main themes I wanted to deliver.
2. To work collaboratively and build off of constructive criticisms. 
3. to develop my own personal opinion and stance instead of being ambivalent.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned good collaborative skills, and how to write clear, cohesive, and coherent essays. I also learned how to analyze academic writing, and how to create collaborative eacademic work.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Learned to build and support clear, logical arguments with strong evidence.
2. Improved drafting, revising, and editing skills to produce polished work.
3. Developed the ability to analyze texts and use insights to enhance my writing.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the varying class structures from week to week. Sometimes we would read articles and analyze them in class while other days would be focused on peer reviewing. There were even hands-on days like the Backyard Brains electric stimulation day.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Parks is always energetic and eager to help with any questions students may have. I really appreciated the variation of classes where she was teaching, helping us with individual work, or giving us time to work in a group. I really liked the small group conferences we did during the literature review paper.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Parks did an incredible job facilitating my learning and the environment of the class was very good.  She cultivated a strong culture and pushed us all to do our best and work hard.  I greatly enjoyed both of our major papers (Teen Brain + Lit Review) and I would definitely keep those for future years.  I also really enjoyed the debate on brain blame in class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought this class had the best environment out of any I’ve been in at Duke. My professor definitely made an effort to ensure we would have a good learning environment by taking time for us to get to one another at the beginning of the semester and also by having fun activities related to the course throughout.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Parks had an incredible way of engaging the class. Each session was particularly tailored to class needs; she introduced and taught topics very well. The most valuable part was the step-by-step process of writing we engaged in with Dr. Parks' class. Rather than assigning a paper with a due date, we would have a different part of our paper due every class (research question, mind map, central claim, outline, draft 1, draft 2, final draft). At every step of the way, Dr. Parks effectively taught the class how to engage in that specific part of the writing process. The emphasis on peer review was also incredibly helpful; learning how to both give and implement effective peer review greatly improved my papers and showed me certain flaws that I may have missed on my own. The real kicker of this class was the topic of Neuroscience. As opposed to high school writing, where all papers were literary analysis, I was able to choose a topic I was genuinely interested in. Previously, writing had been my most despised subject in school, but Dr. Parks' class gave me a real passion for my writing due to the topic, her unique way of engaging the class, and her care to help each student along with the writing process. This was likely the most impactful course I have every taken, and I would keep every aspect of it for future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Parks created a very inclusive and open environment, and having the class on east campus made it a very easy commute. I feel like I got to know a lot of people in class, and it made me comfortable to share my ideas and pieces of writing. She encouraged lots of group work, which I would continue to implement in future years. We all learned together like a team, and it really made it a positive and fun space for the students.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This was one of my favorite classes this semester! Dr. Parks did a great job fostering a supportive learning environment, promoting collaboration and intellectual thinking. I enjoyed working with others and seeing videos and real-life examples of neuroscience research and studies. There was a great balance between independent work and collaboration. I feel that the structure of the program was laid out well as we progressed and grew throughout the semester, we took on more responsibilities (finding our own articles, coming up with our own research question, etc).

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The introduction of Zotero has changed my journey of academic writing and is a resource I will use continuously in the future. The establishment of small deadlines have also inspired me to create my own personal deadlines outside of the course, which is a skill I plan on continuing to develop in the future for learning.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor fostered a highly engaging learning environment by encouraging active participation and collaboration with both peers and the professor. The course focused on accessible, low-level reading that allowed for more in-depth discussions and critical thinking.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned about strategies for planning, drafting, and revising my writing–including reverse outlines, storyboard matrices, and pulling all topic sentences together. 
I also learned about a lot about good practices for scientific writing–how to find good sources, use Zotero to organize my sources, and specific etiquette for citations.  
I became more comfortable with peer review, in both how to give and receive feedback, and how to ask for feedback on specific things.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned vital skills in peer reviewing, critical thinking, and scholarly communication. By engaging with both scholarly texts and my peers, this course encouraged me to accept the critiques of others in order to strengthen my writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned that first drafts are never going to be pretty, but that it is essential to get something written down in order to move forward with the writing process. I learned how to engage with the work of other scholars, like the papers of my peers, but also published literature. This skill included the ability to give effective feedback. Thirdly, I learned how to write my own literature review with the help of a group.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The Engage and reflection assignments allowed me to step back and reflect on my learning process. The professor is open to meeting outside of class to provide constructive feedback on students' work which encourages them to improve. Outside resources like the writing studio are also strongly encouraged, further supporting learning. We also do creative activities such as drawing and team-bonding activities outside, and we all loved it!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professor created a very comfortable learning environment as she showed genuine care for each of her students well being and took an interest in their progress. I think the frequent group and individual discussions with Dr. Parks were invaluable.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: From the beginning of the semester, the instructor had a detailed and accessible schedule that outlined how the course would proceed each day, which was helpful for planning my time. Also, she was very communicative in what she expected from us and open to feedback. She often was proactive in this second aspects, asking about how we felt about assignments (whether that be in effectiveness or how we felt about the deadline) and was willing to be flexible and change things based upon our answers. A large portion of this class required working in groups, and she established expectations and structure for how those groups would function, which was an incredibly important foundation as far as how our group operated and communicated throughout the semester. As far as my group project experiences go, it was one of the best.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Parks facilitated my learning through a variety of both in and out of class activities that fostered teamwork and collaboration. The strategies she employs encouraged a friendly, yet scholarly, means of communication, boosting my relationship with my peers while allowing us to also experience the hardships associated with extensive collaboration over time. Dr. Parks was extremely kind and always made herself available to assist us along the writing process if we needed help. She was fun, happy, light-hearted, and full of unwavering positive energy.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Though I am a Chemistry major, Dr. Parks made this course one of my all-time favorites. She always found ways to keep us engaged, making the class enjoyable and interesting at all times. She introduced activities that were extremely fun, but always had a crucial message behind them. They always enabled us to be more insightful. For instance, today we took 5 minutes away from our traditional assignments to try and fit a set of balls she brought from home into a bowl. We started this exercise immediately after reflecting on some of the things that were important to us in our lives. Being the last day of class, Dr. Parks was giving us a friendly reminder that even as the semester comes to a close and so many different stresses come up in our lives, that we need to keep the "big" things stable. As long as we focus on those, everything else will fall into place. (The balls wouldn't fit into the bowl unless the biggest ones went first). There were other neuroscience related activities too, such as the brain to brain interface activity (my favorite one). Dr. Parks is also very energetic and there is never a boring moment. It is evident that she cares for her students, through the lengths she goes to in explaining material, the humanity she expresses to the class, and the genuine care she demonstrates to all.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

response_text: I feel as though I definitely grew in terms of scholarly thinking, in learning how to dissect evidence in a way that effectively works towards a claim. I also feel a lot more confident inserting my voice into our pieces. As someone who comes from a heavy writing background, I feel as though this course has consolidated the skills I've been working on for a long time in a new context, and I'm really grateful for how supportive and effective this environment was for doing so.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How to engage with scholarly writing - this course taught me how to analyze and respond to articles discussing neuro scientific data 
2. Feedback - both ways. This course taught me to ask for and effectively use feedback from others (peer, writing studio, teacher etc.). It also made me a better peer reviewer and has made me more cognizant of the strategies and themes I want to include in my writing
3. Writing with my own voice in a more science based research field

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned how to analyze scholarly sources and integrate them into my own argument. 
2. I learned how to conduct scholarly research with online databases.
3. I learned how to bring my own voice into scientific writing and consider the wider implications of scientific development on society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Through this course, I developed many writing skills and immensely grew as a writer. My work on the two main papers we were assigned gave me the opportunity to practice ideating an argument, drafting, and revising. None of my work had ever undergone a revision to the extent of my paper in this class, where I truly focused on cohesion, conciseness, clarity, line of reasoning, evidence to analysis ratio, applying knowledge learned through mini-lessons in class to better my paper. Overall, I grew in this course to think about writing and the writing process in a new way. Scientific writing is so much more than making a statement or explaining research, but rather understanding the current state of understanding in a particular field, developing a unique argument that adds to the conversation, articulating your claim in a way that makes sense to the reader while maintaining scientific accuracy, and being receptive of feedback at all stages of writing. Writing is truly a process where critical thinking is of the utmost importance, and my confidence in my capabilities grew as a result of this course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Parks was AMAZING as both an educator, a source of support, and an engaging scholar. Her expertise radiates in such a constructive way; I feel like I always gained new insights during our discussions of various skills-- even those I already knew how to do-- and I never had any fear asking her for help or advice, which I really treasure in an educator. She always made it clear that we had many external sources of support too, whether that be through handouts or by encouraging us to go to the writing center or use our librarians. I appreciate the way she taught various writing skills, notably in terms of structuring an essay and balancing the insertion of our voices into a piece. I am really glad I took this course!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Parks utilizes a lot of engaging activities to facilitate discussion or build skills. This includes spending class time to analyze interesting sources, holding workshops to refine our essays, and reflection activities for fun to help us think back on the writing process. I particularly liked Dr. Parks' model of peer review, which involved peers reading each other's essays and holding small group conferences between them to share their critiques.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Parks was an incredible teacher, who not only taught us writing skills in a traditional way of lecture-style lessons, but also integrating interactive activities that were engaging and collaborative to ultimately further our learning in the course. I appreciated the collaborative nature in class, from peer-sharing in class to larger class discussions to extensive peer-review to cowriting a paper. Additionally, I liked how the assignments guided us through the writing process by breaking a daunting task into smaller chunks, such as researching 2 articles or creating an outline, instead of having one big due date for our final paper. Not only was this effective to aid us in time management, but it also led me to think deeper, especially in the beginning stages of my paper. Lastly, Dr. Parks is an incredibly kind and competent instructor that creating a very positive learning environment and was always willing to answer any questions or have a discussion.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

What was good about this course was that even if I didn't agree with some of the material or other students, we could always have a civil discussion and see eye to eye on the reasons behind each perspective or the objective historical background. I also tihnk that my general writing ability improved, since before I was used to stretching out essays with redundant wording and following a strict format that I knew would work. In this class, however, I felt that I could naturally write to my desired length and, through peer workshops, able to refine my writing into what I considered the best as well.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained much insight by taking this course through the texts that we read throughout the semester. Important concepts that stuck with me was Orietalsim, the way the West perceives the East. We also learned about how females are perceived in Asian American culture, and also the stories of many important people.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned about the history of Orientalism and Edward Said's analysis of how the West has viewed and treated the East.
2. I learned how to cite properly, how to introduce / contextualize the author, and
3. I learned a lot about the history of different ethnic Asian groups in the U.S and specific historical events like the Chinese Exclusion Act, the Vietnam War and its effect on various refugee groups, the Korean War and the Korean baby export business, and much more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned new insights related to a diverse perspective of Asian American stories. There are so many different types of Asian Americans, and hearing about the Hmong, Vietnamese, Chinese, Korean, Japanese, Indian, etc. people was very impactful to show the similarities but also differences in all of their experiences. I also learned how to analyze a variety of different sources, from graphic novels to documentaries to poetry. All of the different ways that Asian Americans chose to tell their stories highlighted to me the uniqueness of the Asian perspective.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:

Writing personal essay by incorporating academic journals or literature. Reading, analyzing and developing my own opinions based on course content. Discussion and deep learning through engagement in content.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Maxwell always made sure to be as accommodating as possible when students were dealing with anything, which made it easier to learn and want to succeed in the class. She made sure to take away as much unnecessary pressure as possible in order to facilitate each student's learning. I also appreciated that reminder emails were often sent out for assignments. Additionally, every class two students were assigned as "notetakers" where they would write down notes from each class in a shared notes document that was accessible to everyone. That way, if we were ever in need of a reminder of what we did in class or wanted to catch up after missing a day, it was very easy to do so. That is an aspect that I would definitely recommend keeping for future years.

response_text: It is a good course- honestly, not much writing involved. As someone who really likes writing, the course was much more technical than I thought it would be. Would have preferred less of a stem - y approach to the class and more of a philosophical / ethical take.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this course! I cannot stress how underrated this course is, both in terms of workload and content. I think the content is especially appealing for STEM majors, since we covered so many fascinating topics like the technical aspects of LLMs (perceptrons, deep learning, transformers), first-order and categorical logic, and many current debates in the AI development like misuse, what it means for a computer system to be sentient, and existential risks. The workload is very manageable, typically just one reading per class and no homework. We did very little writing compared to other WRITING 101s, only having a 500-word midterm paper, a 1500-word final paper, and occasional 200-300 word quick responses in class. Professor Victor is very smart and approachable as a PhD student, and he always mentions recent AI news in class whenever he found something interesting. One thing is that we didn't get a whole lot of feedback on our writing throughout the course and not much has been graded so far, so I'm not actually sure what my grade will be at the end of the semester. Besides that, great course, learned a lot, and felt very intellectually stimulating throughout!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! It's a very intellectually stimulating class -- it genuinely makes you think and consider different perspectives, and exposes you to so many different fields within ethics that you probably didn't know even existed. Prof. Crespo does a great job at making sure the students get to have a say in what the class is about, and is very flexible with introducing subjects or papers that fit students' personal interests, as well as global issues.

I also learned about the importance of self reflection and how it can guide future writing projects by targeting areas of improvement.

response_text: I have gained knowledge on the true process of writing and the best ways to structure critical stances on issues related to gender discrimination. We had plenty of writing exercises that made me more comfortable with gathering ideas. We would have many class debates that would expand traditional ways of viewing the gender gap in STEM. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of things through taking this Writing 101 course. Given that the course is called "Closing the Gender Gap in STEM" I learned a lot about several female scientists who were so influential yet their contributions are not always recognized. I loved all of the articles that we were asked to read for class and given how much I liked them all, I think I retained the course content well. I also learned about the different waves of feminism as well as sameness compared to difference feminism which was something I was not very familiar with before taking this course. Given that my instructor heavily valued word economy, I will always remember one analogy he said to the class which was something along the lines of words being like money so writers should be intentional with what words they pick and to avoid words that do not push one's argument forward. So through taking this course I definitely think I have become a stronger writer.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class I learned what word economy was, how to fix writers block and I learned a lot about female scientists whose work was often overlooked due to sexism in the field.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to experience a challenge. Every writer has an opportunity to grow, and Caleb guarantees that. Use every resource possible, make sure to complete the readings. You make the class what it is. If you simply try to pass along without contributing to discussions or taking the writing process seriously, you will be unfulfilled and you will not flourish. Also, manage your time well. Caleb gives assignments that can seem daunting, but it is always best to just start writing. Especially because he gives us enough time to complete assignments and is open to extending deadlines in response to the class.

It also helped me learn a greater variety of writing styles, some of which I probably would've never learned if not for this class (ex. album review, program note). Also, the PNP project being structured so that students must cut down large portions of their work to around 500 notes was a helpful experience. Although it felt like I was putting in too much time into work that won't be used in the beginning, I know see how useful this project is.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Idea synthesis -- I learned how to connect my ideas and examine the intersections of these ideas / explore how they relate to each other.
Constructive criticism -- On major assignments (mid-term paper, final project), we were given time to peer review and receive feedback. We were also directed to schedule help sessions at the Writing Center, which was conducive to a multi-staged writing process.
Detailed reading and annotation -- Throughout the semester, we read texts at home and then discussed them in class, which required deep contemplation. We also used these texts as mentor pieces, and picked up some of the writing techniques in our own work.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I used the drafting process to learn as I write
2. I reworked my own synthesis and analysis in my writing compositions
3. I questioned information on a deeper level to develop stronger, original claims

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned many new skills in this Writing course. I learned about 1) different new styles of writing and how to write in those styles 2) the importance of qualitative data and creative research 3) the ability to conduct a qualitative research project, and write a paper that follows that structure and 4) many skills to make my writing better with a more engaged experience, such as writing more drafts, working in pieces, and utilizing peer and teacher feedback.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed my writing process and learned how to draft more effectively.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned how to collect primary source information about a topic we were writing about. We then learned how to combine that information into a paper with secondary sources. We also learned how to generate themes from the info and data we gathered and to express those themes in our writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think that I have gotten much better at revising and being willing to edit my work. I used to believe that my first draft was probably good enough and that once I wrote something I could turn something in. I have learned that this is not the case and that I must instead make many iterations in order to have the best writing possible.I also learned more about research and how to conduct it. While using only scholarly research is hard, it does make your writing so much more reliable and that is important.I have also learned how to give peer feedbakc and the importance of it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think creatively about creativity and writing as a field and was exposed to know ways of writing such as reverse outlining, debunking the myths behind creativity, and how to engage an in academic conversation.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I now understand how to approach writing in an academic context, I see writing as an open-ended conversation, and I now understand that writing is a thinking process that allows for ideas to be brainstormed and interrogated. All of these things I will take and use outside of this class as well as the idea of process work and not being scared of revising.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to more effectively revise my essays; revision is more than having a flow and word choice. It was important for me to learn how I present the information, the placement of paragraphs and ideas, and meaningful analysis affects readability and my ability to share my thoughts with the readers. Also, I learned that writing is about the process of thinking not presenting already formed thoughts. This was important for me to break down my already-formed writing processes and explore a new approach to writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. From reading the various articles on myths, I gained more insight into how I was personally following various academic "norms" and thus motivated to challenge them when appropriate.
2. Through specific peer and teacher feedback, I've learned how there is a disconnect between the content in my head and the content I ultimately present in my paper.
3. Because of the process-driven timeline of each assignment, I now value the writing process as more the opportunity to grow rather than simply the final product.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I started thinking of my writing in terms of how I can communicate my ideas as clearly as possible and now check for that when I revise. Also, I learned how to have inquiry in my writing and gather primary research through interviews.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned how to conduct my own interview-based academic research and how to analyze and interpret qualitative data in a paper
2) I learned what it means to inquire in writing and explore difficult questions in a way that goes beyond just arguing a point
3) I learned how to contribute to a larger conversation in academic writing and synthesize evidence to make new, fresh points and analysis rather than just restating a bunch of other author's points .

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The individual conferences with the professor were extremely helpful to improve my writing direction

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor facilitated our learning by creating specific assignments that promoted the engaged and dynamic editing process. We had peer review drafts, instructor drafts, short responses, all that helped aid me in writing a final paper.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The big assignments were very well structured and there were guiding assignments along the way which were quite helpful.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor set up the assignments to be do throughout an extended period of time to allow you to receive feedback, and not just do the entire project the night before its due. This structure allowed me to complete these projects to the best of my ability.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The main thing that helped me stay engaged with this class was the fact that all of the classes were engaging and were very constructive if we ever did any activities where we were writing.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the feedback aspect was great. I was getting constant feedback and even if it wasn't part of the assignment to receive feedback, if I emailed Dr. Davis, she would provide feedback. This helped a lot with how I should approach my work.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Davis ensured that the class was engaging through activities such as peer review, moving around the room looking at articles or books, activities on sticky notes/flashcards that facilitate my learning. The activity in the beginning of the class with the different puzzles to think creatively was very interesting and should keep for future years. It would be interesting to circle back and do a similar activity at the end of the course to see our progression.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor made sure there was lots of engagement within students during class and between peers through peer response which facilitated learning opportunities by receiving feedback and how to revise and better your work outside of your own eyes. I think this level of engagement really helps the course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated the emphasis this class put on reading someone else's thoughts or discovery, discussing the reading in class, and then implementing the reading into what we were working on. However, toward the end of the semester, this process felt repetitive and less meaningful, especially when working on our writings seemed more important and the readings felt familiar or repetitive. When the ideas in the readings were not new, I felt the readings were not interesting or helpful. Maybe there is a different way of thinking about something and discussing it to break this repetitive process.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I felt that the instructor did a great job in making our learning environment open and constructive by encouraging in-class discussions and having many opportunities for reflection. The idea of a process work was somewhat new to me, but looking back, it was very helpful in facilitating my learning through each assignment. For future years, I would definitely keep the reflections, process work, and individual conferences.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor had the materials needed and additional resources available in their respective weeks in Canvas, and they were available for questions after class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class was one of my favorite English/writing courses I have ever taken in my life, and it was pretty much entirely thanks to Dr. Davis. In particular, the conferences she held for 2 of our assignments were absolutely game-changing for my approach to writing and performance on the papers. Her feedback is exceptional, and the conversations we had about my work and what I was trying to express in my writing were so valuable to me. She's so good at taking your writing and helping you see things you might have not noticed/realized are in your work and identify points you could make to strengthen the paper. She guides you to ways to improve your work. She doesn't just tell you "do this" "change this," or "fix this" - she helps you actually understand what effects different techniques/ideas/structure in your work can have and figure out what exactly is the strongest way to present your ideas and fulfill the prompt. I loved the conferences and I would absolutely keep those as a part of as many assignments as is feasible since I feel like that improved my writing and reasoning abilities so much.

response_text: Professor gave valuable feedback on writing style that pushed me to rework drafts. Sometimes I got bored of content monotony from reading about creativity so much

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was very stimulating in that you chose topics and got to delve into them and fully immerse yourself in writing. question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class was stimulating by challenging the assumptions and practices most first-year students have coming out of high school.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: On the first few days of class, I remember taking a deeper dive into what creativity actually is, which immediately made the subject relevant to my own life. Throughout the class, I've been able to make connections between the in-class topics and my own life, which has made it intellectually stimulating. One aspect that could be improved is incorporating more mediums when considering creativity rather than just written articles, such as more TEDTalks.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class exposed me to new ways of going about the writing process and challenged some of my previous ideas about writing.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was stimulating because of the 3 major papers we had throughout the year and how the prompts themselves were so interesting and so detached from the "traditional essays" you write in high school. High school writing is so rigid - 5 paragraph structure, focused on arguing a point - but the writing we did on this class was so much more thorough and interesting and truly was at a higher-level. I also liked how we always had so much freedom to choose what we wrote about. The narrative inquiry paper was about ourselves so we got to choose our guiding question, we got to pick our writing/creativity myths, and the academic research was about pretty much anything we wanted concerning creativity/writing. That meant that for every assignment I was deeply invested in the topic I was writing about.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It’s a challenging course that requires a lot of attention

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a fascinating class about the nature of creativity and how it relates to academia. You will write three engaging pieces that will challenge your notion of creativity and academic writing.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It involves a sizeable amount of writing - more than most of the other writing sections. To me, the topic wasn't that interesting either as it was exploring the writing process and creativity as separate processes.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Very difficult, she WILL push you. Sometimes can feel like you're being talked down to, and the class will make you feel like crap sometimes. Reading her comments has ruined multiple afternoons for me. It frustrated me to no end. HOWEVER, if you want to get better at writing, what she does works. I definitely had to push myself and I feel like the work has paid off.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a good class but keeping track of all of your process work, and other draft types can be confusing for the writing assignments.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is harder than it may look! Be willing to dig in and change your writing... a lot.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Stick through the process! You will learn and grow in this class even though it is challenging and there is a lot of writing! Dr. Davis is truly amazing and a passionate professor who instills values of perseverance and curiosity in her students through her enthusiasm and kindness. In addition, she is great if you want one-on-one feedback on your writing.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class helps you write in an academic context but also pushes to redefine writing as an engaging, thinking process. This class has been very effective in teaching me how to contribute to a conversation and also how to brainstorm and voice my ideas.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The course challenged the way I approached the writing process. It was exceptional in teaching me how to approach a first draft and revision. However, though this course is about creativity, the course did not incorporate creativity in writing. In the first assignment, a narrative inquiry, I felt free to use metaphors, imagery, and experiences to paint a picture of my experience with writing, which I enjoyed. However, the last two assignments, a review and research essay, felt very constricted. While knowing how to approach these genres of writing may be helpful for my future years of college, I was expecting to be able to have my own creative twist and explore a topic that interested me; I wish I could have explored a topic that sparked my curiosity rather than a topic related to creativity or writing.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Dr. Davis is a very knowledgable and helpful instructor, and this class definitely is a representation of this. You learn based on how much effort you are willing to put in this class, but overall a great experience!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Putting your best effort into the engagement assignments does help a lot when it comes to preparing the final submission for a major assignment.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's an absolutely phenomenal Writing 101 that will make you a better writer, and it is so enjoyable so long as you pick writing topics that actually interest you. Read all feedback you get, even for the final essays, since you will be able to apply the feedback for one kind of essay on the others.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned these things in writing 101...
1. How to develop my writing skills in an academic way 
2. I learned about the intricacies of the latinx culture and identity in a way I've never thought about it 
3. I learned how to work in groups and participate in important conversations that covered difficult topics

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The class taught me a lot about both writing but also the Latinx experience. I learned a lot about how to analyze a text, construct an effective argument, build supporting information, and write solid introduction and conclusion paragraphs. Sotelo-Miller emphasizes story telling and how it can be used as an effective way of building a narrative and I learned a lot about how to convey my own voice in my writing. On the other hand, I also gained a lot of information about how people define Latinidad, what it means to be American, the immigration process, and the experiences of undocumented individuals.

response_text:
- Research
- Writing

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We had three main projects: a review, podcast, and critical analysis. During this course, we developed analytical writing skills, argumentation, and more. We also practiced our presentation and organization skills by leading several presentations and one 45min-1hr group discussion.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the way Latine culture was shaped by the historical events that happened to the different groups that make up the Latine community. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professor did I great job of incorporating elements of a traditional writing class while also making the class very engaging. The think and writes done at the beginning of each class were a good way of getting us in the writing mindset and reflecting on our own thoughts. I also really enjoyed how the course was structured very collaboratively, the professor encouraged group discussion and we also had multiple group workshops and assignments throughout the year. I really enjoyed the context reports and group presentations done on our main sources. They helped us become more engaged with the content and incorporate our own ideas and reflect on what content we found important. I also appreciated how much time we had to work on each assignment. The fist draft, second draft, and final draft structure, as well as the multitude of workshops that went along with each assignment, allowed us to strengthen our pieces and gain feedback at every step.

These methods were incredibly engaging in bringing in all voices from members of the class. In future years, I would highly recommend continuing the use of these group activities.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I would keep some of the methods of instruction the same, such as writing our final research paper in steps. First we wrote the abstract, then the outline, and finally the annotated bibliography. This way, we get feedback throughout the whole process, and we have chances to revise.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
