question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Overall, this course is a good first-year Writing 101 class. It allows you to work on basic writing skills without expecting you to be advanced in terms of your writing abilities. However, I would say that the way this course is run is ambiguous at times. Sometimes students feel like they are unaware of what is happening in class or what is due for the next class session. I also feel like this class could work on better in-class communication between Professor Bello and students.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: good course to take if interested in technology and media and its impact on identity; make sure to do the readings

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say to come in with an open mindset. This class was neither about liking nor disliking digital media, and I think sometimes people get caught up on that topic. There are weekly writing assignments and reading assignments due before each class, so be prepared to write and read pretty frequently. The load is quite manageable and builds across the term, so you are always fully prepared to take on the assignments. Make sure to complete the reading assignments to be able to fully participate in conversations, for it is quite obvious when students don't. Additionally, since there are so many in-class group activities, you are sure to build relationships in this class, so come in with an open mind.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: There is an essay or writing assignment due every week. In addition, there are readings every week. It is a lot of homework, and each assignment is graded out of five points. Because of this, assignments that take much longer are worth the exact same as the smaller assignments.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are interested in discovering the relationship between digital technology (including social media) and people in contemporary society, please take this class. This class will really help you to practice your critical thinking ability and hone your writing skills. You will be able to learn in an environment with less pressure and get a taste of what academic research looks like.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about structure while writing, especially writing with a purpose. I don't think I really understood why people wrote before this, but I think I have a better sense of the purposes of both reading and writing now. I learned specifically how to outline a paper, how to write with an audience in mind, the purpose of an introduction to hook the reader, give them a reason to read it. I think as important as it is to communicate your thoughts, it's equally important to think about how your writing is going to be interpreted on the other side.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how to analyze methods of discourse used across a genre and about genre conventions. I also learned about various ways of thinking about education for example the Banking Model of Education and the Problem-Posing Model of Education. Lastly, I learned about how to present my thoughts in an organized and systematic fashion as well as relate my individual experiences to a quote or concept displayed in a text.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I became better at thinking about literature and its consequences. We learned about literary theory and how to apply it to the genre of fantasy fiction. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the method of reading and utilizing critical theory in my writing, I gained insights into how fantasy novels influence children (their belief systems, identities, etc), and I learned how to incorporate supporting secondary sources into my literary analysis.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to deeply analyze texts to find the deeper meaning behind different words and scenes in different types of media. I learned how to set up different essays structurally to make my argument flow and make the most sense. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I received meaningful exposure to critical theory, research methodology for written argument, and collaborative revision. I had never integrated theory into my writing before, nor had I been exposed to college-level analysis. Kate's class and her teaching provided a very strong introduction to theory, both as a lens for interpreting work and producing effective arguments. Next, the assignments and class structure provided support and encouragement in learning to research external sources for my arguments. I was able to draw on sources from the Duke Library that I would have otherwise not used without this class's support. Lastly, I feel that I improved in my ability to give and receive meaningful feedback on my writing, thanks to the class's structure that encouraged peer discussion and revision.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How to better structure an essay for flow
2. Close-reading of both book and movie scenes
3. How there are implicit biases in fantasy novels that play on gender/racial stereotypes, and how they can shape the way children dream/think about reality

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to work on close reading, diving deeper into the analysis of different sections of a text and make valuable connections. I also learned a lot about the genre of children's fantasy literature and how it has evolved over time. It is important to consider how surrounding historical context impacts a writer's work. One method that we used in our writing was the uneven u, which is a structure that places direct evidence in the center of a paragraph so that it can be preceded by necessary context and followed by a connection to the main point.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Good grasp on essay writing structure, reading critical theory, engage in these academic discussions

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class, I learned about the analysis tool of "the uneven u" and practiced identifying it in others' writing and using it in my own. I also learned several frameworks of critical theory, including disidentifications, LeGuin's carrier bag theory of fiction, and Chesterton's idea of the morality of fairy tales. We also developed by discussion our understanding of the evolution of the fantasy genre over time.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really appreciated how the class environment struck a balance between structure and freedom. Providing background context before discussions and posing thoughtful questions helped guide the conversation, while still allowing students the freedom to choose to answer the question or not. This doesn’t mean students weren’t participating just because it was voluntary—in fact, I think since it was voluntary participation encouraged MORE students to engage without feeling pressure. Indeed, our class discussion was effective, efficient, and full of interesting points and perspectives about the texts and movies.

The in-class discussions are very helpful because we get to hear tons of perspectives on different papers and texts. I like that before essays are due, we get to peer edit them. This helps find simple errors and gives great feedback from different point of views. I think this course should be kept pretty much the same.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I like how we moved through different units beginning with fantasy to fairytales to analyses on power/prophecy. I felt like this helped give the class more structure, as each unit kind of built on the other, and we could easily tie what we learned from one book in conversation with another. I really enjoyed how "chill" the classroom environment was. Class felt more like a conversation between the students, rather than an intimidating discussion with "right" or "wrong" answers. Professor Turner often asked really thought-provoking questions when we do close readings of scenes that I would have never thought about before. She is also very understanding of her students' circumstances and allows late assignments so long as you communicate before hand.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

response_text: I really loved the function of discussion in this class. Professor Turner was incredible at both determining the materials for discussion and mediating the discussion itself. There were many moments in discussion when I realized my worldview was shifting and opening up or when I reevaluated literature I had loved reading in the past based on the theory we were talking about. The lectures were also well done- in-depth enough to be useful, but concise enough to be engaging and digestible. I also have to say that I enjoyed the readings outside of class very much. Professor Turner assigned a variety of difficulty levels in our readings, enough to challenge us and push us to develop our academic reading skills without burning out. I did find some of the reading difficult, but difficult in a good way and very rewarding. Professor Turner was also incredibly supportive and accessible, which made the class a lovely and comfortable space to be in.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This course was a great introduction to an undergraduate level class that helped me develop the skills needed to handle the college level workload. Compared to high school English, I felt like there were fewer strict guidelines to follow, which both allowed me to grow with more intellectual freedom and also forced me to learn how to find my own structure without as many points of feedback. Still, Professor Burkbauer kept certain check-in points such as the paper proposals and peer workshops, which made it a reasonable transition. She made it very clear that she was available to help with our writing but also to help our general transition, and struck a remarkable balance between being a personable mentor and a respectable instructor.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The structure of the class pushed me to take the time necessary to craft a thorough, well-written paper instead of writing it last-minute. We had multiple weeks of peer feedback, which was very helpful for me, and also allowed me to spend several sessions working on my essay with a new perspective each time. In addition, the annotation assignments forced me to learn how to read more efficiently while still participating in active reading and gleaning necessary information from the text. Also, the instructor's lessons on signal phrases and MLA citations were very clarifying, and I will continue to employ these strategies in future essays.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Sometimes Prof. Li likes to go on tangents a lot during class and it can be somewhat boring - I usually find myself counting the minutes until we leave just because I am not interested in the content that we are discussing that particular day. I think the class could be more intellectually stimulating if each class did not have exactly the same format as the previous day's class - all of the days kind of felt the same in this class and some variety would have helped me be more engaged on a day-to-day basis.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: A lot of the things we discussed were new to me, so engaging with this novel material was stimulating. Professor Yan's excitement and interest in the topics we interacted with also helped in making the course more stimulating. However, I think the course could be more stimulating by breaking up the academic conversations with fun activities. For example, other WRIT 101 courses go to the gardens or attend lectures from visiting scholars; I think this course, and student's learning, could be improved by reducing time spent purely engaging with academic texts as it gets repetitivve and boring as the semester goes on.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a very challenging and time-consuming course, but very intellectually stimulating and rewarding. In the long run, you will probably become a better writer, but intense projects and assignments will wear you down during the semester.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Try your best to engage with the topic even if it isn't your first choice necessarily. You can truly learn a lot about the field. I also encourage you to get to know your classmates as that can make the experience in this class a lot easier and more exciting, whether that is for group presentations or just reaching out outside of class if you need help with an assignment. I think this course will change your perception of what writing is and how it is done. You will certainly grow a lot as a student in this class!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is essentially like AP English Language & Composition on steroids. You go over a lot of the same kind of content (although way more in-depth) relating to rhetorical analysis, argumentative skills, framing and supporting claims with evidence, etc. That is not unlike what you may expect in an intro to academic writing class, but this one in particular has a lot of readings associated with it that very much go a level beyond any kind of the content that you would have learned in high school.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are looking for any easy WRIT 101, I would not recommend this course. While it is not the most demanding, this WRIT 101 is one of the more challenging and time-consuming courses. If you are a prospective English major or want to learn about the abstract concepts in writing, then you will probably like this course. However, for most students, who are just trying to get the requirement out of the way, reading 20+ page articles and writing 300+ word reflections on discourse communities before each class meeting will not be enjoyable, in my opinion. The assignments are not terrible -- three 2000 essays -- but in comparison to other courses which have three 800 word essays on Disney and nature, they are dense and completing them gets old quick.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Not the most interesting Wri 101 class. Considerable amount of work, but will get most credit if you submit your work on time. Dr Yan is an amazing person, super kind, probably the most welcoming professor I've met at Duke. However, she is a new professor and needs time to learn how to teach effectively. She is trying her best!! However, the guidelines of the class are very vague - students don't know what to write about, and what is required of them. You won't know if you're doing well until the final grade of the project is released - and by that time it'll be too late to change anything. However, I feel like Dr Yan is really trying very hard to make her class better, so maybe it'll be better next semester.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You have the chance to delve deeper into your passions; enjoy it!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think the most important skills I learned were essentially unlearning everything I learned about writing in high school. For example, in high school, I was taught you can't use an I and that paragraphs should be long and bulky in an argument essay. I remember receiving my feedback for my first argument essay and saying to myself, "Wow, I have a lot to relearn." Therefore, to me, it was a very informative course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the relationship between humans and nature in urban design, how to structure argumentative paragraphs, and how to work on conciseness.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot on how to really strengthen an argument. Though I thought I was a bit strong in this area prior to enrolling in the course, Dr. Smith really showed me a lot that I had never considered when approaching a piece of writing, and I really appreciate the level of precision and care she took in teaching us these skills. In addition, I learned much on how to format a paper (works cited pages, incorporating figures, etc.) and how to write in different styles, such as an Op-Ed vs. a formal argumentative paper, something I think was very valuable considering the changing landscape of our engagement with literature.

In the past, all I really did for research was a quick google search. The papers that we did were great since they allowed me to deep dive into my topic of choice.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Taylor facilitated our learning by giving us time to freewrite and engaging us with the topic matter through participatory discussion, reading interesting articles, and cool projects. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This subject material was engaging and I really enjoyed our class discussions. Class activities were varied and engaging, and I really enjoyed our trip to the Rubenstein to look at archives. The grading system for this class was supportive and clear. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Our professor framed the course to have 3 major essays - one 3-4 page close reading (no outside sources), one 4-5 page research paper (academic outside sources), and a 6-8 page final paper (close reading coupled with outside non/academic sources). As a result, we were able to develop our skills to write these types of essays. She also deliberately required MLA format for the first essay and APA format for the second paper so that we could gain experience writing both types of papers. She also provided very basic but also helpful guides to writing a general essay in case our high school english courses didn't prepare us sufficiently. Regarding the course topic, throughout frequent in depth discussions of our selected course readings, current events, podcasts, or personal experiences, we all gained a deeper/nuanced perspective on the theme of meritocracy and its prevalence, importance, and impact.

1. Content: How artificial intelligence systems (including LLMs) work, what the risks and benefits of this technology is, and how we can think about it from an ethical framework.
2. Skill: How to construct logical arguments (informal logic).
3. Skill: How to analyze complex readings and extract the most relevant information.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In my AI writing course, one of the most valuable skills I developed was the ability to craft effective prompts. I learned how to design and refine prompts in ways that elicit precise, nuanced, and contextually relevant responses from AI systems. This process required a deep understanding of clarity, specificity, and iterative testing to optimize outputs. By carefully balancing openness and specificity in prompts, I was able to generate creative and targeted responses, whether for academic essays, marketing ideas, or research-related tasks.Another critical area of growth was gaining insight into the ethical considerations surrounding AI-generated content. I explored the implications of bias, authenticity, and accountability when using AI tools, learning to critically evaluate outputs rather than simply accepting them at face value. This training helped me identify potential biases in AI-generated text and taught me how to adjust input parameters or address dataset limitations to create fairer and more balanced results. Together, these insights not only enhanced my technical abilities but also strengthened my understanding of the ethical responsibility required in leveraging AI for writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Professor Crespo taught me how to deconstruct arguments and critically analyze research papers. The class AI, Ethics, and Society combines research analysis of AI technology and the philosophical implications of such technology. Professor Crespo does a fantastic job organizing the class to make it approachable to freshmen without sacrificing challenge and engagement. He is a witty intellectual who can converse on any topic. The three things I took from his teachers were the ability to read research papers, create arguments that follow logical structures, and the reason that AI could potentially have societal impacts through its bias and misuse. Overall, I enjoyed taking the class and recommended enrolling to all my friends considering Writing 101 courses for the Spring semester.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so many new things in this course, especially related to content. I had never taken a course in the fields of AI or ethics in my life, so it was a very new experience, and all the readings gave me new knowledge. Professor Crespo also taught me how to come up with premises, which I had never done in the past, so this was a very helpful new skill. I also learned how to construct effective introductions in detail.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, the instructors played a significant role in facilitating my learning through their collaborative teaching approach and their ability to provide spur-of-the-moment explanations. The collaborative environment encouraged active participation and exchange of ideas, fostering a space where I felt comfortable asking questions and engaging in discussions. Working together with classmates and the instructor to tackle challenges not only enhanced my understanding of AI writing but also helped me see how different perspectives can enrich the creative and technical process.The instructors' spontaneous explanations during class were particularly impactful. Whether clarifying a concept, demonstrating a new tool, or addressing a question in real-time, these moments provided immediate clarity and made the material feel more accessible and relevant. These on-the-spot insights often connected theoretical knowledge to practical applications, which made learning feel dynamic and engaging.For future years, I would highly recommend retaining both the collaborative components and the instructor's adaptability in responding to student needs. These elements created a supportive and interactive learning environment that was essential to my growth in the course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The learning environment for Professor Crespo’s class is primarily an open discussion. We would read over a research paper or passage and discuss our thoughts on it with a set question that Prof. Crespo asked. Most importantly, Professor Crespo encourages thought-provoking conversations through frequent encouragement. He frames difficult questions in a palatable way while explaining confusing concepts if the class appears quiet and stuck.Our daily reading is challenging; instead, it is usually very dense research papers with little lay appeal. Professor Crespo's framing of the entire class as one larger discussion, combined with quick intermissions for explaining ideas, lets students retain information, unlike most other courses I am taking.Lastly, his assignments are about more than just learning the material. For example, he doesn’t create assignments just to help us further understand how AI will affect society through encoded biases. While that is a more significant portion of the class, he creates assignments so that we can focus on a writing concept like argumentation or audience appeal. Combining these methods makes students more knowledgeable about AI ethics and teaches them how to be better writers in a number of fields.I particularly enjoyed his assignment, which involved us writing a Duke Vertices Science Magazine article about a new large language model that we found interesting. The assignment made us consider our audience, explain concepts with examples while using our words wisely, and research a genuinely exciting topic. On top of all this, some students even published their articles in the school science magazine, which helped them get more involved around campus.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was already very intellectually stimulating. One thing that could make the class more stimulating would be to have more group-oriented projects. It is difficult to include these in writing classes. However, I would hope that, in the future, Professor Crespo could include in-class group presentations or projects related to how AI could affect society.A second thing I would recommend—while ambitious with our limited time—would be adding a class unit on how AI could affect the economy through job loss and other adverse effects. We could also learn how AI is used in schools and whether it is ethical to use things like ChatGPT. There are a lot of areas where the class can be expanded; however, there is also a minimal amount of class time to fit these recommendations. Therefore, I believe that Professor Crespo does a pretty stellar job at including philosophy, societal implications of AI, and more technical research-oriented topics on how AI functions.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you're considering taking this course, I’d highly recommend it. It offers a unique combination of hands-on learning and thoughtful discussion about AI's role in writing and creativity. The course not only teaches you practical skills, like crafting effective prompts and refining AI outputs, but also encourages you to think critically about the ethical and societal implications of AI tools. The collaborative environment is one of its greatest strengths, with opportunities to share ideas, work through challenges with peers, and engage in meaningful conversations. If you're curious about AI and its impact on writing or want to develop skills that blend creativity with technology, this course is a fantastic choice.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would not take this course again if I had to. Benjamin Hojem is a good instructor with good insights on your writing but the way the class is graded terrifies me. If you drop from an A to an A-, there is no way to go back to an A. The grading contract structure does not reward improvement and thus there is no incentive for anyone to put in more than the minimum effort required. The course is not difficult but it is just a lot of work without much learning which makes it boring.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I really learned how to feel comfortable with revising my papers, how to draft a paper that is easily understandable by someone who has no knowledge on the topic, and how to write sort of unconventionally.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to be comfortable with drafting and rewriting through peer reviews and conferences. Additionally, I also learned how to visualize my learning which helped with my creativity. For example, visual activities like the map helped me a lot when writing my academic research paper. Also, I learned how to give constructive feedback to my peers that would actually help them with their paper.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learnt how to capture conversations between secondary sources 
2. I learnt how to incorporate inquiry in storytelling
3. I learnt how to conduct interviews and code the interview data, later integrating it into the essays.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed the mindset of treating writing like an iterative process: the first draft of any assignment won't be perfect, but I shouldn't get too attached to this version as I was taught in this course the necessity of changing things in a draft. I also developed my research skills and how to find and contribute to a conversation/research topic. Finally, I learned about the creative aspects of writing, how creativity fluctuates, and how the writing process is inherently creative.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the writing process and how to use different skills that work best for me to my advantage. Three specific things include the diverging and converging process, the fact that first drafts should only be drafts or a version of the final product, and I learned that all writing in creative writing and that creativity is a skill that everyone possesses.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to practice word economy in my writing, how to combat misogynist stereotypes as a woman in STEM and help close the gender gap in STEM, and how to write an argumentative essay.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was extremely reading-heavy, so I definitely learned a lot of useful skills and techniques from the authors we were exposed to.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned how to think introspectively as well as with a very wide perspective on the world and society. The lense through which I was required to think under was challenged in many ways. I was also encouraged to speak more in class and engage in conversations about our readings. As someone who typically does not enjoy participating in class discussions or public speaking, I feel as though this course led me to engage in discussions more frequently. Through that, I felt more confident speaking in front of my peers and the professor. Another skill I learned that is specific to writing was the practice of simplifying ideas and sentences in order to create more effective sentences.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to write effectively, read efficiently yet thoroughly, and I learned how to participate in a discussion setting.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor and the aspects of the course helped facilitate my learning by allowing for the students within the class to share their opinions and perspectives regarding the content and readings of the course. Due to this being the main structure of the course, it allowed me to understanding others perspectives regarding the different topics we discussed and learn more about the content overall from their outside knowledge their brought to the class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor was very patient when answering questions and took the time to explain in detail. He is also very passionate about this course which is admirable. I would keep the reading quizzes however the readings should be a bit shorter.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Caleb was very passionate about the course material, and the reading quizzes helped me hold myself accountable for completing the readings before each class. I also really liked having many smaller activities throughout the semester that built up to writing our final research paper at the end.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Although the course was insightful, I must say that the way it was structured was relatively poor. We would go weeks without writing (which was unexpected for a Writing 101 course) and be assigned extraneous amounts of reading in that time instead. After a while, we would be assigned extremely heavy writing assignments, to compensate, and be given a very short amount of time to complete them. Additionally, the topics we were meant to write 1,000-3,000 words about, were often unrelated to the concepts we spoke about in class and seemed very disconnected from the course, making them difficult to write. For instance, one assignment that the class believed to be irrelevant was a twelve page annotated bibliography, one page describing each source, and then a two page commentary connecting the material. On it's own, the assignment sounds reasonable, however, the relevance to the class material was minimal and seemed as though we were prioritizing reaching a word limit rather than engaging with the content. It is important to note that after being submitted, this bibliography was never referenced again. In comparison to other Writing 101 classes, this course was far more demanding and did not align with the experience of my peers. Overall, the concepts learned in this course were interesting, however, its structure was incredibly confusing, and at times I questioned the relevance.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Caleb, the professor for this course, made sure to make all students feel welcome, understood, and comfortable. I never felt as though I was in a space where I could not say my opinion in this class. He also made everyone feel included as he would often bring others into the conversation and be sure that everyone's voice was heard at least once throughout each class period. Although, this may be nerve racking for some students at first, I think this style of teaching is necessary to create a comfortable and engaging environment. I would recommend that this teaching style be promoted as it leads to a comfortable and proactive classroom environment.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor was engaged in the material himself and was very passionate to teach and discuss the topics. He was also very knowledgable on the topics. He was also happy to help and give feedback when needed. He was able to work with me through problems and obstacles that were not expected to come up.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Three specific things which I learned was about genre, voice, and the rhetorical situation. We learned about how genre is a wya which someone writes, and can help connect the audience to the writer. Voice is the way in which an author writes and incorporates themselves in to the article. The rhetorical situation sir the way which the writer responds to some sort of discourse for a certain audience.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed the skills of discerning one academic genre from another, and identifying voice based on the discourse community applicable. Also, I learned how to make an effective poster that readers can learn from without having to spend extended periods of time asking clarification questions. Finally, I learned about the issues of accentism and native-speakerism which is a prevalent form of discrimination for multilingual people.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed my knowledge of language and its relationship with outward identity, such as how our voice can be used to reflect our identity. From this, I also developed skills relating to the analysis of academic writing because of the course-assigned readings. Lastly, I learned about the prevalence of accentism and how in certain places the way you talk determines how people view you in society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The course is wonderful-- there are three main papers that are graded on a rubric, and all have interesting topics. The first two help you introspect about yourself, your identity and where you came from. The last assignment helps you engage with more 'academic' forms of writing. Dr Tan is a fair grader, easily accessible, and a very knowledgable woman; she gives great feedback and is ready to help you in any way whatsoever. For an international student, this is the perfect writing course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say that overall, the class isn't too hard. You have to put time into it out of class in order to keep up with the homework and the class, but overall wasn't too much. The professor made sure not to assign too much reading between classes, and the daily writing was not bad either. On average, between each class, we had to read about 5-20 pages of an articles and then respond in about 200-500 words. I think that the course is interesting if you like thinking about language and linguistics. However, the title of the course is a bit misleading because we mostly talking about language and identity, but not power.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The real topic of this course is more along the lines of, "experiences of a second-language speaker, academic discourse, and genre reviews."

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how talk about my feelings and emotion, the ability to be vulnerble, and my writing skills had been improved a lot.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about myself and gained some key insights about not only the way I feel about myself but also the way others feel about themselves. One way of thinking I learned was a "me" sandwich in writing, in which writing about myself would involve a paragraph sandwiching a quote in the middle, between starting and ending sections about myself. This method is applicable to other topics of interest as well, since it increases the focus of a piece of written work on the topic itself. One skill I developed was the ability to portray a story in an effective blend of showing and telling. This is not only important for this class, but also highly important for communication in the real world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned that writing can be a helpful tool rather than something scary. Before coming to Duke, I had a bad perception of writing. I did not have the best experience in writing my college application. After Sheryl's class, I can acknowledge that I am not perfect, but regardless, my growth is the most important. 
I learned that being vulnerable, even though pointing out the failures, can make you a very strong person. I have become more vulnerable with my classmates and friends. I have learned that sharing how I feel with others is a powerful tool for having healthy mental health and friendships. 
I got the insight of what the best teachers are like. I think it is a privilege to be Sheryl's student. She proved to me how the best of us is sometimes just being ourselves without exactly being perfect; something very contrary to what a lot of people think of Elite Universities. I think what is elite is to recognize what we have, make the most out of it, enjoy it in the moment, and keep facing your fear to grow.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Something so simple yet so profound that Sheryl has taught me is giving myself the "permission to feel." I love that she placed so much emphasis on self-reflection and really thinking about who I am as a person. Sheryl always reminded us of the importance of staying true to who we are and letting ourselves be as unapologetically us. That has been helpful in producing much more authentic pieces of writing.
2. Sheryl always does emotion check-ins before the start of every class, which has definitely taught me the importance of taking a few minutes out of each day to pause whatever I'm doing really think about how I'm doing mentally. 
3. In the middle of class, Sheryl always leads us through a little stretching/yoga break to make sure we're taking care of our minds and bodies, getting some rest, and relieving some stress.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me how to be honest with myself. It would have been easy to lie about how I am feeling and how things are going but because of Sheryl, I have learned how to truly call out my emotions for what they are instead of masking them because it's easier. I have also learned how to be vulnerable and honest when sharing with others. I have found so much help from Sheryl and my classmates all because I decided to be vulnerable. She has also taught me the beauty behind not taking everything seriously. Life is stressful enough, not everything has to be this way.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to write academically/in a literature review style, which I think is a pretty good skill to get exposed to early on, and Professor Spinner is definitely very knowledgeable when it comes to academia and submitting your research. I also learned how to corroborate/contrast certain sources and how to cite them properly, and the process of sifting through a variety of scholarly/peer-reviewed sources and choosing ones that supported my argument.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned how the perception of witches has evolved over time, especially in relation to the feminist movement. First, I discovered how witches were historically viewed as malevolent figures during the witch hunts, but later became symbols of empowerment. Second, I explored how modern feminists have reclaimed witchcraft as a form of resistance and autonomy, challenging traditional gender roles. Finally, I gained a new understanding of how witchcraft can be both a spiritual practice and a tool for reshaping power dynamics, offering women a way to assert control over their lives and identities.

-how to create a personalized grimoire

thinking about meritocracy in a critical way - considering the American dream and social mobility as a whole. is it based on real meritocracy or more so privilege and luck?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Professor Scharnhorst truly helped me to develop my researching skills, teamwork and leadership skills. I feel much more comfortable exploring the Duke Rubenstein archives through her guidance. She taught us how to navigate complex research databases and efficiently sift through different materials to find the most meaningful evidence. I feel like my understanding of the archival system has grown greatly since the beginning of this course!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to effectively cite various sources and give proper credit to the authors and their work, before I found it more difficult to credit the authors properly, now I do it easily and much more effectively than I did before.Through this writing course I also learned the importance of first drafts, how even the most qualified authors struggle to make an incredible first draft. This class taught me how to learn from the failures and edit quickly and to the best of my abilities. It's important to create a format in which you can work off of.Last but not least I learned how to collaborate with many different minds, how to build onto every individual in the group using each other as resources instead of obstacles.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One important thing I learned in this class was the usage of pruning my articles. Before this class I never considered revision to include taking out chunks of your writing but now I see the benefit in minimizing. It helps you to remove possibly irrelevant content. A viewpoint that I acquired was microhistorical. That is, trying to understand big picture concepts by analyzing specific case studies.

We also had an interview project, so I learned a lot of soft skills during that process of interviewing a former Duke athlete.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Three new things I learned in this course included how to best organize information in order to present it in an understandable way, reading primary sources more criticaclly in order to extract more information, and analyzing how point of view and bias may influence certain writers' pieces and how they present their opinions on certain topics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Looking up authors and what other works they have written is something that I don't naturally do the first time I pick up a document, but it is something that I have worked harder towards during this class.
Writing proposals for writing projects is something new to me, but I got familiar with it during this class.
This class also gave me a lot more perspective on the anti-war side of the Iraq War. I hadn't heard too many arguments for the anti-war side before so that was a really interesting perspective to learn about.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I improved my writing skills. I think I was still used to writing "high school" essays and so it was great to learn how college essays are written (for example shorter paragraphs etc)
I definitely improved my knowledge of the Iraq War. Before I knew basically nothing about the war beyond Saddam Hussein. I learnt all about the reasons to go to war, the history behind the conflict, the anti-war movement etc
I also developed a new way of thinking with regards to looking at primary sources. Given that we looked at so many I think my interpretation skills definitely improved.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed the ability to think critically and break down complicated pieces of writing. I also learned how to structure my writing much better than I knew before. I feel more confident articticulating my opinions in front of a group of student.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the DEPICT method, a form of analysis of a text that looks for documents, people, time periods, ideas, etc. This method is a comprehensive way to organize your thoughts. I learned to be critical of the source and for whom a text is being written rather than simply critical of the argument and logic. I learned that I had to be very specific with my insights and not mince words or put words in somebody's mouth.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Research methods involving historical documents, writing strategies for essays, places to get help for writing (academic writing center), in depth knowledge about the Iraq War.

While there are important class readings that provide context for the class, I enjoy that class periods are structured more like discussions than lectures. I feel like I am more engaged this way. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked how much time we were given for everything. We only wrote a couple of papers, so there was a lot of free time between to edit and go through the writing process.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: He would ask questions about the reading and try to get us into a discussion. He would start with just asking for general thoughts and would then narrow down further as we went, always facilitating discussion.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked how for the most part, the class was open discussion as opposed to slide learning or a lecture. We learn best through our peers and I feel that much of my learning in this class is from not only Ethan as my professor but also my classmates.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Ethan facilitated discussions in nearly every class by posing questions about the previous night's reading. I like discussion-based classes, so our conversations helped me learn effectively. I'd keep this discussion-based format.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Our learning was facilitated through the assigned readings we had to do for each class. Then what we read was discussed each class where Ethan (instructor) guided us through the talk with certain questions. There were moments when we didn't know how to answer a certain question and Ethan was able to walk us through that. He also helped us through a process of developing an essay regarding the Iraq War in which there were multiple steps we had to take that I liked. I think positively of the class layout and how we did things.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I love the variety of reading we've done. Arguments for and against the war, voices of soldiers in the war, their families, journalists in Iraq, etc.We should also keep the short responses. We did them twice but I'm not entirely sure why we stopped. I think that was really effective because having to write about the reading means I have to give it a closer read and think about it a lot more.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: My instructor facilitated instruction in several ways. He helped keep the conversation going by always asking questions to spark conversation. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class is stimulating in the sense that it truly forces you to think for yourself. Since most of our class periods are structured as discussions between peers and instructor, everyone has to think for themselves in order to contribute to the conversation. In this way, most, if not all, students in the class are engaged and focused on the topic being discussed by all.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I like the focus on discussion on the readings - it definitely felt very stimulating. However sometimes because of the volume of the reading it felt like we couldn't properly dive into each one, or people had to jog their memory and reread the particular article, by which point we were already on to the next article.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was stimulating because coming in, not that many people knew about the details of the Iraq War, and it felt like as we were navigating through the different opinions we were reading, everyone was learning in detail about this war that was only 20 years ago and still has consequences in todays world.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I found this class intellectually stimulating whenever we'd be in good conversation about the war or US foreign policy.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class was stimulating in that I was motivated to participate in discussions most of the time and to do so I had to actually do the readings and understand the context of what we were discussing. Also, some readings were difficult in their material or I had no prior knowledge of the material in which reading it made it stimulating. I think some moments, the class was not stimulating when I was lazy and didn't feel like talking some classes, and it was very easy to not involve myself in the discussion. Maybe making some discussions more active and having more of a variety of activities would allow people to participate each class.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Our discussions on the reading were very engaging and got me to think about many things I have not thought of before. The short writing assignments and the longer projects made sure that I spent time to develop my own understanding of the war.A classmate brought in his mother, who served in Iraq during the war, for a presentation. We also had Roy Scranton (an author who has also served in the war) come in over Zoom and talk to us. Those were great and made the course a lot more interesting.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: What made the class stimulating was that there was always a different topic to be discussed every class. I can't think of ways of making the class more stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It could be made more stimulating if it was taught like a history course. In reality, this course was a history course, taught like a writing course. In the end, we neither learned about writing nor the Iraq war.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Discussion was stimulating for me because I got to hear everyone’s ideas on the readings for class

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Iraq War, in letters, is an interesting class to take if you are curious about a subject you have not covered before. With a host of readings and spanning decades, the course covers a variety of topics that are designed to stimulate debate and engage the class. Freedom on the writing assignments allows for personal interest to bloom.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If I were to offer information about this course to a student that is considering taking it in the future, I would tell them that it is definitely an engaging class that covers challenging topics. Personally, I was not that aware of a lot of the details surrounding the Iraq War, and thus this class was very helpul for me to learn about an important period in history. I would tell them to keep up with the class readings and do background research as necessary. This is especially important to participating in discussions in the most informed way possible.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Writing is very different at college than it is in high school, so just be prepared for many things to change when you're in this class. It is a fun class to learn this new process in, but it is definitely a big shift.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely do it if you are interested in the Iraq War, or want to learn about it. I myself knew nothing and now come away with a good background knowledge. It's such a fascinating topic in US history. It's not a particularly difficult class if you can do a bit of reading.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would tell them that it is a great writing class to finish your required credit while also learning about something new, especially if you like history. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
-Had us to multiple assignments in prep for larger projects. It got repetitive but it also helped me to determine which ones work best for me. The assignments broke down the larger project into smaller steps and made it much more manageable
-Emphasized that we are human, and that it's okay to ask for help/extensions because she is confident in our abilities and honesty to get work done. Cares about wellbeing of students and their past, and how to get them to access resources now.
-Encouraged us to explore topics that tie our interests back to class content, which taught us how to make gaps between different fields in research

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I cannot recommend this class enough. I loved exploring what it means to be human and what defines "humaneness" and how we use that concept to categorize not only other humans but other species. I never thought of science fiction as being an academic tool before this class and I now think it's the best way to engage with social dilemmas. I also used to have only one definition of academic writing (which was very intimidating) but I now see it in a much better and more inclusive light. My ways of thinking seemed to evolve with each reading and I loved how the assignments weren't comprehensive but rather our own engagement of the concepts (making it much more personal and motivating to complete assignments). Especially with the final paper being my choice, I was able to connect films, songs, and concepts together in ways I never thought of before (and it gave me clarity on what I want to pursue for my major).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to analyze pieces of media using a theoretical framework, how to research and develop an academic writing project, and the process of getting published in an academic journal

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The concept of a 'theoretical framework', how to write in conversation with another text, and how to write academically (with academic structure, annotated bibliographies, literature reviews, APA citations, etc.). I also learned a lot about humanity and what deems someone to be labeled as human.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the process of academic writing, how writers come up with something new to contribute to the field, and I learned about the different sub genres of sci-fi.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: how to apply theories into my writing analysis, process of publishing papers, editing and constructive peer review, really good writing foundations

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a lot of insight into the publishing process and the differences between the humanities in academia and how we might have approached it in grade school. I also enjoyed using examples of sci-fi in popular media to construct very relevant criticisms of power in the real world, which I hope to take with me from the course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Ishmael is simply the best. she's so relatable and down to earth. She encourages new ideas and values student imput on the class format and is very understanding. Most of all she truly engages with you not only as a student but truly pays attention to your work and gives extremely helpful advise and makes sure she is available as a resource to you. She expects you to take assignments seriously but if you take this class I'd assume you wouldn't have a problem doing that.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I especially enjoyed discussing science-fiction from different times/locations and analyzing what they had to say about their respective societies. It was really interesting comparing how different people applied their frameworks in different ways or took different messages from the same media.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The in class film analysis paired with a seminar style discussion of the media was very helpful for me. It taught me skills to better participate in a seminar, and it opened my eyes to other students' perspectives that I would not have thought of on my own.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The lectures were usually helpful, with examples given on how academic writing works. Sometimes it felt like the assignments were just busy work. I like the idea of the final essay being a culmination of all the techniques we learned in class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Had good feedback and cared about us as students and people. She let us write about our interests for final papers so that made it actually really interesting and enjoyable to write about.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the in-class discussion-based learning a lot, especially after we'd watch an episode and read a theory text. I thought it was great to hear my peers' perspectives on how these frameworks applied to the texts.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would tell a prospective student to try their best to understand the readings assigned for homework, but that skimming texts is also really important. I had this previous conception that skimming is lazy, taking short cuts, etc. However, about halfway through the class, Prof Ishmael expressed to us that we should be skimming the readings. That would have saved me a lot of time and stress over the readings.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the premise-conclusion construction of an argument, types of inferences, modus ponens & modus tollens, non-consequentialism & consequentialism, speciesism, animal ethics, longtermism, social discount rate, types of fallacies in writing, AI consciousness, moral considerations of AI, catastrophic risks of AI, and other ethical arguments.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
