question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Emphasis on writing center theory, consulting practices, and personal writing processes. Learned both technical and general ideals surrounding the writing center.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about my writing process and approaches to writing consultations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- I developed an increased awareness of what was actually going on in my own writing process thanks to helpful writing center theory readings like Sondra Perl's "Understanding Composing," and was able to tailor my process to be more helpful. 
- I read the foundational texts of writing center theory and developed my understanding of the purpose and potential of writing centers. 
- I gained a broader understanding of what writing is like for others through conversations with my peers and practice EWC consultations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about understanding writing center theory and specific writing processes that I can pass on and incorporate in my own consultations. I learned to properly read and analyze the texts in this class. I learned to think more openly about the texts, interpreting each point in context of the main theme.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This skill allowed me to debunk stereotypes associated with the writing center, and it encouraged me to be more open-minded about the types of writing that we may be exposed to in the writing center. Through this class I've been able to view writing centers and a writer's identity as a much more nuanced subject.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: A lot was learned in terms of consulting processes and wetting center theory. Seeing as that before taking this class I knew nothing about this, a lot was learned. This could be like research methods, encountering disabilities/learning differences in the studio, language differences, etc.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) Developed a better, fuller understanding of the diversity of writers, and how intertwined writing and identity are
2) How to work with a student's writing, and how to guide them towards being a better writer
3) The writing center is an incredibly undervalued academic resource on campus

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course developed my critical thinking, communication and writing skills, particularly in the form of analyzing writing processes in order to strengthen my own and other skills as a writer.  It was difficult, but through endless readings, practice consultations, writing project and my skills in these fields were grown tenfold.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed my own writing process, my ability to consult others on their academic writing, and further understanding of the importance of writing communities in universities. I became a more skilled writer, procrastinated less on my work, and turned to collaborative settings as I completed writing assignments.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- I learned how to critically analyze writing and writing practices of peers and my own.
- I gained experience as a prospective writing consultant to offer helpful feedback to students for a given assignment.
- I problematized the nature of the writing center, questioning its purpose, goals, and how it may create tension with other parts of the university.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I got into a major deep dive of writing studio work. The first big lesson I am taking away is better understanding my own and others writing composition process. I was able to reflect on what does my writing process look like, what can be added to it, and how does showcasing my work to others fit in that process. Additionally, I learned of a lot of peer to peer tutoring skills. We read literature that make suggestions such as sitting next to a tuttee, having moments for casual conversation, checking in on students needs, etc. which was helpful to ground what my consultation practices will look like. I also learned the importance of continuing to push what a writing studio can mean/look like. This played a role in developing my final project to think of a community engaged aspect of the writing studio.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about consulting strategies, writing studies, and my own writing and learning processes. This course shifted the way I think about being a listener and helped me reconcile the different attitudes towards writing which I have observed in my peers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to navigate the writing center as both a tutor and tutee, while considering how my own backgrounds and others' backgrounds may influence our actions. I worked on strengthening my perception of writing as a process, as opposed to a single act, and on how to communicate that theory with others.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed self-control, reflectiveness, and analytical thinking skills throughout this course. I have been able to withhold myself from taking on a "fix-it" or editorial mindset to writing consulting, thought more deeply about what I am writing about and how it is representative of who I am as a person, and how to be able to dissect and interpret various forms of writing/writing styles/dialects.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr Asmuth as an educator was incredibly effective at building an environment where all students felt comfortable conversing openly and honestly. I truly believe rapport building between students and the educator is such an effective way of facilitating meaningful conversation, and should be prioritized by educators in the future. I also really appreciated the setup of the projects, where we would submit several drafts and also have an opportunity to revise at the end— it really emphasizes all that we were reading about writing as a buildable, fluid, and often reflective process.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Asmuth did a great job of leading interesting class discussions, allowing me to voice my opinions and hear the thoughts of my peers. I also liked the revision element of the course, having to revisit many of my pieces several times and think about ways to improve them.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really appreciated the variety of readings and writing assignments, as well as the opportunity to consult with my peers and with Writing 101 students.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Asmuth, I thought, was quite open about meeting and checking in with us frequently, which I really appreciate. I never felt like I was on my own and they made it clear that they were here as a resource for us.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Asmuth seemed to always be excited to be in class, and consistently provided, thoughtful, helpful, constructive advise which helped me to become a more confident writer, and a better writing consultant.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I love how the class focused on open discussion. Most of our time together was us just conversing about the different works we had read for this week with Dr. Asmuth asking prompting questions and encouraging us to further our ideas. I also loved the freedom Dr. Asmuth gave us to simply troubleshoot consultation practices, work together to work on our writing assignments, walk outside for small groups conversations, and more. I think this really allowed us to grow more independent and collaborative as writers.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Asmuth facilitated my learning by being flexible and accepting of all the different types of work submitting, still offering constructive feedback that would later help me develop my midterm and final portfolios. They paid attention to the details and left meaningful comments on each assignment, which helped me improve as a writer. The structure of the course with all of the readings, discussion posts, and writing assignments really got me thinking and fostered communication with my peers about our various reactions to writing center philosophies.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I found the general pacing of the course to be fair, though at times the deadlines felt very strict (for example, having the consultant philosophy project due a week after the major deliverable project meant I was not able to put as much time and care into the former as I would've liked). The structure of the class itself, the weekly reflections and the four major projects felt reasonable, and I understood why we were doing what we were doing at any given point. The readings all felt relevant, if not a bit tedious to analyze, and a student's mileage may vary regarding their interest/engagement with the content.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: While the weekly reading reflections were a bit of a pain at times, it was really helpful to complete as the specific questions that I needed to respond to ensured that I thoroughly read the week's readings. Additionally, the reflections came into play for the major assignments as I was able to reflect on and reference the reflections- making me feel like the reflections deep dives were worth it. I did like that we would be paired up with different people throughout the course of the semester- it made sure I could get to know my peers better and that I could interact with different perspectives on my work.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Asmuth was very proactive and often reached out with advice or actively encouraged us to seek help from them, which was reassuring because I did find this course to be challenging. I liked the collaborative discussions we had in class as well as how we built upon and synthesized the readings into our personal philosophies. I also liked that we had built in consultations to gain actual experience, as those helped me build a lot of confidence.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Asmuth was a very, very helpful resource and guide throughout the course, and I truly felt like they were so encouraging and wanted me and every other student to succeed. Having all of the potential consultants take this class is smart for ensuring we're all on the same page pedagogically, but it also allowed me to meet and get to know many of my future coworkers. I thought having to revise and submit multiple drafts (a first draft, a second for professor comments, and a third in the midterm and/or final portfolio) was a strong choice that encouraged me to actually set aside time to draft and revise.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

response_text: This course may not be the most riveting, but if you want to be a writing consultant, you'll have to grin and bear it.

response_text: I've learned a lot from Writing 255 and I definitely do feel prepared to be a writing consultant at the writing studio. The workload for the course was heavier than I initially expected with weekly readings and reflections on top of developing different components for a portfolio you turn in at the end of the semester. I definitely do think it's doable, but the work should be spaced out to not be overwhelmed on weekend nights like I sometimes found myself. The concepts do apply to anything that you are studying/thinking of doing so I'd recommend!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Especially if you haven't really engaged with writing studies prior to this course, it can be a very challenging but rewarding experience.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class will teach you a lot about writing, and it will ask you to reckon with your own perception of writing as well as how you implement collaboration in writing. The readings are sometimes long, but I generally felt like every assignment was leading me towards learning something new.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take the time to practice what you are reading-- the future writer who comes to you is depending on it for an effective consultation! Don't be afraid to tie outside interests to the class as well (e.g., STEM concepts and practices, creative writing, etc).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Prior to this course I had heard about writing studies, but never understood why it is difficult to categorize writing as "good" or "bad". This course helped me understand why writing is a personal process and is not as linear as taught in high school. Additionally, I learned how writing can have social and historical implications, such as the acceptance of AAVE and empower groups such as L2 writers and international students.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. What are discourse communities 
2. How to be a consultant 
3. Educational pedagogies

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class, I have learned many strategies for peer review and tutoring. I have also become familiar with the philosophy of writing centers, explored the discourse of peer instruction, and developed my own philosophy on the matter.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Learning how to make writing your own via translingualism
2. The importance of identity and perspective on writing
3. Negotiating meaning and how to challenge standardized writing practices

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about writing studies as a field and how writing studio philosophy has changed over the years. I also enjoyed readings specifically learning about L2 writers and neurodivergent writers. Learned how to lead writing consultations.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Yan made herself available throughout the entire semester. She was always easy to contact and her patience with the class made me feel comfortable asking for help, and expressing when I didn't understand the material.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the peer editing and discussion posts.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I believe that the papers we wrote furthered my understanding of key concepts.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Being in such a small classroom environment (5 students total), I felt that everything that I said was always heard and valued by not only my teacher but also my classmates. My professor helped foster a learning environment in which everyone was able to share their beliefs and ideas without fear of judgement or disapproval. I think that keeping this course under 15 people is ideal.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Li gave thorough and timely feedback and was very approachable.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It felt as if the material was very niche and didn’t apply much to the real world.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The literature was interesting and challenged my perspective.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think this course was stimulating for me because I was able to mold the class into what I wanted it to be. Since we were able to take a in-depth look at topics that interested us personally, I chose to focus my research on something that was very close to my heart and a passion I wanted to pursue. Being able to make the class your own is a characteristic that kept me engaged, even when our general class topics did not.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It would also be nice to know what are expected grade is before the last day of classes. Even though we get to submit and evaluation defining our given grade, we have no idea if this will be supported by the professor because even our midterm portfolio was not given a letter grade. If the class is going to be ungraded until the last day, it would be nice to see estimates of what grade assignments would be given if they were not marked for completion just to keep track of our own progress in the course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is more than preparing to become a writing consultant. This course is more about "the history and application of writing".

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Only take this course if you are truly interested in education and writing. It’s a very small niche and will feel boring if you don’t find the material engaging. The course is not worth taking if you’re just doing it to becoming a writing consultant. In order to be a writing consultant at Duke you have to come to school a week early for a training program.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Get work done before the deadlines. Make a calendar of what you need to do.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Talk to people that have taken the class before! The workload gets to be a lot so really choose a research topic you're genuinely interested in. Even though I don't like writing, I would still recommend this course to people if they want to explore writing more. In my experience, this course was very make it your own so I made it interesting out of what may have not been very interesting. Don't just take the course to become a writing consultant because the amount of writing you'll be doing isn't worth it if you aren't interested.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is a lot of work and time-consuming, especially for a class that can't be anyone's highest workload class, as it's advertised as a bridge to being a writing consultant, not as much of an education pedagogy course. The assignment descriptions were very broad, so it was hard to understand exactly what was expected.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Developed skills to be effective writing consultant in the future and learned a lot about Writing Center Theory and the Writing Studio.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a better understanding of writing center pedagogy, tutoring practices, and different forms of writing in the academic discipline.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to synthesize information separately from the resources (connect them with topics outside of the course), self-reflect meticulously on my progress in a course, and the inner workings of the writing center and their tutors.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about writing pedagogy, the function of a writing center, and how to successfully conduct writing consultations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot more about the specific challenges certain students face (students of color, students with learning differences, students who speak other languages) both in the writing center and outside of it, I learned what the purpose of the writing center is, I also learned how to be a better consultant and I learned how to be more sensitive to other people's needs and go with the flow.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Coming into this course, I had no idea that there was such a thing as writing center theory or scholarship, let alone the depth of the research and how impactful it is on the mission of the Writing Studio. In this class, I learned about the history of the writing center and its development as a center for collaboration rather than just as a place for grammar revision. I also gained the hard skill of learning how to actually give a writing consultation and use the software. Additionally, I learned a lot about diversity and how people's backgrounds, communities, and language acquisition impact their writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to conduct a writing consultation, I learned about current debates and discussions in writing center scholarship, I gained experience writing a literature review which I had not done before this course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned a lot about the importance of environment when doing a writing center consultation. Beforehand, I did not realize how intentional writing centers need to be in establishing an effective physical enviornment as well as being intentional with your words and techniques for each individual student, in order to ensure an effective consultation. I also gained a lot of new insights about how to effectively interact with students from various backgrounds as well as effectively communicating with students that have various learning disabilities. Lastly, I learned a lot about how writing studios developed their ideologies when determining which services they will and will not use, in order to ensure that students grow as writers.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The structure of the class makes a lot of sense. The class is far more reading intensive than I was expecting but it all played a role in the outcome of the class. The writing assignments were confusing in that we received great feedback on them but didn't receive a grade for them. I didn't love the idea of self-grading our final grade in a portfolio. I would have preferred to revise the formal writing pieces and just received a grade for them.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I did like that we approached our understanding of writing centers and our own writing journeys in different ways through assignments, reflections, and discussion posts. I also think it was helpful to be discussing topics in class and then working on assignments on the side that had direct applicability to readings we would do.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The practice consultations with the students were the most helpful part of the course. It felt like I was putting together all of the discussion and practicing for something that I would do in the future. I would like to keep the resource discussion, but I would like it if we were able to discuss more (as most of our discussions were cut-off from a lack of time).

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: She always made sure that we were engaged with the readings and the material that we were learning through discussion posts. While they were tedious, I think that they were ultimately helpful in keeping a record of what we learned and to have something to go off of for class discussions. I also liked the mix of theoretical learning through the readings and class discussions and more practical learning through our writing consultations. I also really appreciated Dr. Schonberg giving us feedback on our work and her willingness to meet with us!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the in class work time was very valuable (especially our consultations with one another). I also loved being paired up with a W101 class and helping them out--I think it was good for us to meet with students outside of the course to practice what we had been learning. And, even though I only went to her once, I really appreciated having Natalie be our EWC. I thought she was great and I also liked our class meeting with her. I also liked our presentations of our deliverables--it really made me invested in my project.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I found the practice consultations through our pairing with a Writing 101 class to be particularly helpful. It helped to ground a lot of the more abstract theory from our in-class discussions with something more tangible. Plus, it taught me that you have to be willing to be flexible with a lot of the "rules" you learn about how a session "should" look based on the scholarship. It was the one-on-one time with the student that I feel has best prepared me for the work I'll do next semester.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The most helpful part of the course for me was doing consultations with Dr. Li's students. I think writing practice and real consultations put me at ease about the process and were great educational tools for me. I also think class discussions on readings were very interesting.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I like that our readings seemed to build on each other from week to week. It was interested comparing the claims of our new authors to texts we've read in the past. I also like the balance that we had between older and new texts.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: We had readings to conduct and also incorporate those ideas into our own pieces of writing. I would consider the portfolios to be stimulating because unlike other classes, we were really asked to evaluate how our learning has occurred in accordance with the learning objectives of the course.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I thought the course was stimulating, particularly through the readings we did. I liked that we didn't just focus on standard writing center pedagogy but also looked at the ways that race, class, gender, ethnicity, learning disabilities, and a multitude of other factors go into how a student interacts with writing and the writing center more broadly. However, I do wish we had more time to discuss the readings as it often felt like we did a lot of work on them outside of class and only got to talk about them for a brief period. I also had hoped we would get a bit more class time to discuss/work on writing assignments to get clarification and not feel so overwhelmed.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I learned more about writing education than I thought there was. I think the level of intellectual stimulation was fine as most of my peers appeared to be gaining new knowledge as well.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The topic was intellectually stimulating because it gave me a solid foundation for how I think about writing, editing, and teaching. It was also very applicable to other aspects of my life, and I like how it equipped me to help some of my friends with their writing. I like how she kept making us think about how what we learned in class could be practically applied.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think the readings were very stimulating, especially because I often found them challenging and really had to dig in to what they were saying to understand them. Especially considering we were in class for 2 1/2 hours, I think maybe there could be some more physical activities (like Ariel's embodied learning).

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Please forgive me if this is insensitive, but I don't know if there's a way to make writing center theory particularly stimulating, for me at least. Given the nature of the information we were learning, I think this class did the most possible to make it engaging, and I enjoyed our in-class discussions, but writing center theory can only be so interesting.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Class discussions were interesting and reading responses made me question all of the readings critically. I was allowed to take issue with ideas and engage in civil debate and discussion. I do wish that more perspectives were presented, however. And I think the course could benefit from more real experience in consultations and more focus on the concrete experience of being a consultant rather than just the scholarship which does not always help concretely in sessions.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think that our discussion sessions kept the class stimulating, as well as our readings on current events like AI in writing. I would have enjoyed if we had more interaction with modern writing studios. For ex., guest speakers from our writing studio, zoom meetings/presentations by people that interact with other writing studios, watching videos about other modern writing studios, reading modern studies about writing centers, etc.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is really enjoyable because you get to write on things that interest you, and you are supported in the ways that you need to be. I would say, however, that the turn around for assignments is quite quick, and if you haven't had great experience with research papers, this is going to be a learning curve. However, I don't want to deter anyone from taking this course because I am very excited about being a writing consultant and the opportunities that it will offer. As long you complete your work to the best of your ability, you will grow as a writer and be successful in the class. I thoroughly enjoyed this class and would take it again.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: While this class was very valuable and I learned a lot, it definitely forces you to work really hard and can be overwhelming at times. Before taking it, make sure your other coursework will allow you to put a lot of time and energy into this course. There will be a lot of hours put in outside of class to get everything done.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: There's quite a bit of theory involved than actual consulting practices. Be prepared to read, spend adequate time on homework every week, and self-reflect meticulously. It is a class where you need to manage your time well with other classes.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you're passionate about the subject and want to work in the Writing Studio, I highly recommend this course! It taught me a lot, but I do think that the course is a lot more work than expected, so just be prepared for that. Overall, though, the work is manageable, and Dr. Schonberg is very understanding of our role as students.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course was very work heavy--do not take it if you will be taking a lot of other writing classes I would reconsider taking this one. Dr. Schonberg is a really good teacher but it takes up a lot of time outside of class. Also be sure that you are ready to argue for a grade--the class is almost entirely self graded.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be ready for a lot of reading and writing and writing about writing. To succeed in this class, you have to be prepared to spend time writing on things that you might find abstract or not particularly interesting, but the practice consultations and time spent working with students is incredibly rewarding.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you want to be a writing consultant, this course is a prerequisite, and I think it is definitely worth it. I wouldn't give up on being a writing consultant out of fear for the workload in WR 255. But know it is a lot of work (reading and writing), so don't expect it to be low commitment. I can also see how this course may be difficult or frustrating if you are not very liberal politically--just keep in mind going in, you may not buy into all of the ideas presented in this course. I do think the overall leaning of the course fits within a very specific "university woke-ism" that may not be palatable to some. But you are allowed to share different ideas as well as your reservations about the scholarship openly. And when it comes to your individual research paper, you can select the topic, so you can choose anything that interests you within the realm of writing center and literacy scholarship more broadly.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I think this course would be great for any student that hopes to one day engage with teaching, tutoring, or writing consulting. I also think it is a good fit in general for students that wish to grow as writers or would like a space to do more self reflection as a writer. The assignments in this course are not difficult, but the workload is not small. There is a lot of reading involved. The teacher is very understanding and nice, so it should be a great learning experience overall.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Theoretically, we learned about the history and different discourses surrounding writing centers. Practically, we got to be paired with a Writing 101 class and practice consultations during the semester.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed the ability to hold Writing consultations through the Writing Center, and learned how to best guide students towards their full potential. I also learned how to better cater my writing to the individual professor given what arguments they are looking for.

response_text:

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned more about writing center studies. I have developed practical skills in writing consultations, and I have learned more about my own writing and perspective I bring to a writing consultation.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: In class discussions and conversations reflecting how consultation turned out + consultations opportunities really helped.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The discussion posts were very helpful to look back on and assess my progress throughout the semester. I enjoyed the resources and support provided in our research process, as well.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The in-class discussions.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Enjoyed the deliverable presentations but would love if we could make the rehearsal section shorter.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class introduced me to new ideas about writing center studies and consultations that I did not know before. I think most of the readings and assessments challenged me to think about things in ways I had not before.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Even though it is the course you are required to take to become a writing consultant, it would exceed your expectations.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Think about whether you really want to spend a semester studying writing center theories and putting in the work. Do not take this class just because you like the thought of being a writing consultant, think about if you're going to be interested in reading writing center theory.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared for a lot of readings, and a few comprehensive assignments, but also to learn valuable teaching skills and be prepared for a job you will be able to perform at in the future of your semesters at Duke.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: As long as you stay on top of your readings and weekly assignments, the class is very informative and helpful for students wanting to work in the writing studio.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The best class I've taken at Duke - learned things that are hard to articulate into words, but it was a life-changing experience. The group-based discussion allowed learning to emerge naturally, rather than forcing specific learning guidelines for the course

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to think about dialogue in a way others outside of this course typically would not, in that dialogue is an aleatory, unprecedented, and irreproducible interaction between people. When engaging in dialogue, instead of trying to hold onto the past or focus on the unrealized future possibilities, I should live fully in the present moment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned to view conversation as an anabolic mechanism towards new thought. I previously thought that talking was simply an exchange; I now know this is false.
2) I learned how to be present. My mind is constantly in a different place than my physical body but speaking in the present and engaging in dialogue with such a fascinating group of students showed me what it meant to be "here and now."
3) I learned a lot about "local knowledge." I didn't really get what this meant at the beginning of the course. However, after discussing what we do in class to someone outside of class, I realized I knew nothing about my classmates except who they were to me within the class -- locally.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned how to conceptualize and further explore the relationship between what someone says aloud and what they mean. We learned vocabularies and theories and developed our own to understand the significance of pieces of a conversation to dialogues as a whole, and to group dynamics as a whole.We learned to structure our class through consensus and group decision-making, sharing our priorities with others and reaching a class environment most helpful to achieving our aims in the dialogue laboratory.We learned how to approach the world dialogically, respecting the dynamics created by the perspective of others and forces in the world beyond our control.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned new ways to think about communication, new practices to develop better communication, and how to pursue new ways of group reflection.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Learning the meaning of kairos, interpretations of authenticity, other methods and terms pertaining to dialogue. 
2. Seeking dialogue in a different sense, learning to enter someone else’s “universe” and how to create a multiverse with your peers.
3. Learning about one’s own goals and how to advocate for progression and learning.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- I developed my skills with dialogue and communicating with people in the moment.
- I learned how to complete lab reports and analyses on small social group. 
- How to improve impact while speaking

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: - present thinking, understanding how I was using language, and education outside of the banking model

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class was essential in the development of my dialogue and analysis skills, which will have wide implications for the rest of my academic experience at Duke. Not only that, but it facilitated an environment that championed social bravery and growth over comfort. I would also add that this class was so radical in design that it forced me to reevaluate my understanding of education as a whole, applying critical theory to the institutions that we hold in such high regard.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: My instructor created a detailed section covering each concept discussed in class. He organized the information clearly and concisely, providing access to all assigned readings, which facilitated our learning progress. This organized scheme enabled me to efficiently track my learning.He offered us the chance to create our own class structure. From the first day, he taught us how to develop our own teaching methods. Gradually, he relinquished his authority as a teacher, allowing us to become both students and teachers simultaneously. This experience taught me creativity and hopefulness.In this course, I learned to be socially aware and humane. David emphasized how dialogue is the cornerstone of human connection and growth. A key concept, the I-Thou method by Martin B., was central to the course. It involves understanding the navigation (words) between different universes (people's minds) and their collisions (dialogue). The course showed me that dialogue is about being sensitive to those around us, a process of discovering and creating with a person rather than labeling them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Local knowledge, love for David Landes, knowledge of dialogue theories

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course is an anti banking model of education where a lot of the learning comes from class conversation accompanied by readings and resources provided by the professor.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: David created an incredible learning environment that allowed me to grow through the experiences, thoughts, and ideas of others. Keep the format just the way it is!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The fact that there was no strict written exam or quizzes, nor list of things to memorize or lecture materials to study made the course a lot more liberating to experiment in ways that facilitated genuine learning.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor facilitated my learned by being very unconventional in his teaching style. This was a refreshing respite from the monotonous learn, study, test of a typical Duke course that made me genuinely excited to both show up for the class and do classwork outside of class. The anarchic structure of the class facilitated my learned because there was no preset content that restricted students from learning what they collectively felt was important. If an unforeseen topic arose, it was welcomed and explored rather than shut down due to divergence from a set plan. Overall, I would say I would keep the methods of instruction the same for future years. However, this is not possible because the structure lay within the body of students that comprises the class and the teacher that comes along with it. So, perhaps keeping the instructor is all that can be done to try and make a class as successful and engaging as The Dialogue Laboratory of Fall 2023.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class's structure was broad and wide open to student interpretation. Dr. Landes created an environment in which we found consensus about our goals in the laboratory together and pursued them as a group of individuals always trying to understand our own motivations and those of others. The course's lack of pre-imposed structure was filled by a group dynamic where we'd explore the parts of dialogue we found most fascinating, which were often influenced by readings we'd do before class.There was a predefined structure to the extent that we'd come to class and converse with each other, share our thoughts and try to understand each other better. Also, Dr. Landes would step into the conversation and try to steer it to match group consensus and address runaway analysis among the group, bringing us back to the emotional basis of the conversation.Overall, the structure was ideal for this kind of laboratory. We'd read the background knowledge required to understand our own goals and to create a mutual understanding about the role of our laboratory in achieving them, and we'd structure class itself around those goals dynamically. This allowed us to pursue the ideas we found most interesting to a much greater depth, and allowed us to pursue our experimental aims free of restrictive class structure.I would keep the entire class structure into the future.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course structure is built to support student interests and needs. I suggest keeping the power in the hands of the students.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the instructor’s method of getting us introduced early on before letting us go on our own helped establish the tone of the course. I think giving the students their own autonomy is the best method moving forward.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This course facilitated my learning by doing away with the banking model and focusing on understanding and shared knowledge. In the future, I would continue with the professors way of choosing weekly readings based off of what the students need.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: By not having a bunch of gimmicks and forcing us to create our knowledge

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: There is very little I would change about this class for future semesters, there is a relevant degree of self-determination in the life of the course, and I have no doubt that with Landes framework future groups of students will be able to change and model the experience to one that they personally can glean the most value from.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Our assignments employed a unique and effective method for teaching dialogue. After each class, we were tasked with creating three distinct reports: a reading reflection, a field report, and a laboratory report. This trilogy was fascinating, as each component required a different set of skills. Reading reflections improved our ability to recall and apply the most personally significant concepts from the readings. Field reports challenged us to apply classroom concepts in our daily lives. The laboratory reports, being the most crucial, helped us understand our individual and collective roles in the specific context and timeframe of each class. Essentially, we discussed the unique or local knowledge we created in our dialogue class.From this class, I learned that the most lasting concepts for the future include: "Pedagogy of the Oppressed," which highlighted learning and teaching as transformational processes and critiqued the current educational system's dampening effect on our desire to transform the world; "Creating Safe Spaces and Brave Spaces," emphasizing the importance of fostering transformation and hope for a better world; "Thought Leaders in Dialogue Theory," demonstrating that the idea of transformational praxis is not only advocated by Davis but has been systematically studied; "Kairos," stressing the importance of speaking at the right moment; "Social Choreography," encouraging a unique perspective on social interactions through spatial organization and people's responses; and "Semantic and Poetic Meaning," contrasting how semantic meaning often falls short in expressing complex emotions like love, whereas poetic meaning can capture these nuances.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The learning environment was left up to the class, and the professor did not force us to do anything. It was an open floor. Anarchy was the word that was introduced to the class on the first day as an adjective for the course.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was extremely stimulating because it relies on the active participation of everyone in the class. It was like a flipped format, where it is taught by the students, which is eye-opening compared to the traditional professor-student format.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The students and professor made this class stimulating. Aside from readings, this class was entirely focused on the people in Social Sciences 109 from 3:05-5:35 every Tuesday. The in-class dialogue was always entertaining because students had the choice to stimulate themselves with whatever dialogue they saw fit for the moment (kairos). However, a lot of my intellectual stimulation actually came from the weekly assignments. It was in these assignments that I did the most self-discovering and produced mind-blowing realizations or connections from both inside and out of the classroom.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was intellectually stimulating because we brought forward curiosities we didn't even know we had, and worked them out with a group of people in the same space as us. We created a group mind that truly tried, and often succeeded wildly, at understanding the feelings underlying our curiosity and addressing those points we were most interested in seeing addressed.These curiosities varied throughout the year, but letting dialogue succeed in bringing them forward meant that they were addressed to almost just the right depth and were constantly the focus of the class. So, for example, this class was intellectually stimulating in that it tested how language choices effected the way others responded to language, and also in how other dialogic choices such as body language tone and positional landmarks created different effects on dialogue. Whatever the specific hypotheses of the class demanded, we explored with one another. We got to see the effect of our interests in action, answering them more holistically. Finally, we refined the skills of approaching others and creating a group mind in action, which is something that can only be learned from experience.Its a very abstract course in some ways, but when the laboratory starts cooking it becomes very real and very personal in a matter of minutes. I think seeing how our abstractions related to real emotions was the most stimulating part of the course.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was stimulating because the learning happened in new forms that were non traditional for the classroom.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think this class was highly stimulating because it, at its core, depends on student participation. As long as the class is actively involved, I don’t see any other methods that would change this.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was without a doubt the most stimulating course I have taken. I believe this is because of the experimental and student driven structure. Every student has their own goals and objectives which makes them more inclined to complete course work.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class makes a proposition to its students that they have lived their entire (measurably successful) lives inside a very rigid definition of education and information transfer; it invites students to recognize and step outside these boundaries to create knowledge together in a more participatory mode of engagement.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I believe that, as this class is part of the arts and performance field, it resembles playing in a theater. The most stimulating aspect for me was the ability to express identity using both an intellectual and humane component. In every session, we were evaluated on a participation basis, which kept our brains active, encouraging us to think critically, openly, and humanely. I am considering taking this class again and feel that every professor should experience it too, as it fosters a sense of connection and applies the concept of 'scinus'—a genius arising from collective thought processes. This class has the potential to transform our rigid and erratic perceptions of growth. It encourages us to think collectively and individually, challenging the notion that society must be entirely individualistic.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The dialogue among the class, and the freedom to mold the class how we wanted to.

response_text: Highly recommended, you learn a lot about dialogue, social interaction, and yourself.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a class unlike any other; it is paramount that you understand and are enthused by that idea because your engagement in the course is the course! This is a great class to take if you want space in your schedule to explore philosophy, rhetoric, and understanding of group dynamics, but it requires you to give something of yourself to it as well.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be open-minded and mature. This class focuses on learning how to brainstorm and create collaboratively. It's pointless if you only focus inward. Engage with ideas and concepts, and train yourself to understand the perspectives of those around you while exploring new ways of interacting with them. Most importantly, set your own expectations for your role in the course. It's a journey of personal exploration, so don't merely mimic others' behaviors. Instead, understand why they act as they do and how this understanding can enhance your interactions with them. Develop your own style; there's no right or wrong. Identify your objectives and be true to yourself.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a very different type of class, and David is very flexible. If you want to take a course that is challenging, and encourages you to talk and build relationships with your classmates take the course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The Dialogue Lab completely transformed how I understand human communication. First, I learned to truly listen - not just to words, but to the subtle layers of meaning, emotion, and intention that flow beneath them. Second, I discovered how a group of strangers sitting in a circle can create an entirely new "collective consciousness" through dialogue, where our shared understanding becomes deeper than any one person's individual thoughts. Finally, and most importantly, I learned that what seems like "just talking" is actually an incredibly complex dance of human connection, where every word, pause, and response shapes not only our conversation but who we become as people.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: HOLY. Look. You learn skills that can't be taught anywhere else at Duke. You get to truly see people, and be seen as a person. It's an entirely different WAY of learning, and it's so challenging but so fun and (imo) much much less stressful than how we've been doing it for all of our lives. You're pretty much guaranteed a good grade as long as you buy in. With that being said, while this class doesn't demand stress, it does demand investment. You have to be present and attentive and willing to be a bit uncomfortable. Try it out!! You will 100% see if you love it or hate it within the first 2 weeks.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: - I learned to see conversations as a way to build meaning collaboratively, not just exchange ideas. I'm an international student, and taking this course with Prof. Landes has given me the language and toolbox to approach everyday conversations as fun toys rather than something we just "do". Notably, I don't think the course gave me "new tools" or "tips and tricks" for having conversation, but rather gave me (1) a space and a community to experiment with and get honest voices and advice about my communication, and (2) a language to explicate what might feel "right" or "wrong" within a conversation and what each action might contribute to a conversation.- I started recognizing that every interaction is shaped by interpretive lenses, helping me better analyze the dynamics at play. This idea was also formed in his past class (WRIT 101) and it plays hand-in-hand perfectly with this class. Two extremely impactful ideas that I continuously repeat to my friends that I've learned throughout my time learning with him were that (1) there is no such thing as an "objective" or "true" lens, and (2) particularities--not generalities--foster the relatability within a narrative/story. Definitely use the language we built in this class over interpretive lenses in my everyday life.- I realized the value of embracing ambiguity and using it to explore deeper, more nuanced perspectives rather than seeking immediate clarity. A lot of the people that come in are CS/Engineering majors that are very used to the dry-cut communication of numbers and fact (self-included). This course (and Prof. Landes' approach) give us a culture shock that "useless" conversations are where true humanity shows up and how people connect.

How to analyze things that happen locally.

2. How to evaluate the significance of an event to another person, and why it is so significant.
3. How to engage in healthy, efficient dialogue.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The circular seating arrangement and lab-style structure of this course was absolutely brilliant - it broke down traditional classroom hierarchies and created this incredible space where we could truly experiment with communication. Landes was more like a skilled facilitator than a traditional instructor, guiding our discussions with light touches while letting us discover profound insights on our own. The weekly "lab reports" were genius because they forced me to process and analyze what happened in our discussions, helping me see patterns and dynamics I would have totally missed otherwise. I especially loved how responsive the course was to our group's specific needs - when we'd hit communication roadblocks or discover interesting tangents, the professor would adapt assignments and readings to help us explore those areas deeper, making everything feel incredibly relevant and personally meaningful.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I've taken WRIT 101 and WRIT267S with Prof. Landes back-to-back. I've had a lot of conversations him inside and outside of the class, and he has definitely earned my full respect over the year or so that I've met him. It's the type of respect that comes when you know someone is *extremely* convinced and in love with what they do and put in the time to understand it and study it well. Once you speak to him and understand the context of his experience in the past, who he taught, his hobbies, you gain more and more of an appreciation to his relationship with the subject. You start to feel like it is his literal baby or "magnum opus". Regardless, Prof. Landes leads the class with the mentality of trying to simply enhance your growth, not particularly direct it. He gives advice and treats people as individuals with separate interests and personalities, which makes the class have a very amplified personality. Some of the advice, experiences, and lessons he has shared with me have even contributed to my personal life in an extremely concrete way. Conversations with him are dense with lessons that are applicable to the class and beyond.As for specific components of the course that stood out to me, the focus away from the usual educational banking model and letting the class direct the conversations of the day is definitely the star of the show for me. Prof. Landes is insanely good at letting conversations happen and only talking when he has to or when it adds to the conversation. I felt a real connection with the class for sure. There is a reason why I felt so strongly about taking this class after WRIT 101--similar feelings were felt in that course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The biggest thing I've learned in this class is how to have more effective conversations. Being able to dissect dialogue on a greater level is something that I think is extremely relevant to any career leaving Duke.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
