question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This course is very cool. You actually learn how to write a screenplay. You start slow and small, with 5- to 10-page short films, and Prof. Bell walks you through the process, so it's not scary. You also read your screenplay in class, and everybody gives feedback. It's vulnerable, but so constructive. You learn so much from your peers in this course. By the end of it, writing an 80-page script is time-consuming, but not super challenging.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Although it was stressful at times, I appreciated the weekly 10-page requirement because it truly pushed me to write, which, in my opinion, is the hardest part. I also liked the reading and casting in class component, which helped me gain confidence and improved my work progress. Watching and later analyzing the movies was also a lot of fun, and I learned a lot from reading scripts while watching them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed many skills and methods of thinking relating to academic writing through this course. We learned about the various nuances of academic writing as a genre in different fields and through a holistic view. The main thing we learned is that academic writing is very much a genre of convention, where scholars tend to follow trends and patterns set by the writers who came before.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: All around a great class with a clear and helpful pedagogy; it is very evident that Dr. Asmuth isn't just someone here to research and teach on the side but is very intentional about making sure kids learn, and that their drive for doing so is backed by a passion for research. response_text: If you are writing or are interested in writing a thesis, this course would be very helpful for you,

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is pretty useful for students who will be writing academic papers, regardless of disciplines.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The class is discussion-heavy and has a decent amount of day-to-day work, but it is an interesting class to take if you are interested in writing a thesis or are interested in learning about academic writing.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Taken two courses with Dr. Asmuth. Super nice professor, very passionate about teaching, and probably one of the best at Duke. There are a lot of assignments, but you will learn a lot later in the semester once you complete all of them.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are working on a thesis as I am, this class is a must! For starters, it held me accountable to finish deliverables for my thesis that had looser deadlines, which was very helpful.  Beyond that, I had fellow classmates stress a lot at the beginning of the thesis class because we were told to write a literature review without many of having learned what a literature review was, but this course had told me exactly what a literature review was and provided me with a myriad of best practices for writing one.  The readings are not too challenging but very rewarding, so do them all.  This class is well worth anyone's time and I expect to use what I learned in this class in job interviews and my future career.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I absolutely loved this course. It was one of the most helpful courses that I took at Duke. However, the class does require a lot of time commitment, averaging around eight hours of work per week. I would definitely recommend taking this course if you are looking to improve your writing skills and learn how to write a good research paper. The amount of feedback you get on all your work will drastically improve your writing skills. Additionally, Dr. Asmuth is very clear with their expectations, meaning that it is possible to do well in the course if you put in the work. The grading criteria is detailed and you will not receive a bad score with no justifications.I would not recommend for you to take this course if you are looking for an easy writing credit.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class, I learned that personal points of views must be considered when writing an argument in order to understand engagement with your text. I also learned about a "legend of cautions" which can account for these potential misinterpretations. Finally, I learned to consider writing a laborious practice that requires exercise like muscles in order to improve.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned that in the pursuit of change, it is important to have a variety of perspectives informing your own perspective. I learned that literature can be a powerful way to reach people and craft narratives that can appeal to the betterment of humanity. I learned that the complexity of backgrounds, experiences, and identities of mine influence so much of where I am at and the causes that I fight for as well as the way in which I fight for those causes.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Power in silence - Marginalized groups may choose to use silence as a tool and that silence can be equally as healing as speaking out. 
Understanding an audience - Adopting different styles to express rhetoric to different audiences, i.e. scientific articles may not be as effective with everyone, even if it is "the fact." Not every style is for everyone. 
Subject positions - Acknowledging how our backgrounds lead to some of the perspectives we have and the way we express them, but also recognizing how those can be misunderstood by individuals with different subject positions and how to bridge that gap.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
-I learned about the imperfect nature of human communication and the iterative nature of change. I at times overthink and over-intellectualize the process of making change without practicing it. Thus, this course allowed me to recognize that theorizing about change-making, while helpful, must translate into action, and that problems will inevitably arise throughout rather than require solving prior to action.
- I learned about the power and implicit rhetoric and strategy in silence, loudness, voice, invisibility, visibility, and physical space.
- I learned about the nuance and complexity of certain rhetorical strategies as not inherently all good or all bad, but as more or less effective depending on context and audience.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I feel more pressure when I'm writing right now, but in a good way. I push myself to be careful when writing for social change. Because people can easily misunderstood your point of view if you are not being specific and crystal clear.
2. I'm now equipped with tools I can use when writing for persuasion: genres, rhetorical methods, audience, etc are all useful concept I learned and mastered during this class
3. I learned how to use forms besides writing (maps, multimedia, poster) to complement writing in helping with social change.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The use of a wide breadth of media for discussion and reflection, along with diverse methods of engaging with them in class were excellent. I also enjoyed how small the class was, it allowed us the time to get to know one another and our unique points of view.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This course was absolutely amazing, but even more so, the professor who taught it was the key to how amazing it truly was. Professor Corey creates a space in which students can creatively approach the projects, assignments, and prompts posed to the students. The feedback that Professor Corey provides is constructive, encouraging, and considers a variety of perspectives in order to bolster arguments, broaden horizons, and improve writing skills. Professor Corey also leaves room for students to be people; whether being gracious with extensions, setting an atmosphere where it's okay to say the wrong thing and learn from it, or even being honest about her own boughts with life and relating to our struggles as students, Professor Corey brings a much needed degree of relatability to the way in which she engages with, discusses with, and instructs students.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Two specific components come to mind. The first is additional labors, which at first seemed really daunting based on the syllabus, but slowly became an outlet to express new ideas and styles of writing. I enjoyed doing the additional labors because it felt like a way to apply some of the things we learned in class, almost like a "checkpoint." Also, the inclusion of documentaries and other styles like art styles, etc. was useful, especially since it equipped us to look at rhetorical choices beyond just word choice, tone, etc. Another thing I liked was the walk and talks. I feel like it is very easy to think about real-life applications inside a nice classroom, but being outside and actually looking at the built environment helps put that more into perspective.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course structure and it full-circle trajectory allowed me to reflect on my learning and growth process throughout the semester. The assigned readings and multimedia assignments further enabled rich class discussions relevant to this historical moment. Professor Corey always facilitated discussions that challenged us to consider new ways of thinking about and approaching certain rhetorical strategies and narratives. I also appreciated the opportunity to engage in creative practices during class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really like the walk-and-talk discussion because it really prompts more interaction between people and people and also people and the environment. I definitely feel more talkative and inspired when walking.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Learning of various rhetorical tools and methods and seeing how those are utilized by authors making their case through, writing, film or art.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The content and discussion of said content was especially stimulating; there was so much that we covered in one semester and everything seemed to build off of each other. I would have loved to talk about speeches, but I appreciating getting to analyze my own in my additional labor. The additional labors and grading contract situation is awesome! I love an opportunity to push myself in my skills outside of what is generally required of me in the course. I also really enjoyed the projects; THEY ARE ALL SO GOOD, INFORMATIVE, AND ENGAGING!!!! I also appreciated that we did not have to write responses for the materials we covered; it gave me the chance to dive deep into the readings and films without feeling stressed about having to rush through them in order to complete some assignment attached to it. Maybe completing in class responses could be cool though for accountability purposes!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The small class size made discussions really interesting, especially as the semester went on and everyone got more comfortable. It was nice being able to hear everybody's opinions and insights. Also, it really felt like the class was tailored to fit a lot of the interests, curiosities, etc. that we may have had throughout, which in my opinion, made it all the more interesting.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

response_text: It's a work-intensive course, but the reward is definitely worth it. It can be hard to find source and stressful at times, but in the end its shaped my efficiency writing and allowed me to employ new tools.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are at all interested in journalism, take this class. It's hard, and the assignments can be frustrating and time consuming. But when you reflect back on what you accomplished over the semester and what you learned, you'll realize how much this course forced you to grow.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is an amazing course where you will learn a lot about journalism and truly come to appreciate it. Start your stories early!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be ready to take a class that will show you the ins and outs of the journalism field from an experienced professional, while also practicing your own craft.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The course could be interesting as an elective, but as a core class that teaches you how to write, it's unhelpful. Professor Adair is a nice guy who is an incredibly experienced journalist, but spends more time talking with guests or about his own stories than teaching you how to write. If you already know how to write and have lots of time and connections off campus, then you'll enjoy the course. If not, you'll struggle and reach the end of the class without feeling a sense of improvement.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you don't have any experience writing news stories, get some before you join the class. As someone who has written for the Chronicle, I can say that there is a huge disparity between outcomes for students who have this and students who don't.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Just do the work. The course is pretty straightforward, Bill's advice/assignments are pretty straightforward, just make the time to do what is required of each assignment and any student will be fine. Bill gives super comprehensive feedback as well, which is helpful.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The class is a great introduction to reporting, and it mostly involves four major assignments. However, be prepared to need to go off-campus for the assignments (you'll need to be really creative to come up with ideas for stories that cannot involve Duke).

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Come ready to learn about journalism, become a better writer, and get introduced to a whole new world. Start learning about current affairs now! Start consuming media if you already don't. And read read read, anything, really.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a fantastic course to take if you are interested in exploring journalism or want to gain the fundamental skills in writing and reporting.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is a great introduction to news writing and reporting (as the name suggests). Coming into the class, I thought myself an experienced writer and had taken a journalism elective, but I realized throughout this semester how little I knew. I benefited greatly from lectures on interviews, structure, and story types, and I can say my writing and journalistic style has changed for the better!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a great course to take if you are considering journalism or simply want to grow as a writer! The skills you gain from speaking to people, learning about different issues in Durham, and learning how to structure a strong story can be applied to anything. Bill is super accessible and genuinely wants to help all of his students succeed. He gives extremely thorough and thoughtful feedback.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to control my voice, control my body language, and structure an understandable speech

response_text: Before this course I was terrified of public speaking, however, Prof. Byerly transformed my mindset and fostered a sense of confidence in me. I learned how to convey the main points of my speech/message effectively and I developed rapport with the audience.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned more in this class than almost any other at Duke. I learned so many fine points about how to become a stronger, more confident public speaker, such as learning to speak without notes. I also learned how to take notes on other peoples' ideas in a way where I can retain more and listen more intently. Finally, I got so much better at using pauses effectively in my speeches.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. how to prepare a speech
2. how to speak in public well
3. how to take good notes

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the difference between memorization vs. knowing the structure of what I want to say, and how much more valuable the latter is. Through the "quotations" section of our final portfolio, I developed a deeper appreciation of keeping my ears open and being present in the moment to hear things that stick with me or make me think. Finally, I learned some physical strategies to combat nerves when speaking in public.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Overall public speaking tips, effective speech writing, speaking advice for certain types of common speeches

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much from this course. I learned how to communicate with others effectively, learned how to control my voice, learned how to address an audience, learned about different styles of speeches, and overall learned so much about my classmates and their lives.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned techniques for managing speech anxiety, I learned strategies for effective speech presentation, and I learned tips for communicating more effectively (varying intonation and speed, maintaining eye contact without losing my place, memorizing ideas rather than words, etc).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Speak more slowly, outline a speech, listen to speeches more constructively.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Ingrid is arguably the most thoughtful professor I've had at Duke. She cares so much about each student and harbors a beautifully constructive learning environment. She does a good job of having us ready to give most stand up speeches in class, while also keeping us on our toes for a few unknown talks. I wouldn't change a thing.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Byerly facilitated our learning by gently yet firmly challenging us to improve, even if that was in front of the entire class. The result of this open, honest classroom environment was that we had a space where we all felt comfortable to share with each other and be honest in our feedback with each other. I would certainly keep the TED talk assignment, as it was challenging and a great way to combine the various topics we had been discussing in the class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Practicing our speaking every week and getting feedback in front of the class was so helpful. I also enjoyed listening to the Ted talks every week. Taking handwritten notes was also so powerful in a way I didn't initially expect.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I would definitely keep Professor Byerly as the teacher for this course indefinitely. She is amazing and really cares about her students and gives each person personalized feedback. The structure was very well-thought, with the portfolio perfectly encapsulating everything we've learned and should've learned in this class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The assignments were well structured. There were a variety of speaking formats and there were consistent opportunities to practice speaking. The textbook summaries were helpful practice for learning to summarizing ideas quickly and succinctly. And the assigned Ted Talks not only provided good examples of public speaking, but shared a variety of powerful ideas that could be applied to life in general. The TED talk assignment was a great final assignment to end the class with.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You get out of it what you put into it. There are a lot of opportunities for public speaking (one official speaking assignment in nearly every single class and lots of opportunities to participate and share thoughts in general). Plus, there is a lot of great speaking tips/strategies and you are given many examples of good speaking through the assigned homework. Putting together the tips and examples along with the opportunities for practice and feedback in each class, you have all the ingredients needed to dramatically improve your public speaking skills. If you are going to take this class, I would recommend planning to spend more time (maybe 5 hours a week) outside of class in order to really take advantage and grow as much as possible. But you really only need to spend an average of 2-3 hours per week to do well.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The class was mostly just presenting speeches that we wrote ourselves in front of the class; so not any particular technical skills, but more an exercise of reflecting on your own life and then present it from a podium to others.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learnt the art of public speaking - some tangible skills like how to structure effective supporting notes, how to tailor your speech to your audience, and then a few other abstract but powerful ones like how to listen and how to convert reflections into crisp speech. Each assignment taught me a skill tailored to it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to publicly speak using techniques such as pausing, voice control, and pacing. How to structure and write an effective speech. How to take notes effectively.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) That the best learning comes from your peers. While we read a textbook and watched videos, I took the most away from my classmates. 
2) That underpreparing is selling yourself short. While doing things the morning of or the night before can work, taking more time and effort to create and practice something will pay off IMMENSELY. 
3) That it's really hard to make changes. I've been "public speaking" for years, so tweaking that skill has been a tough and incomplete journey.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One of the most valuable lessons was learning how to organize a speech effectively. I learned techniques to connect with an audience, including the importance of tone, body language, and eye contact.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to confidently speak in front of an audience and use my fear as confidence. I learned how to speak to an intended audience and what a story worth sharing looks and sounds like.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The immediate feedback to every speech was incredible, and every assignment was amazingly fun to do. I loved the interviews and introductions activity. This course taught me not how to speak, but how to make the words I speak have an impact.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: We read a textbook, took notes in class, prepared speeches, and watched TedTalks. I think I took a lot of way from this method of teaching because we consumed information from a lot of different sources. I would keep the same format going forward.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The mix of planned speeches, impromptu exercises, and collaborative group work allowed me to practice different aspects of public speaking in varied contexts. Classmates’ feedback created a supportive environment and offered diverse perspectives on how my speeches were perceived.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved that the class was only 15 students and that it was a no technology classroom. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned techniques of public speaking, both in theory and in practice. I also learned how to display oneself in social settings, and the importance of those. Lastly, I learned to dream big and understand my role as a Duke Alumni.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: So many things, but to name three... confidence, poise and preparation. I learned how to have confidence when speaking in front of a group of people. Along with this, I learned how important it is to be poised in high pressure situations. Lastly, I learned how important it is to be prepared before class and the amazing things it can do for your performance.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed new skills in public speaking including stage presence, gestures, and tone. I also learned a lot of life lessons from both my professor and my classmates.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned public speaking tips about my body language, how to take effective notes on others' speaking, and how to "fake it 'till you make it" with confidence.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I developed my note-taking skills. I learned the value in taking notes in many situations, not just class lectures, and it's helped me to remember more details and synthesize information more effectively in both academic and non-academic settings. Professor Byerly's note-taking assignments were structured in a way that streamlined my notes while also making them more useful to me when I go back and check them.
2. I became a better listener. In addition to note-taking, Professor Byerly's assignment involving writing down memorable quotations that we hear in our everyday lives (from friends, colleagues, family members etc instead of just celebrities) pushed us to listen harder to those around us. This has not only made me more engaged with my surroundings but has led me to see the world in a different light thanks to my new focus on really appreciating the perspectives other people share instead of listening to respond.
3. I became a more confident and skillful orator. Public speaking is something that can only be learned by doing it, and we did it plenty in this class. At the end of the course, I not only felt more assured of myself behind the podium, but I learned what does and doesn't work so that I can give the most effective speeches possible.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned that public speaking is a mutable skill that can be improved with practice
I learned note-taking techniques and how to effectively prepare notes for a speech -- just enough information to guide talking points, but want flexibility and want to deliver speech naturally/authentically
I am learning how to use my voice and speaking style as an instrument
I learned the importance of being interested in what you're speaking about in order to produce a compelling speech -- it doesn't have to be a crazy story or niche topic, it just needs to be about what you care about and know about

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The art and science of public speaking, how to be a better listener and the different forms of speech (awards speeches, eulogies, interviews, etc.)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course teaches you how to be an effective speaker, breaking down the process from note-taking and preparation to delivery and effective listening techniques. We learned the academics of public speaking through our assigned readings, witnessed effective public speaking through our weekly Ted Talk videos, and then had the opportunity to deliver many speeches throughout the semester-- from improvised speeches, to historical speeches, to our own Ted Talk. We learned the basic etiquette of speaking-- always introduce yourself, never adjust your clothing-- and wrapped the semester up with effective interviewing techniques. I became much more confident behind the podium and learned so much about and from my peers.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

Even though sometimes it was hard to realize, speaking in public every single week helped me develop my speech-delivering and speech preparation skills. I think that the podium component of the class should definitely be kept for future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Being able to put the theory into practice by giving speeches in front of the class every week was genius, and I would definitely keep that. I believe there is no amount of theory that can teach one to speak in public, if they don't put themselves out there and try it out. Therefore this is the biggest advantage of this class, and exactly what should be kept.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The environment that was fostered made it easy to be relaxed and to learn. The small class component was vital in this as I feel like I learned so much about everyone and felt at ease around them all when it came time to deliver a speech in class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Her personal anecdotes really helped to facilitate our learning. I thought all of the assignments were compelling and worthwhile, as was the film we viewed near the end of the semester.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The no electronics policy in class created an environment that was very conducive to learning. I wish that all Duke professors had this policy. I loved the opportunity to give both prepared and extemporaneous speeches.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The environment was perhaps the most supportive seminar I've taken at Duke and it is in large part due to the efforts of Professor Byerly to build cohesion and camaraderie in the first few weeks of the course. The focus on opening up about personal stories (without requiring people to share beyond what they were comfortable with) made everyone in the class a person first, and classmate second. Combined with the consistent group feedback on people's speeches, the class overall felt incredibly collaborative even though we had very few assignments that were explicitly group work. Only one actually, if I'm remembering correctly, which makes it all the more impressive that the group was so connected without ever having been forced to connect with each other.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
I loved the opportunity to learn from my peers. It created a vulnerable, safe learning space, and we all brought different strengths to the table that we could learn from. Getting peers' feedback on our TEDx Talks was super valuable too: it can be hard to notice things I can improve upon up at the podium: for me, it took feedback from my peers to see these things (like the person who had no idea how often they said "like" from a story Dr. Byerly shared)
I like how Dr. Byerly did not reveal the details of assignments until the week before they were due (with the exception of major assignments like our TEDx Talk) because it prevented us from over-stressing and over-rehearsing

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Prof. Byerly did an amazing job of facilitating learning by teaching us to be reflective from day 1 and giving us opportunities to express ourselves in front of our peers.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Byerly is an extraordinarily engaging and interesting person-- her lectures draw on her extensive public speaking experience while weaving in anecdotes about growing up in Apartheid South Africa, studying music, moving to the United States, her voyages on Semester at Sea, the diary she's written in every single day, and her experience raising sons. I think the most effective part of the class was the no-technology rule; it ensured that everyone was focused and engaged. The homework videos are engaging and we always had enough time to prepare for our speeches.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Professor Byerly is one of the most engaging professors. The stories she tells are joyful and hilarious and, while occasionally off-topic, I always learn something from them. She really encouraged us to live our lives in a more meaningful way- from keeping track of memorable quotes we hear throughout the semester to keeping a list of things we love and things we hate. In addition to Professor Byerly, we learn so much from our peers in this class. We went from complete strangers to knowing so much about each other in a supportive and uplifting environment. I think the genuine conversation and lack of technology really made the class intellectually stimulating.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The hardest part will be snatching a spot in the class. That's not to say parts of the class weren't daunting, but it's not a class where the challenge is managing the workload. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You are genuinely lucky if you get a spot in this class. It is so popular and seats are limited, so if you are even remotely on the fence, enroll and do not look back. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Commit to the course-- do the readings on time, watch the Ted Talks, ask questions in class, keep track of memorable quotes, and practice as much as you can before giving a speech. In our assignments and speeches, we are asked to talk about very intimate and, occasionally traumatic, details about our lives. To get the most out of the course, you really have to share. You shouldn't take the course if that makes you uncomfortable.
